events.title: Narrator's Philosophy and Introduction to Gatsby
detailed_summary: The narrator, Nick Carraway, reflects on his father's advice to withhold criticism, acknowledging the unequal advantages people possess.
He explains that this inclination to reserve judgment has made him privy to many secrets but also subjected him to bores.
This quality led to him being misidentified as a 'politician' in college due to his access to the private struggles of others.
Nick confesses that his tolerance for human behavior is not limitless, particularly after a disillusioning experience back East.
He states that Jay Gatsby, the book's namesake, was uniquely exempt from his general post-East disillusionment, despite representing things Nick naturally scorns.
Nick describes Gatsby as possessing a 'gorgeous' quality, an exceptional sensitivity to life's possibilities, comparing it to a seismograph.
This quality wasn't mere impressionability but an unparalleled capacity for hope and romantic readiness.

Nick concludes that Gatsby himself was fundamentally decent; it was the corrupting influences surrounding his aspirations ('what foul dust floated in the wake of his dreams') that temporarily soured Nick's view of humanity.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: In my younger and more vulnerable years my father gave me some advice that I’ve been turning over in my mind ever since.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: No—Gatsby turned out all right at the end; it is what preyed on Gatsby, what foul dust floated in the wake of his dreams that temporarily closed out my interest in the abortive sorrows and short-winded elations of men.

events.text_segment:
In my younger and more vulnerable years my father gave me some advice that I’ve been turning over in my mind ever since.
“Whenever you feel like criticizing anyone,” he told me, “just remember that all the people in this world haven’t had the advantages that you’ve had.”
He didn’t say any more, but we’ve always been unusually communicative in a reserved way, and I understood that he meant a great deal more than that. In consequence, I’m inclined to reserve all judgements, a habit that has opened up many curious natures to me and also made me the victim of not a few veteran bores. The abnormal mind is quick to detect and attach itself to this quality when it appears in a normal person, and so it came about that in college I was unjustly accused of being a politician, because I was privy to the secret griefs of wild, unknown men. Most of the confidences were unsought—frequently I have feigned sleep, preoccupation, or a hostile levity when I realized by some unmistakable sign that an intimate revelation was quivering on the horizon; for the intimate revelations of young men, or at least the terms in which they express them, are usually plagiaristic and marred by obvious suppressions. Reserving judgements is a matter of infinite hope. I am still a little afraid of missing something if I forget that, as my father snobbishly suggested, and I snobbishly repeat, a sense of the fundamental decencies is parcelled out unequally at birth.
And, after boasting this way of my tolerance, I come to the admission that it has a limit. Conduct may be founded on the hard rock or the wet marshes, but after a certain point I don’t care what it’s founded on. When I came back from the East last autumn I felt that I wanted the world to be in uniform and at a sort of moral attention forever; I wanted no more riotous excursions with privileged glimpses into the human heart. Only Gatsby, the man who gives his name to this book, was exempt from my reaction—Gatsby, who represented everything for which I have an unaffected scorn. If personality is an unbroken series of successful gestures, then there was something gorgeous about him, some heightened sensitivity to the promises of life, as if he were related to one of those intricate machines that register earthquakes ten thousand miles away. This responsiveness had nothing to do with that flabby impressionability which is dignified under the name of the “creative temperament”—it was an extraordinary gift for hope, a romantic readiness such as I have never found in any other person and which it is not likely I shall ever find again. No—Gatsby turned out all right at the end; it is what preyed on Gatsby, what foul dust floated in the wake of his dreams that temporarily closed out my interest in the abortive sorrows and short-winded elations of men.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: During my youth, when I was more impressionable and vulnerable, my father shared advice that has resonated with me ever since. He told me, 'Whenever you feel like criticizing someone, just remember that not everyone in this world has had the advantages you've had.' He said no more, but given our typically reserved yet communicative relationship, I understood he meant something much deeper. Consequently, I tend to withhold judgments, a practice that has led many interesting individuals to reveal their true selves to me, while also making me a target for numerous experienced bores. People with unusual mentalities quickly recognize and attach themselves to this trait in a typical person, which is why during college, I was unfairly labeled a politician because I was privy to the private troubles of wild, unfamiliar men. Most of these confidences were unsolicited – I frequently pretended to be asleep, preoccupied, or dismissively cheerful when I sensed, through some clear signal, that a personal revelation was about to begin; this is because the intimate confessions of young men, or at least their expression, are usually imitative and marked by obvious omissions. The act of reserving judgment is an act of boundless hope. I still worry about missing something if I forget the (as my father snobbishly suggested and I snobbishly agree) unequal distribution of fundamental decency at birth. And after boasting about my tolerance, I must admit it has a breaking point. Conduct might originate from strong foundations or unstable ones, but beyond a certain threshold, I lose interest in its source. Upon returning from the East last autumn, I felt a desire for the world to conform to a sort of permanent moral discipline; I no longer wanted unrestrained glimpses into the human heart. Only Gatsby, the figure this book is named after, was exempt from this reaction – Gatsby, who embodied qualities I generally disdained. If personality is an uninterrupted series of successful actions, then there was something magnificent about him, a heightened capacity for life's potential, as if he were like a complex instrument registering earthquakes thousands of miles away. This responsiveness wasn't mere superficial impressionability often misidentified as 'creative temperament' – it was an exceptional gift for hope, a romantic readiness unlike anything I have ever encountered and am unlikely to find again. No, Gatsby himself turned out alright; it was what preyed upon him, the corrupt influence ('foul dust') that followed his dreams, that temporarily extinguished my interest in the failed sorrows and fleeting enthusiasms of others.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14: When I was younger and more impressionable, my father once gave me advice that has stayed with me. He told me, "Before you criticize someone, remember that not everyone has had your privileges." He never elaborated, but our family always communicated in a subtle way, so I knew his words carried greater meaning. Because of this advice, I tend to avoid judging others, which has made people of many sorts open up to me—though it has also left me enduring some tedious company. Those with unusual minds can sense and seek out this trait, and so during college, I was wrongly assumed to be a politician, simply because I knew the private troubles of many wild and mysterious men. I usually did not ask for these confidences—often I'd pretend to be busy or even asleep to avoid hearing them, since young men's personal revelations are often unoriginal and incomplete. To withhold judgment requires great optimism. I still worry that I’ll miss something important if I forget, as my father rather proudly implied and I now repeat, that basic decency isn’t equally distributed at birth. Yet, admitting all this about my tolerance, I recognize it has its boundaries. People may act from good or shaky principles, but beyond a certain point, their motives no longer matter to me. After returning from the East last fall, I wished the world would maintain a high moral standard and avoid wild adventures into people’s hearts. The only exception was Gatsby, after whom this book is named. Despite Gatsby embodying much that I normally disdain, he had a remarkable charm—a heightened sense for life’s possibilities, similar to a sensitive device recording distant tremors. This attribute was not the usual so-called artistic openness, but rather an amazing capacity for hope, a romantic optimism I’ve never seen before and don’t expect to again. In the end, Gatsby himself was innocent; it was the corrupting influences around him, the tainted aftermath of his dreams, that made me lose faith in the shallow joys and fleeting sorrows of other men.

events.title: Nick's Background and Move East
detailed_summary: Nick outlines his family background as established and prosperous Midwesterners, with a humorous note about their supposed noble ancestry.
He mentions his actual lineage traces back to his great-uncle who started a wholesale hardware business.
He graduated from Yale (New Haven) in 1915 and later fought in the Great War.
His war experience left him feeling restless and finding the Midwest lacking.
Consequently, he decided to relocate East to pursue a career in the bond business, a common path for young men he knew.
His family discussed and approved the move, with his father providing financial support for the first year.
He arrived East in the spring of 1922, believing the move to be permanent.
Although initially considering city lodging, the warm weather and his preference for lawns and trees led him to accept a colleague's suggestion to rent a house together in a nearby town.
The colleague was unexpectedly transferred to Washington, leaving Nick to occupy the rented house alone.
His initial household included a briefly owned dog, an old car, and a Finnish housekeeper who cooked and cleaned.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: My family have been prominent, well-to-do people in this Middle Western city for three generations.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I had a dog—at least I had him for a few days until he ran away—and an old Dodge and a Finnish woman, who made my bed and cooked breakfast and muttered Finnish wisdom to herself over the electric stove.

events.text_segment:
My family have been prominent, well-to-do people in this Middle Western city for three generations. The Carraways are something of a clan, and we have a tradition that we’re descended from the Dukes of Buccleuch, but the actual founder of my line was my grandfather’s brother, who came here in fifty-one, sent a substitute to the Civil War, and started the wholesale hardware business that my father carries on today.
I never saw this great-uncle, but I’m supposed to look like him—with special reference to the rather hard-boiled painting that hangs in father’s office. I graduated from New Haven in 1915, just a quarter of a century after my father, and a little later I participated in that delayed Teutonic migration known as the Great War. I enjoyed the counter-raid so thoroughly that I came back restless. Instead of being the warm centre of the world, the Middle West now seemed like the ragged edge of the universe—so I decided to go East and learn the bond business. Everybody I knew was in the bond business, so I supposed it could support one more single man. All my aunts and uncles talked it over as if they were choosing a prep school for me, and finally said, “Why—ye-es,” with very grave, hesitant faces. Father agreed to finance me for a year, and after various delays I came East, permanently, I thought, in the spring of twenty-two.
The practical thing was to find rooms in the city, but it was a warm season, and I had just left a country of wide lawns and friendly trees, so when a young man at the office suggested that we take a house together in a commuting town, it sounded like a great idea. He found the house, a weather-beaten cardboard bungalow at eighty a month, but at the last minute the firm ordered him to Washington, and I went out to the country alone. I had a dog—at least I had him for a few days until he ran away—and an old Dodge and a Finnish woman, who made my bed and cooked breakfast and muttered Finnish wisdom to herself over the electric stove.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: For three generations, my family has been prominent and well-off in a city in the Middle West. The Carraways function somewhat like a clan, and we have a long-held belief that we are descendants of the Dukes of Buccleuch. However, the true originator of my branch of the family was my grandfather’s brother, who arrived here in 1851. He avoided fighting in the Civil War by hiring someone to go in his place and established the wholesale hardware business that my father operates today. I never met this great-uncle, but people say I resemble him, especially noting the stern painting of him displayed in my father’s office. I finished my studies at New Haven in 1915, exactly twenty-five years after my father, and a little later, I took part in the military action against Germany known as the Great War. I found the experience of the counter-attack quite satisfying, so much so that I returned home feeling unsettled. Instead of being the vibrant core of the world, the Middle West now struck me as a distant, unpolished fringe—leading me to decide to move East and learn the bond market business. Everyone I knew was involved in the bond business, so I presumed there would be enough room for one more single person. My aunts and uncles discussed my plan extensively, as if they were selecting a preparatory school for me, and finally gave their cautious, somewhat hesitant consent, saying, “Why—ye-es.” My father agreed to support me financially for a year, and following various delays, I moved East, intending it to be a permanent relocation, in the spring of 1922. The practical approach would have been to find accommodation in the city itself, but it was a warm period, and I had recently left an area with spacious lawns and welcoming trees. Thus, when a young man from the office suggested we rent a house together in a town outside the city, it seemed like an excellent idea. He located the property, a weathered, simple bungalow costing eighty dollars a month. However, at the very last moment, his company transferred him to Washington, and I moved into the country house alone. I had a dog—at least for a few days until he ran off—an old Dodge car, and a Finnish woman who cleaned, prepared my breakfast, and murmured Finnish proverbs to herself over the electric stove.

For three generations, my family has been well-regarded and affluent residents of this Midwestern city. The Carraways are somewhat of an extended family, and there's a family legend that we're descended from the Dukes of Buccleuch, but in reality, our family line in America began with my grandfather's brother. He arrived here in 1851, avoided fighting in the Civil War by sending someone in his place, and established the wholesale hardware business that my father continues today.

I never met this founder, but people say I resemble him, particularly as depicted in the stern portrait in my father's office. I graduated from Yale in 1915, just twenty-five years after my father, and soon after, I served in World War I. I enjoyed the action so much that I returned home feeling unsettled. The Midwest, which once felt like the center of everything, now appeared remote and insignificant. So, I decided to move East and learn the bond business, as it seemed everyone I knew was doing the same and I figured there was room for me too. My extended family discussed my plans as though they were choosing a preparatory school, and eventually agreed, albeit reluctantly. My father agreed to support me financially for a year, and after some delays, I moved East permanently in the spring of 1922.

It made sense to find an apartment in the city, but since the weather was warm and I missed the open spaces of my old home, I was attracted to the idea, suggested by a coworker, of renting a house together in a suburb. He found a shabby bungalow for eighty dollars a month, but before we could move in together, he was transferred to Washington, so I ended up living there alone. I briefly had a dog, who soon ran away, an old Dodge car, and a Finnish housekeeper who cooked my breakfast, made my bed, and spoke Finnish sayings to herself as she worked in the kitchen.

events.title: Settling into West Egg and Renewed Ambition
detailed_summary: Nick's initial loneliness dissipated after he gave directions to a newly arrived man, making him feel like a part of the community.
The onset of summer brought a strong sense that life was restarting.
He felt there was much to learn and experience, drawing energy from the environment.
He bought books on finance and investments, hoping they would reveal the secrets to wealth, standing like 'new money' on his shelf.
He also intended to revive his collegiate literary pursuits, aiming to become a 'well-rounded man'.
He reflects, however, that focusing on one perspective might be a more successful way to view life.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: It was lonely for a day or so until one morning some man, more recently arrived than I, stopped me on the road.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: This isn’t just an epigram—life is much more successfully looked at from a single window, after all.

events.text_segment:
It was lonely for a day or so until one morning some man, more recently arrived than I, stopped me on the road.
“How do you get to West Egg village?” he asked helplessly.
I told him. And as I walked on I was lonely no longer. I was a guide, a pathfinder, an original settler. He had casually conferred on me the freedom of the neighbourhood.
And so with the sunshine and the great bursts of leaves growing on the trees, just as things grow in fast movies, I had that familiar conviction that life was beginning over again with the summer.
There was so much to read, for one thing, and so much fine health to be pulled down out of the young breath-giving air. I bought a dozen volumes on banking and credit and investment securities, and they stood on my shelf in red and gold like new money from the mint, promising to unfold the shining secrets that only Midas and Morgan and Maecenas knew. And I had the high intention of reading many other books besides. I was rather literary in college—one year I wrote a series of very solemn and obvious editorials for the Yale News—and now I was going to bring back all such things into my life and become again that most limited of all specialists, the “well-rounded man.” This isn’t just an epigram—life is much more successfully looked at from a single window, after all.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: I felt a sense of isolation for a couple of days, until one morning, a man who had moved to the area even more recently than I had, stopped me on the road. He looked lost and asked, 'How can I find my way to West Egg village?' I told him the directions. As I continued my walk, the feeling of loneliness was gone. I felt like a local expert, a pioneer, an established resident. Simply by asking for directions, he had inadvertently granted me a sense of belonging in the community. Consequently, amidst the bright sun and the rapid emergence of leaves on the trees, resembling scenes in fast-forwarded films, I felt that familiar conviction that life was starting fresh with the arrival of summer. For one thing, there was so much reading material available, and I felt I could absorb abundant good health from the young, life-giving air. I purchased twelve books covering banking, credit, and investment securities. They sat on my bookshelf, bound in red and gold, looking like freshly printed money and promising to reveal the valuable secrets known only to legendary wealthy figures such as Midas, Morgan, and Maecenas. Furthermore, I fully intended to read many other books as well. In college, I had a penchant for literature – one year I authored a series of quite serious and obvious opinion pieces for the Yale News – and now I planned to bring back these kinds of interests into my life and once again become that rather limited type of person, the 'well-rounded man.' This is more than just a witty remark; ultimately, it is often more effective to observe life from a singular, focused viewpoint.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14: For a day or two, I felt lonely, but then one morning a man who was newer to the area than I was stopped me on the road to ask directions to West Egg village. I gave him directions, and after that, I didn’t feel alone anymore. I felt like a guide and a pioneer—he had, in a sense, informally given me the right to feel like I belonged in the neighborhood. With the sunlight and the rapid growth of leaves on the trees, as if in a sped-up film, I had the recurring feeling that summer was a chance for life to start fresh. There was so much to learn and take in from the invigorating young air. I bought several books about banking, credit, and investments, which sat on my shelf, bright and new, as if they were fresh coins, filled with the promise of sharing secrets known only to people like Midas, Morgan, or Maecenas. I also intended to read many other books. Back in college, I had a literary streak—even wrote a series of serious and rather obvious articles for the Yale News one year—and I now aimed to return to that and once again become that rare kind of specialist: the well-rounded man. This isn’t just a clever saying—after all, life is better understood when viewed from a single perspective.

events.title: Geography of the Eggs and Arrival at the Buchanans'
detailed_summary: Nick describes the peculiar geography of his new home on Long Island: two adjacent, identically shaped peninsulas ('eggs') separated by a bay.
He notes their contrast despite physical similarity: West Egg, where he lives, is considered less fashionable than East Egg.
His own small house is positioned between two large estates, renting for significant sums.
The mansion to his right, an imitation Hôtel de Ville with vast grounds, belongs to Mr. Gatsby, whom he hasn't met.
Nick appreciates his own modest house for its view and proximity to the wealthy.
Across the bay, the opulent white mansions of East Egg are visible.
The narrative proper begins as Nick drives to East Egg to dine with Tom and Daisy Buchanan.
He clarifies his relationship: Daisy is his second cousin once removed, and he knew Tom at Yale.
He recounts Tom's past athletic achievements and immense family wealth, noting Tom's recent move East with a string of polo ponies.
Nick speculates that Tom's restlessness stems from seeking the thrill of his past football career.
He arrives at the Buchanans' impressive red-and-white Georgian Colonial mansion.
He observes the vast lawn rolling up to the house and Tom Buchanan standing confidently on the porch.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: It was a matter of chance that I should have rented a house in one of the strangest communities in North America.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The front was broken by a line of French windows, glowing now with reflected gold and wide open to the warm windy afternoon, and Tom Buchanan in riding clothes was standing with his legs apart on the front porch.

events.text_segment:
It was a matter of chance that I should have rented a house in one of the strangest communities in North America. It was on that slender riotous island which extends itself due east of New York—and where there are, among other natural curiosities, two unusual formations of land. Twenty miles from the city a pair of enormous eggs, identical in contour and separated only by a courtesy bay, jut out into the most domesticated body of salt water in the Western hemisphere, the great wet barnyard of Long Island Sound. They are not perfect ovals—like the egg in the Columbus story, they are both crushed flat at the contact end—but their physical resemblance must be a source of perpetual wonder to the gulls that fly overhead. To the wingless a more interesting phenomenon is their dissimilarity in every particular except shape and size.
I lived at West Egg, the—well, the less fashionable of the two, though this is a most superficial tag to express the bizarre and not a little sinister contrast between them. My house was at the very tip of the egg, only fifty yards from the Sound, and squeezed between two huge places that rented for twelve or fifteen thousand a season. The one on my right was a colossal affair by any standard—it was a factual imitation of some Hôtel de Ville in Normandy, with a tower on one side, spanking new under a thin beard of raw ivy, and a marble swimming pool, and more than forty acres of lawn and garden. It was Gatsby’s mansion. Or, rather, as I didn’t know Mr. Gatsby, it was a mansion inhabited by a gentleman of that name. My own house was an eyesore, but it was a small eyesore, and it had been overlooked, so I had a view of the water, a partial view of my neighbour’s lawn, and the consoling proximity of millionaires—all for eighty dollars a month.
Across the courtesy bay the white palaces of fashionable East Egg glittered along the water, and the history of the summer really begins on the evening I drove over there to have dinner with the Tom Buchanans. Daisy was my second cousin once removed, and I’d known Tom in college. And just after the war I spent two days with them in Chicago.
Her husband, among various physical accomplishments, had been one of the most powerful ends that ever played football at New Haven—a national figure in a way, one of those men who reach such an acute limited excellence at twenty-one that everything afterward savours of anticlimax. His family were enormously wealthy—even in college his freedom with money was a matter for reproach—but now he’d left Chicago and come East in a fashion that rather took your breath away: for instance, he’d brought down a string of polo ponies from Lake Forest. It was hard to realize that a man in my own generation was wealthy enough to do that.
Why they came East I don’t know. They had spent a year in France for no particular reason, and then drifted here and there unrestfully wherever people played polo and were rich together. This was a permanent move, said Daisy over the telephone, but I didn’t believe it—I had no sight into Daisy’s heart, but I felt that Tom would drift on forever seeking, a little wistfully, for the dramatic turbulence of some irrecoverable football game.
And so it happened that on a warm windy evening I drove over to East Egg to see two old friends whom I scarcely knew at all. Their house was even more elaborate than I expected, a cheerful red-and-white Georgian Colonial mansion, overlooking the bay. The lawn started at the beach and ran towards the front door for a quarter of a mile, jumping over sundials and brick walks and burning gardens—finally when it reached the house drifting up the side in bright vines as though from the momentum of its run. The front was broken by a line of French windows, glowing now with reflected gold and wide open to the warm windy afternoon, and Tom Buchanan in riding clothes was standing with his legs apart on the front porch.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1:
It was just by chance that I ended up renting a house in one of North America's most unusual places. This location is on a thin, bustling island that extends directly east of New York City, featuring, among other notable natural sights, two peculiar land formations. About twenty miles from the city, a pair of enormous, identically shaped landmasses, resembling eggs and separated by a small bay, push out into Long Island Sound, the calmest saltwater area in the Western Hemisphere, like a vast wet farmyard. They aren't perfectly oval; like the egg in the famous story, both are flattened at the point where they almost touch. However, their physical similarity must be a constant source of amazement for the seagulls flying overhead. For those on the ground, their differences in every aspect except shape and size are a more interesting observation.
I resided in West Egg, which was the—well, the less prestigious of the two, though describing it as just 'less fashionable' doesn't fully capture the strange and somewhat ominous contrast between them. My home was situated right at the tip of the egg-shaped peninsula, merely fifty yards from the Sound, positioned between two enormous estates that cost twelve or fifteen thousand dollars to rent for the season. The one on my right was incredibly large by any standard; it was a faithful copy of a town hall from Normandy, France, complete with a tower on one side, looking brand new under a thin covering of fresh ivy, and it boasted a marble swimming pool and over forty acres of gardens and lawn. This was Gatsby’s mansion. Or, more accurately, since I hadn't met Mr. Gatsby, it was the mansion inhabited by a gentleman named Gatsby. My own house was unattractive, but it was small enough to be overlooked, which provided me with a view of the water, a partial view of my neighbor’s extensive grounds, and the comforting closeness of millionaires—all for just eighty dollars a month.
Across the small bay, the elegant white mansions of fashionable East Egg gleamed along the waterfront. The story of the summer truly begins on the evening I drove across the bay to have dinner with Tom and Daisy Buchanan. Daisy was my second cousin once removed, and I had known Tom from our time in college. I had also spent two days with them in Chicago immediately following the war.
Among his many athletic achievements, her husband had been one of the most formidable football players (an 'end') ever at Yale—a well-known figure nationally for a period, one of those people who achieve such focused, high-level skill at twenty-one that everything afterward feels anticlimactic. His family was immensely wealthy—even during college, his casual spending was criticized—but he had now left Chicago and moved East in a way that was quite impressive: for example, he had transported a group of polo horses from Lake Forest. It was difficult to comprehend that someone my age had the wealth to do such a thing.
I don’t know why they came East. They had spent a year in France without any particular reason, and then had restlessly moved from place to place wherever rich people gathered and played polo. Daisy told me over the phone that this was a permanent move, but I didn't believe her; I couldn’t see into Daisy’s heart, but I felt that Tom would continue drifting indefinitely, searching, perhaps a little sadly, for the intense excitement of some unforgettable football game he could never relive.
And so it was that on a pleasant, breezy evening, I drove over to East Egg to visit two old friends whom, paradoxically, I barely knew anymore. Their house was even more elaborate than I had anticipated, a cheerful Georgian Colonial mansion in red and white, overlooking the bay. The lawn started at the beach and stretched towards the front door for a quarter of a mile, flowing over sundials and brick walkways and vibrant flower gardens. Finally, as it reached the house, it seemed to climb the side walls as bright vines, as if carried by its own momentum. The front of the house was punctuated by a line of French windows, now glowing with reflected gold and wide open to the warm, windy afternoon, and Tom Buchanan, dressed in riding clothes, stood on the front porch with his legs spread apart.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
Purely by chance, I happened to rent a house in one of North America's most unusual neighborhoods. This community was situated on a narrow, lively island stretching directly east from New York City, notable for two distinctive land shapes. About twenty miles from the city, two enormous land masses—shaped like eggs and nearly identical—protrude into Long Island Sound, separated only by a narrow strip of water. These 'eggs' aren't perfect ovals; instead, they're slightly flattened where they touch, much like the egg from the Columbus story, which must constantly amaze the seagulls flying overhead. But for those on the ground, what's even more striking is how different the two areas are, despite their similar shapes and sizes.

I lived in West Egg, which was considered less fashionable—though that only hints at the odd and rather unsettling differences between the two. My own small, rundown house sat at the very tip of West Egg, barely fifty yards from the water, squeezed between two grand estates that rented for as much as twelve or fifteen thousand dollars a season. The enormous property on my right was modeled after a French town hall, complete with a tower, new ivy, a marble pool, and over forty acres of gardens. This was Gatsby’s mansion, though at the time, I didn’t know Gatsby himself, and only knew it belonged to someone named Gatsby. My modest home was unsightly, but being small and overlooked, it gave me a view of the water, a glimpse of my neighbor's luxurious lawn, and the comfort of living near millionaires—all for just eighty dollars a month.

On the other side of the bay, the elegant houses of fashionable East Egg gleamed by the water. The real story of the summer began the evening I drove over there to have dinner with Tom and Daisy Buchanan. Daisy was my distant cousin, and I had known Tom at college. Shortly after the war, I visited them for a couple of days in Chicago.

Tom, in addition to his physical prowess, had been a star football player at Yale, becoming something of a national celebrity and reaching a peak so early in life that everything afterwards seemed less impressive. His family was extremely affluent—even at college, his lavish spending was remarkable. Now he’d left Chicago and moved East in a spectacular way, even bringing a team of polo ponies from Lake Forest, which seemed almost unbelievable for someone my age.

I never really understood why they moved East. After spending a year in France for no particular reason, they drifted from place to place, following wealthy crowds and polo matches. Daisy claimed this move was permanent, but I doubted it. I couldn’t see into Daisy’s mind, but I had a sense that Tom would always be searching for the excitement and intensity of a long-lost football game.

So, on a warm and windy evening, I set off to East Egg to visit two old friends—though, truthfully, I barely knew them at all. Their house was even more impressive than I expected: a bright red-and-white Georgian Colonial mansion overlooking the bay. Its lawn stretched from the beach towards the front door for a quarter mile, crossing sundials, brick paths, and vibrant gardens, eventually climbing up the house in a cascade of vines. The front of the house was lined with glowing French windows thrown wide open to the gentle afternoon breeze, and Tom Buchanan, dressed in riding clothes, stood on the porch with his feet planted firmly apart.

events.title: Tom's Introduction and Meeting Daisy and Jordan
detailed_summary: Nick describes Tom's physical transformation since college: now a sturdy, hard-featured man of thirty exuding arrogance and aggression.
Tom's powerful build seems barely contained by his riding clothes, suggesting a 'cruel body'.
His husky voice adds to the impression of fractiousness and paternal contempt.
Nick recalls their Yale senior society connection, sensing Tom desired his approval despite their lack of intimacy.
Tom briefly boasts about his estate, showing Nick the grounds.
They enter a bright, airy room filled with wind blowing through open windows, causing curtains to flutter dramatically.
Two young women in white dresses, Daisy Buchanan and Jordan Baker, recline on a large couch, appearing almost weightless.
Tom closing the windows stills the room, causing the women and furnishings to 'settle'.
Jordan lies motionless, chin slightly raised as if balancing something.
Daisy greets Nick with a charming laugh and exaggerated claims of happiness, holding his hand warmly.
Daisy quietly identifies the other woman as Miss Baker.
Jordan acknowledges Nick with a nearly imperceptible nod, seemingly disturbed in her pose.
Nick is immediately struck by Daisy's captivating, musical voice.
He observes her sad yet lovely face, noting the unforgettable excitement conveyed through her voice, hinting at thrilling experiences past and future.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: He had changed since his New Haven years.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Her face was sad and lovely with bright things in it, bright eyes and a bright passionate mouth, but there was an excitement in her voice that men who had cared for her found difficult to forget: a singing compulsion, a whispered “Listen,” a promise that she had done gay, exciting things just a while since and that there were gay, exciting things hovering in the next hour.

events.text_segment:
He had changed since his New Haven years. Now he was a sturdy straw-haired man of thirty, with a rather hard mouth and a supercilious manner. Two shining arrogant eyes had established dominance over his face and gave him the appearance of always leaning aggressively forward. Not even the effeminate swank of his riding clothes could hide the enormous power of that body—he seemed to fill those glistening boots until he strained the top lacing, and you could see a great pack of muscle shifting when his shoulder moved under his thin coat. It was a body capable of enormous leverage—a cruel body.
His speaking voice, a gruff husky tenor, added to the impression of fractiousness he conveyed. There was a touch of paternal contempt in it, even toward people he liked—and there were men at New Haven who had hated his guts.
“Now, don’t think my opinion on these matters is final,” he seemed to say, “just because I’m stronger and more of a man than you are.” We were in the same senior society, and while we were never intimate I always had the impression that he approved of me and wanted me to like him with some harsh, defiant wistfulness of his own.
We talked for a few minutes on the sunny porch.
“I’ve got a nice place here,” he said, his eyes flashing about restlessly.
Turning me around by one arm, he moved a broad flat hand along the front vista, including in its sweep a sunken Italian garden, a half acre of deep, pungent roses, and a snub-nosed motorboat that bumped the tide offshore.
“It belonged to Demaine, the oil man.” He turned me around again, politely and abruptly. “We’ll go inside.”
We walked through a high hallway into a bright rosy-coloured space, fragilely bound into the house by French windows at either end. The windows were ajar and gleaming white against the fresh grass outside that seemed to grow a little way into the house. A breeze blew through the room, blew curtains in at one end and out the other like pale flags, twisting them up toward the frosted wedding-cake of the ceiling, and then rippled over the wine-coloured rug, making a shadow on it as wind does on the sea.
The only completely stationary object in the room was an enormous couch on which two young women were buoyed up as though upon an anchored balloon. They were both in white, and their dresses were rippling and fluttering as if they had just been blown back in after a short flight around the house. I must have stood for a few moments listening to the whip and snap of the curtains and the groan of a picture on the wall. Then there was a boom as Tom Buchanan shut the rear windows and the caught wind died out about the room, and the curtains and the rugs and the two young women ballooned slowly to the floor.
The younger of the two was a stranger to me. She was extended full length at her end of the divan, completely motionless, and with her chin raised a little, as if she were balancing something on it which was quite likely to fall. If she saw me out of the corner of her eyes she gave no hint of it—indeed, I was almost surprised into murmuring an apology for having disturbed her by coming in.
The other girl, Daisy, made an attempt to rise—she leaned slightly forward with a conscientious expression—then she laughed, an absurd, charming little laugh, and I laughed too and came forward into the room.
“I’m p-paralysed with happiness.”
She laughed again, as if she said something very witty, and held my hand for a moment, looking up into my face, promising that there was no one in the world she so much wanted to see. That was a way she had. She hinted in a murmur that the surname of the balancing girl was Baker. (I’ve heard it said that Daisy’s murmur was only to make people lean toward her; an irrelevant criticism that made it no less charming.)
At any rate, Miss Baker’s lips fluttered, she nodded at me almost imperceptibly, and then quickly tipped her head back again—the object she was balancing had obviously tottered a little and given her something of a fright. Again a sort of apology arose to my lips. Almost any exhibition of complete self-sufficiency draws a stunned tribute from me.
I looked back at my cousin, who began to ask me questions in her low, thrilling voice. It was the kind of voice that the ear follows up and down, as if each speech is an arrangement of notes that will never be played again. Her face was sad and lovely with bright things in it, bright eyes and a bright passionate mouth, but there was an excitement in her voice that men who had cared for her found difficult to forget: a singing compulsion, a whispered “Listen,” a promise that she had done gay, exciting things just a while since and that there were gay, exciting things hovering in the next hour.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1:
Tom had undergone changes since his college days at New Haven. He was now a robust, sandy-haired man in his early thirties, with a somewhat stern mouth and an air of arrogance. His two bright, haughty eyes dominated his face, creating the impression that he was perpetually leaning forward aggressively. The effect of his powerful physique was undeniable, even his somewhat feminine riding clothes couldn't conceal it—his glistening boots seemed strained by his legs, and you could see significant muscle shifts under his thin coat when he moved his shoulder. It was a body built for tremendous physical force—a body that felt cruel.
His voice, a low, raspy tenor, reinforced the sense of irritability he projected. It carried a hint of condescending superiority, even towards acquaintances—and some men from New Haven had intensely disliked him.
He seemed to communicate, implicitly, "Don't assume my judgment on these subjects is absolute merely because I possess greater strength and masculinity than you." We were members of the same exclusive college society, and while we were never close, I always felt he approved of me and desired my liking, perhaps with a certain harsh, defiant longing of his own.
We chatted briefly on the sunny porch.
"This is a pleasant estate I've got," he remarked, his gaze restlessly scanning his surroundings.
Taking hold of my arm, he turned me to face the sweeping view from the front, indicating a submerged Italian-style garden, a half-acre section filled with dense, fragrant roses, and a small, blunt motorboat bobbing on the water offshore.
"It previously belonged to Demaine, the oil magnate." He then turned me back around, politely but abruptly. "Let's go inside."
We walked through a tall entryway into a bright, rosy-hued room, bordered subtly at both ends by French windows that connected it to the house. The windows were slightly open, appearing stark white against the fresh green lawn outside that seemed to spill a little way into the room. A breeze swept through, causing the curtains to billow inward at one end and outward at the other like pale flags, spiraling them upwards towards the ornate, cake-like ceiling, before skimming across the deep red rug, creating a wave-like shadow as wind does on the surface of the sea.
The sole object in the room that remained perfectly still was a massive sofa where two young women reclined, appearing suspended as if on a tethered hot air balloon. They were both dressed in white, their gowns undulating and fluttering as though they had just drifted back inside after a brief flight around the residence. I must have stood for a few moments, listening to the sharp sound of the curtains flapping and a framed picture creaking on the wall. Then, with a distinct thud, Tom Buchanan closed the rear windows, and the captured wind in the room subsided, causing the curtains, the rug, and the two young women to settle slowly downwards onto the floor.
The younger of the two was unfamiliar to me. She was stretched out fully on her end of the sofa, completely still, her chin slightly lifted, as if she were balancing an object that might easily fall. If she noticed me peripherally, she gave no indication—in fact, I was nearly prompted to softly utter an apology for disturbing her entry. Her appearance exuded a perfect self-reliance.
The other young woman, Daisy, attempted to stand—she leaned slightly forward with a conscientious look—then she laughed, a delightful, slightly silly little laugh, and I joined in and moved further into the room.
"I'm utterly frozen with happiness," she declared.
She laughed again, as if she had just said something exceptionally clever, and held my hand momentarily, looking up into my face, assuring me that I was the person in the world she most wanted to see. This was typical behavior for her. She hinted in a soft tone that the last name of the woman balancing was Baker. (I've heard it suggested that Daisy's soft voice was just a technique to make people lean closer; a trivial observation that didn't diminish her charm at all.)
Regardless, Miss Baker's lips twitched slightly, she gave me an almost imperceptible nod, and then quickly tilted her head back again—the item she was balancing had evidently wobbled slightly, startling her. Again, an urge to apologize arose within me. Any display of complete self-sufficiency tends to elicit an awestruck respect from me.
I glanced back at my cousin, who began to question me in her low, captivating voice. It was the sort of voice that holds your attention, rising and falling as if each phrase were a unique musical sequence that would never be repeated. Her face was beautiful and held a touch of sadness, yet was bright with vibrant features—sparkling eyes and a vibrant, expressive mouth. However, it was the excitement in her voice that men who had loved her found unforgettable: a compelling, melodic quality, a hushed invitation to 'Listen,' a suggestion that she had recently experienced joyful, thrilling events and that more delightful, exciting things were waiting in the immediate future.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
He was different now than he had been during his college days at New Haven. He was a strong, fair-haired man of thirty, with a tough mouth and an arrogant attitude. His two bold, gleaming eyes dominated his face, making him look as if he was always aggressively pushing forward. The delicate look of his riding attire could not conceal the raw strength of his body—he seemed to fill out his shiny boots so much that they strained at the laces, and when he moved his shoulder beneath his thin jacket, you could see his muscles shifting. His physique suggested great power—a harsh, capable body. 

His voice, with its gruff and husky tenor, contributed to the sense of restlessness he projected. He spoke with a trace of condescending authority, even to those he liked—there had been men at New Haven who couldn't stand him. It was as if he was always saying, 'Don't assume my opinion is conclusive just because I'm stronger and more masculine than you.' We had been in the same senior group, and although we were never close friends, I always felt he approved of me and wanted my approval as well, in a somewhat rough, longing way.

We chatted for a short while on his sunlit porch. 

"I have a great place here," he told me, his eyes darting inquisitively around. He turned me by the arm and, with a broad hand, gestured across the front of the property, showing me an Italian garden below, a stretch of deep, fragrant roses, and a blunt-nosed motorboat bobbing in the offshore tide. "It used to be Demaine's, the oil millionaire," he said, suddenly and courteously turning me again. "Let's go inside."

We entered a tall hallway that led to a bright, rose-tinted room, barely tied to the rest of the house by French windows at each end. The windows were open, standing white against the fresh grass outside, which seemed to reach slightly indoors. A breeze moved through the room, pushing curtains in at one end and out the other like pale flags, twisting them toward the cake-like, frosted ceiling, and then rippling the wine-colored rug, casting shifting shadows across it like wind over the sea.

The only thing in the room that didn't move was a huge sofa, where two young women seemed to be anchored as if atop a tethered balloon. Both were dressed in white, and their dresses floated and billowed as though they had just breezed back in from a quick flight around the house. I stood for several moments, listening to the snapping curtains and the groaning picture on the wall. Then, Tom Buchanan slammed shut the rear windows, the breeze vanished, and the curtains, rug, and two women slowly settled to the ground.

Of the two women, one was a stranger to me. She was stretched out on her end of the sofa, perfectly still, her chin slightly raised as if balancing something that might fall at any moment. Even if she noticed me from the side of her eyes, she didn't show it—in fact, I almost felt compelled to apologize for bothering her by arriving.

The other woman, Daisy, tried to get up—she leaned forward with earnestness—then let out a charming, quirky little laugh, prompting me to do the same as I entered the room. "I'm paralyzed with happiness," she exclaimed. She laughed again as if making a clever remark, held my hand briefly, and looked up at me in a way that made it seem as if I was the only person she wanted to see. That was characteristic of her. She quietly hinted that the other woman's last name was Baker. (People say Daisy's soft-spoken manner forced others to lean in to hear her; a critique that didn't diminish her appeal.)

Miss Baker barely moved her lips and nodded at me, then quickly tilted her head back again—whatever she was 'balancing' seemed to wobble and unsettle her. Again, I almost apologized—I'm always awed by displays of absolute self-assurance.

I turned back to Daisy, who began to ask me questions in her low, captivating voice—the kind the ear follows as if it were a melodic tune heard only once. Her face was beautiful and a bit sad, with sparkling eyes and a passionate mouth; but her voice held a kind of excitement that men found unforgettable: a musical kind of insistence, a whisper that invited you to listen—a suggestion that she had just experienced something joyful and interesting, and that something equally thrilling was about to happen next.

events.title: Drawing Room Banter and Introduction of Gatsby's Name
detailed_summary: Nick shares greetings from acquaintances in Chicago.
Daisy reacts with performative delight, suggesting they move back immediately, then mentions her unseen daughter.
Tom interrupts to inquire about Nick's profession.
Upon learning Nick is a bond salesman, Tom dismissively states he hasn't heard of Nick's firm, irritating Nick.
Nick asserts Tom will hear of it if he remains in the East.
Tom confirms his intention to stay East, glancing meaningfully at Daisy.
Jordan Baker unexpectedly and emphatically agrees with Tom.
Jordan rises, complaining of stiffness from her prolonged pose on the couch.
Daisy implies Jordan resisted earlier suggestions to go to New York.
Jordan refuses a cocktail, citing that she is in training.
Tom expresses incredulity about Jordan achieving anything.
Nick studies Jordan, noting her athletic build, erect posture, and wan, discontented expression, feeling he's seen her before.
Jordan contemptuously remarks that Nick lives in West Egg and mentions knowing someone there.
Before Nick can state he knows no one, Jordan names Gatsby.
Daisy inquires, 'What Gatsby?'
Dinner is announced just as Nick is about to explain Gatsby is his neighbor, and Tom forcefully escorts him from the room.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: I told her how I had stopped off in Chicago for a day on my way East, and how a dozen people had sent their love through me.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Before I could reply that he was my neighbour dinner was announced; wedging his tense arm imperatively under mine, Tom Buchanan compelled me from the room as though he were moving a checker to another square.

events.text_segment:
I told her how I had stopped off in Chicago for a day on my way East, and how a dozen people had sent their love through me.
“Do they miss me?” she cried ecstatically.
“The whole town is desolate. All the cars have the left rear wheel painted black as a mourning wreath, and there’s a persistent wail all night along the north shore.”
“How gorgeous! Let’s go back, Tom. Tomorrow!” Then she added irrelevantly: “You ought to see the baby.”
“I’d like to.”
“She’s asleep. She’s three years old. Haven’t you ever seen her?”
“Never.”
“Well, you ought to see her. She’s—”
Tom Buchanan, who had been hovering restlessly about the room, stopped and rested his hand on my shoulder.
“What you doing, Nick?”
“I’m a bond man.”
“Who with?”
I told him.
“Never heard of them,” he remarked decisively.
This annoyed me.
“You will,” I answered shortly. “You will if you stay in the East.”
“Oh, I’ll stay in the East, don’t you worry,” he said, glancing at Daisy and then back at me, as if he were alert for something more. “I’d be a God damned fool to live anywhere else.”
At this point Miss Baker said: “Absolutely!” with such suddenness that I started—it was the first word she had uttered since I came into the room. Evidently it surprised her as much as it did me, for she yawned and with a series of rapid, deft movements stood up into the room.
“I’m stiff,” she complained, “I’ve been lying on that sofa for as long as I can remember.”
“Don’t look at me,” Daisy retorted, “I’ve been trying to get you to New York all afternoon.”
“No, thanks,” said Miss Baker to the four cocktails just in from the pantry. “I’m absolutely in training.”
Her host looked at her incredulously.
“You are!” He took down his drink as if it were a drop in the bottom of a glass. “How you ever get anything done is beyond me.”
I looked at Miss Baker, wondering what it was she “got done.” I enjoyed looking at her. She was a slender, small-breasted girl, with an erect carriage, which she accentuated by throwing her body backward at the shoulders like a young cadet. Her grey sun-strained eyes looked back at me with polite reciprocal curiosity out of a wan, charming, discontented face. It occurred to me now that I had seen her, or a picture of her, somewhere before.
“You live in West Egg,” she remarked contemptuously. “I know somebody there.”
“I don’t know a single—”
“You must know Gatsby.”
“Gatsby?” demanded Daisy. “What Gatsby?”
Before I could reply that he was my neighbour dinner was announced; wedging his tense arm imperatively under mine, Tom Buchanan compelled me from the room as though he were moving a checker to another square.

She then added unexpectedly, 'You really should see the baby.' 'I'd like to,' I said. 'She's sleeping. She's three years old. Haven't you ever seen her?' 'Never.' 'Well, you must see her. events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
I shared with her that I had spent a day in Chicago during my journey east, and that many people had sent their regards through me. 

"Do they miss me?" she exclaimed joyfully. 

"Everyone in town is miserable without you. All the cars have their rear left wheels painted black as a sign of mourning, and there's a constant sound of lament all night on the north shore."

"How wonderful! Let's go back, Tom. Tomorrow!" she said, then added out of nowhere, "You should see the baby."

"I'd like that."

"She's asleep. She's three. Have you ever met her?"

"No, never."

"Well, you really should. She's—"

Tom Buchanan, who had been restlessly pacing, paused and placed his hand on my shoulder.

"What are you doing, Nick?"

"I'm in the bond business."

"Which firm?"

I told him the name.

"Never heard of them," he said definitely.

I found this irritating.

"You will," I replied briefly. "Especially if you stay in the East."

"Oh, I'll stay in the East, you can count on that," he replied, glancing at Daisy and then at me, as if waiting for something more. "I'd be a fool to live anywhere else."

At this, Miss Baker suddenly said, "Absolutely!" so unexpectedly that I jumped—it was the first thing she'd said since I arrived. She seemed as surprised as I was, as she yawned and stood up briskly from the sofa.

"I'm stiff," she complained. "I've been lying there for ages."

"Don't blame me," Daisy said, "I've been trying to get you to come to New York all afternoon."

"No, thank you," Miss Baker replied to the four cocktails brought from the pantry. "I'm training."

Their host stared at her, incredulous.

"You are?" He quickly finished his own drink. "I have no idea how you manage to get anything done."

I observed Miss Baker, curious about what it was that she accomplished. I liked watching her. She was a slender young woman with an upright posture, made even more noticeable by the way she threw her shoulders back. Her gray eyes, tired from the sun, looked at me with a polite but slightly discontented interest from her pale, charming face. It struck me that I'd seen her, or her photograph, somewhere before.

"You live in West Egg, don't you?" she said with a hint of disdain. "I know someone there."

"I don't know anyone—"

"You must know Gatsby."

"Gatsby?" Daisy asked. "What Gatsby?"

Before I could explain that he was my neighbor, dinner was announced; Tom firmly linked his arm with mine and ushered me out of the room as if he were moving a piece on a chessboard.

events.title: Dinner Tensions and Tom's Racist Rant
detailed_summary: Daisy and Jordan lead the way to the dinner porch, where candles flicker.
Daisy extinguishes the candles, commenting on the approaching summer solstice.
Jordan listlessly suggests making plans.
Daisy shows a bruised knuckle, accusing Tom of causing it, calling him a 'brute'.
Tom protests the word 'hulking'.
Nick observes the cool, detached manner of conversation between Daisy and Jordan, contrasting it with more engaged Western interactions.
Nick makes a light comment about feeling 'uncivilized', asking about mundane topics like crops.
Tom reacts violently, declaring civilization is disintegrating and referencing a racist book by 'Goddard'.
He asserts the scientific validity of white racial superiority and the need to suppress other races.
Daisy lightly mocks Tom's intellectual pretensions.
Tom insists on the scientific basis of his ideas, identifying the group (including Daisy after hesitation) as 'Nordics' responsible for civilization.
Nick perceives a sense of desperation beneath Tom's assertive racism.
The telephone rings inside, interrupting Tom, and the butler goes to answer it.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Slenderly, languidly, their hands set lightly on their hips, the two young women preceded us out on to a rosy-coloured porch, open toward the sunset, where four candles flickered on the table in the diminished wind.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: When, almost immediately, the telephone rang inside and the butler left the porch Daisy seized upon the momentary interruption and leaned towards me.

events.text_segment:
Slenderly, languidly, their hands set lightly on their hips, the two young women preceded us out on to a rosy-coloured porch, open toward the sunset, where four candles flickered on the table in the diminished wind.
“Why candles?” objected Daisy, frowning. She snapped them out with her fingers. “In two weeks it’ll be the longest day in the year.” She looked at us all radiantly. “Do you always watch for the longest day of the year and then miss it? I always watch for the longest day in the year and then miss it.”
“We ought to plan something,” yawned Miss Baker, sitting down at the table as if she were getting into bed.
“All right,” said Daisy. “What’ll we plan?” She turned to me helplessly: “What do people plan?”
Before I could answer her eyes fastened with an awed expression on her little finger.
“Look!” she complained; “I hurt it.”
We all looked—the knuckle was black and blue.
“You did it, Tom,” she said accusingly. “I know you didn’t mean to, but you did do it. That’s what I get for marrying a brute of a man, a great, big, hulking physical specimen of a—”
“I hate that word ‘hulking,’ ” objected Tom crossly, “even in kidding.”
“Hulking,” insisted Daisy.
Sometimes she and Miss Baker talked at once, unobtrusively and with a bantering inconsequence that was never quite chatter, that was as cool as their white dresses and their impersonal eyes in the absence of all desire. They were here, and they accepted Tom and me, making only a polite pleasant effort to entertain or to be entertained. They knew that presently dinner would be over and a little later the evening too would be over and casually put away. It was sharply different from the West, where an evening was hurried from phase to phase towards its close, in a continually disappointed anticipation or else in sheer nervous dread of the moment itself.
“You make me feel uncivilized, Daisy,” I confessed on my second glass of corky but rather impressive claret. “Can’t you talk about crops or something?”
I meant nothing in particular by this remark, but it was taken up in an unexpected way.
“Civilization’s going to pieces,” broke out Tom violently. “I’ve gotten to be a terrible pessimist about things. Have you read The Rise of the Coloured Empires by this man Goddard?”
“Why, no,” I answered, rather surprised by his tone.
“Well, it’s a fine book, and everybody ought to read it. The idea is if we don’t look out the white race will be—will be utterly submerged. It’s all scientific stuff; it’s been proved.”
“Tom’s getting very profound,” said Daisy, with an expression of unthoughtful sadness. “He reads deep books with long words in them. What was that word we—”
“Well, these books are all scientific,” insisted Tom, glancing at her impatiently. “This fellow has worked out the whole thing. It’s up to us, who are the dominant race, to watch out or these other races will have control of things.”
“We’ve got to beat them down,” whispered Daisy, winking ferociously toward the fervent sun.
“You ought to live in California—” began Miss Baker, but Tom interrupted her by shifting heavily in his chair.
“This idea is that we’re Nordics. I am, and you are, and you are, and—” After an infinitesimal hesitation he included Daisy with a slight nod, and she winked at me again. “—And we’ve produced all the things that go to make civilization—oh, science and art, and all that. Do you see?”
There was something pathetic in his concentration, as if his complacency, more acute than of old, was not enough to him any more. When, almost immediately, the telephone rang inside and the butler left the porch Daisy seized upon the momentary interruption and leaned towards me.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: Moving gracefully and without haste, the two young women, with their hands resting lightly on their hips, went ahead of us onto a pinkish porch facing the setting sun. On the table there, four candles gently flickered in the reduced breeze. Daisy frowned and asked, "Why candles?" She quickly put them out with her fingers. "In two weeks, it will be the longest day of the year," she said, looking brightly at all of us. "Do you always anticipate the longest day and then let it pass? I always look forward to the longest day of the year and somehow never observe it." Yawning, Miss Baker commented, "We should make some plans," as she settled into her chair at the table, appearing as relaxed as if she were getting into bed. "Okay," Daisy agreed. "What shall we plan?" She turned to me, seeming lost, and asked, "What kinds of things do people plan?" Before I had a chance to reply, she looked with a look of surprise and concern at her little finger. "Look!" she exclaimed, complaining, "I've hurt it." We all looked, and her knuckle was bruised and discolored. "You did this, Tom," she said, blaming him. "I know you didn't intend to, but you actually did it. This is what happens when I marry a brutal man, a huge, imposing physical specimen of a—" Tom interrupted grumpily, "I dislike that word 'hulking,' even when you're joking." "Hulking," Daisy repeated firmly. At times, she and Miss Baker spoke simultaneously, subtly and with playful randomness that wasn't quite trivial chat. It was as cool as their white dresses and their detached eyes, lacking any strong desire. They were present, and they accepted Tom and me, making only a polite, effortless attempt to entertain or be entertained. They understood that dinner would soon be over, and a little later, the evening itself would also end and be dismissed without ceremony. This felt starkly different from the West, where an evening was hurried through stages towards its conclusion, either in constant disappointed anticipation or in sheer nervous apprehension of the present moment. "You make me feel unsophisticated, Daisy," I admitted after my second glass of somewhat impressive but corky claret. "Couldn't you perhaps talk about farming or something similar?" I didn't have any specific meaning behind this comment, but it was received in an unforeseen manner. "Civilization is collapsing," Tom declared aggressively. "I've become extremely pessimistic about things. Have you read 'The Rise of the Colored Empires' by this author, Goddard?" "Why, no," I replied, somewhat taken aback by how he said it. "Well, it's an excellent book, and everyone should read it," he said. "The central idea is that if we aren't careful, the white race will be... completely overwhelmed. It's all scientific data; it's been substantiated." "Tom is becoming quite intellectual," Daisy remarked with an air of thoughtless sadness. "He reads complicated books with difficult words. What was that word we—" "Look, these books are all scientific," Tom insisted, giving her an impatient look. "This expert has fully developed the entire concept. It's our responsibility, as the leading race, to be vigilant, or these other races will take charge." "We have to suppress them," Daisy whispered, winking intensely towards the strong sunlight. "You should live in California—" Miss Baker started to say, but Tom stopped her by shifting his weight heavily in his chair. "The theory is that we are Nordic," he explained. "I am, and you are, and you are, and—" After a very brief pause, he included Daisy with a slight nod, and she winked at me again. "—And we have created everything that constitutes civilization—you know, science and art, and all of that. Understand?" There was something sad about how focused he was, as if his self-satisfaction, more intense than before, was no longer enough for him. When the telephone inside the house rang almost immediately and the butler left the porch, Daisy seized the brief interruption and leaned towards me.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
Gracefully and leisurely, with their hands resting gently at their sides, the two young women led us outside onto a porch tinged with a pink glow from the setting sun. Four candles flickered on the table in the gentle breeze. "Why do we need candles?" Daisy questioned, frowning, as she extinguished them with her fingers. "In two weeks it’ll be the longest day of the year." She beamed at us. "Do any of you ever wait for the longest day of the year only to miss it? I always do." 

"We should make plans," Miss Baker said with a yawn, settling into her chair as if she were slipping into bed.

"Okay," Daisy replied. "What should we plan?" She looked at me uncertainly. "What do people normally plan?"

Before I could answer, her gaze fixated on her little finger in surprise. "Look," she complained, "I hurt it." 

We all looked and saw her knuckle was bruised. "It was you, Tom," she accused. "I know you didn’t intend it, but it happened. That’s what comes from marrying a brute of a man, a huge, hulking example of—"

"I dislike that word, 'hulking,'" Tom interrupted irritably, "even in a joke."

"Hulking," Daisy repeated stubbornly.

Occasionally, she and Miss Baker spoke at the same time, softly and playfully, never quite rambling, and their manner was as composed as their white dresses and uninterested gazes. They were present and welcoming to Tom and me, making only a modest show of interest or amusement. They understood that dinner would soon finish and the evening would pass quietly, in stark contrast to the West, where evenings felt rushed and filled with anxious expectation or dread about how they'd end.

"You make me feel uncultured, Daisy," I confessed after my second glass of wine. "Can’t you talk about farming or something?"

I hadn't meant anything significant, but the comment took an unexpected turn.

"Civilization’s falling apart," Tom burst out. "I’ve become very pessimistic about things. Have you read 'The Rise of the Coloured Empires' by this Goddard fellow?"

"No," I replied, surprised by his intensity.

"It’s a great book—everyone should read it. The premise is that, unless we’re careful, the white race will be overwhelmed. It’s all scientifically proven."

"Tom’s getting very philosophical," said Daisy with a hint of absent sadness. "He reads deep books with long words. What was that word we—"

"These books are all scientific," Tom insisted, impatiently. "This man’s figured everything out. As the dominant race, it’s our duty to make sure other races don’t take over."

"We have to stop them," Daisy murmured, winking at the fiery sunset.

"You ought to move to California—" Miss Baker started, but Tom cut her off by shifting in his seat.

"The point is, we’re Nordics. I am, you are, and you are," he said, after a tiny pause including Daisy with a nod, and she winked at me again. "We’re the people who made civilization—science, art, and everything. Understand?"

There was something sadly earnest in his focus, as if his self-satisfaction was no longer enough for him. Then, as the telephone rang inside and the butler left the porch, Daisy used the brief interruption to lean closer to me.

events.title: Phone Call Interruptions and Revelation of Tom's Affair
detailed_summary: During the interruption, Daisy leans in to tell Nick a fabricated 'secret' about the butler's nose.
Her captivating manner draws Nick in momentarily before the effect fades.
The butler returns, speaks privately to Tom, who then leaves the table frowning.
In Tom's absence, Daisy turns her charm on Nick again, comparing him to a rose.
Nick recognizes the insincerity but feels her warmth.
Daisy abruptly excuses herself and goes inside.
Nick and Jordan share a look devoid of meaning.
Jordan silences Nick, listening intently to a muffled, emotional conversation from indoors.
After the sounds cease, Jordan reveals to Nick that Tom has a mistress in New York.
Jordan expresses annoyance that the woman calls during dinner.
Tom and Daisy return to the table together.
Daisy attempts to cover the tension with forced gaiety, talking about the romantic atmosphere outdoors.
Tom appears unhappy and suggests showing Nick the stables later.
The telephone rings again; Daisy firmly signals Tom, and the conversation dissolves.
Nick recalls the candles being relit unnecessarily and the heavy, awkward silence, feeling the palpable tension caused by the unseen caller.
He reflects that the situation felt alarming rather than intriguing.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “I’ll tell you a family secret,” she whispered enthusiastically.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: To a certain temperament the situation might have seemed intriguing—my own instinct was to telephone immediately for the police.

events.text_segment:
“I’ll tell you a family secret,” she whispered enthusiastically. “It’s about the butler’s nose. Do you want to hear about the butler’s nose?”
“That’s why I came over tonight.”
“Well, he wasn’t always a butler; he used to be the silver polisher for some people in New York that had a silver service for two hundred people. He had to polish it from morning till night, until finally it began to affect his nose—”
“Things went from bad to worse,” suggested Miss Baker.
“Yes. Things went from bad to worse, until finally he had to give up his position.”
For a moment the last sunshine fell with romantic affection upon her glowing face; her voice compelled me forward breathlessly as I listened—then the glow faded, each light deserting her with lingering regret, like children leaving a pleasant street at dusk.
The butler came back and murmured something close to Tom’s ear, whereupon Tom frowned, pushed back his chair, and without a word went inside. As if his absence quickened something within her, Daisy leaned forward again, her voice glowing and singing.
“I love to see you at my table, Nick. You remind me of a—of a rose, an absolute rose. Doesn’t he?” She turned to Miss Baker for confirmation: “An absolute rose?”
This was untrue. I am not even faintly like a rose. She was only extemporizing, but a stirring warmth flowed from her, as if her heart was trying to come out to you concealed in one of those breathless, thrilling words. Then suddenly she threw her napkin on the table and excused herself and went into the house.
Miss Baker and I exchanged a short glance consciously devoid of meaning. I was about to speak when she sat up alertly and said “Sh!” in a warning voice. A subdued impassioned murmur was audible in the room beyond, and Miss Baker leaned forward unashamed, trying to hear. The murmur trembled on the verge of coherence, sank down, mounted excitedly, and then ceased altogether.
“This Mr. Gatsby you spoke of is my neighbour—” I began.
“Don’t talk. I want to hear what happens.”
“Is something happening?” I inquired innocently.
“You mean to say you don’t know?” said Miss Baker, honestly surprised. “I thought everybody knew.”
“I don’t.”
“Why—” she said hesitantly. “Tom’s got some woman in New York.”
“Got some woman?” I repeated blankly.
Miss Baker nodded.
“She might have the decency not to telephone him at dinner time. Don’t you think?”
Almost before I had grasped her meaning there was the flutter of a dress and the crunch of leather boots, and Tom and Daisy were back at the table.
“It couldn’t be helped!” cried Daisy with tense gaiety.
She sat down, glanced searchingly at Miss Baker and then at me, and continued: “I looked outdoors for a minute, and it’s very romantic outdoors. There’s a bird on the lawn that I think must be a nightingale come over on the Cunard or White Star Line. He’s singing away—” Her voice sang: “It’s romantic, isn’t it, Tom?”
“Very romantic,” he said, and then miserably to me: “If it’s light enough after dinner, I want to take you down to the stables.”
The telephone rang inside, startlingly, and as Daisy shook her head decisively at Tom the subject of the stables, in fact all subjects, vanished into air. Among the broken fragments of the last five minutes at table I remember the candles being lit again, pointlessly, and I was conscious of wanting to look squarely at everyone, and yet to avoid all eyes. I couldn’t guess what Daisy and Tom were thinking, but I doubt if even Miss Baker, who seemed to have mastered a certain hardy scepticism, was able utterly to put this fifth guest’s shrill metallic urgency out of mind. To a certain temperament the situation might have seemed intriguing—my own instinct was to telephone immediately for the police.

There's a bird on the lawn that I'm certain must be a nightingale that arrived on a transatlantic ship. It's singing away—" Her voice became lyrical: "It's romantic, isn't it, Tom?" As Daisy shook her head decisively at Tom, the topic of the stables, and indeed all previous conversation points, dissolved into thin air. I couldn't decipher what Daisy and Tom were thinking, but I doubted if even Miss Baker, who seemed to possess a certain tough skepticism, could completely dismiss the unseen guest's shrill, metallic urgency from her mind. To some personalities, the situation might have seemed intriguing—my own immediate impulse was to call the police.
