events.title: Nick and Jordan's Intimacy Grows in Central Park
detailed_summary: As night falls fully and their carriage travels under a bridge, Nick's focus shifts from Gatsby's elaborate plan concerning Daisy.
He acts on his attraction to Jordan, putting his arm around her and pulling her closer.
He invites her to dinner.
Nick reflects on his perception of Jordan as 'clean, hard, limited' and appreciates her 'universal scepticism'.
He finds himself drawn to her as she leans back within his embrace.
A thought about the categories of people crystallizes in his mind: 'There are only the pursued, the pursuing, the busy, and the tired.'
Jordan softly comments that Daisy 'ought to have something in her life,' hinting at dissatisfaction in Daisy's marriage.
Nick asks if Daisy is aware of the plan or wants to see Gatsby.
Jordan clarifies that Daisy must not know about the arrangement beforehand; Nick's invitation should appear as a simple, casual tea.
As their carriage passes the illuminated façade of Fifty-Ninth Street, Nick contrasts his own romantic situation with that of Gatsby and Tom.
Unlike them, he doesn't have an idealized, disembodied female face haunting his thoughts.
Motivated by this reflection and Jordan's faint, 'wan, scornful' smile, he tightens his embrace.
He draws her closer still, bringing his face near hers as the chapter ends on this intimate moment.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: It was dark now, and as we dipped under a little bridge I put my arm around Jordan’s golden shoulder and drew her toward me and asked her to dinner.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Her wan, scornful mouth smiled, and so I drew her up again closer, this time to my face.

events.text_segment:
It was dark now, and as we dipped under a little bridge I put my arm around Jordan’s golden shoulder and drew her toward me and asked her to dinner. Suddenly I wasn’t thinking of Daisy and Gatsby any more, but of this clean, hard, limited person, who dealt in universal scepticism, and who leaned back jauntily just within the circle of my arm. A phrase began to beat in my ears with a sort of heady excitement: “There are only the pursued, the pursuing, the busy, and the tired.”
“And Daisy ought to have something in her life,” murmured Jordan to me.
“Does she want to see Gatsby?”
“She’s not to know about it. Gatsby doesn’t want her to know. You’re just supposed to invite her to tea.”
We passed a barrier of dark trees, and then the façade of Fifty-Ninth Street, a block of delicate pale light, beamed down into the park. Unlike Gatsby and Tom Buchanan, I had no girl whose disembodied face floated along the dark cornices and blinding signs, and so I drew up the girl beside me, tightening my arms. Her wan, scornful mouth smiled, and so I drew her up again closer, this time to my face.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: It had grown dark now, and as we drove under a small bridge, I gently put my arm around Jordan's radiant shoulder, drew her nearer, and asked her to join me for dinner. My mind suddenly shifted away from Daisy and Gatsby, focusing instead on this direct, firm, perhaps limited individual, who held a deeply skeptical view of everything and who leaned back comfortably within the space of my arm. A particular phrase began to echo in my mind with a kind of exhilarating intensity: 'There are only those who are pursued, those who pursue, those who are busy, and those who are weary.' Jordan quietly said to me, 'And Daisy really needs something in her life.' I asked, 'Does she actually want to see Gatsby?' She responded, 'She's not meant to know about his desire to see her. Gatsby wants it kept a secret. Your only job is to invite her for tea.' We drove past a cluster of dark trees, and then the front of Fifty-Ninth Street, a building illuminated with a soft, pale glow, cast its light down into the park. Unlike Gatsby and Tom Buchanan, I didn't have the image of a girl's detached face appearing among the shadows of the buildings and the bright signs; consequently, I pulled the girl beside me closer, tightening my hold. Her pale, slightly disdainful lips curved into a smile, so I drew her even closer again, bringing her face next to mine this time.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
Night had fallen, and as we went beneath a small bridge, I slipped my arm around Jordan’s shimmering shoulder and pulled her near, inviting her to dinner. My thoughts shifted away from Daisy and Gatsby, focusing instead on Jordan herself—straightforward, self-assured, a woman marked by worldly doubt, who leaned back with confidence just inside my embrace. A particular phrase echoed in my mind with a rush of excitement: “There are only the pursued, the pursuing, the busy, and the tired.”

Jordan quietly remarked, “Daisy should have something in her life.”

I asked, “Does she want to see Gatsby?”

“She shouldn’t know about it. Gatsby doesn’t want her to. You just need to invite her to tea.”

We went beyond a barrier of dark trees, and then the soft, pale lights of Fifty-Ninth Street shone down onto the park. Unlike Gatsby or Tom Buchanan, there wasn’t a woman whose intangible image haunted me through the city streets, so I held Jordan closer, my arms tightening around her. She gave a thin, mocking smile, which made me pull her even nearer, this time pressing her face to mine.

events.title: Gatsby's Proposition and Tea Arrangement
detailed_summary: Nick arrives home late to find Gatsby's entire mansion inexplicably illuminated.
Initially thinking it's another party, Nick realizes the house is silent except for the wind.
Gatsby approaches Nick across the lawn.
Nick comments on the house looking like the World's Fair.
Gatsby deflects, suggesting trips to Coney Island or his pool, which Nick declines due to the late hour.
Gatsby waits with barely concealed anticipation.
Nick confirms he has spoken to Jordan Baker and will invite Daisy for tea.
Gatsby feigns nonchalance, insisting Nick shouldn't be troubled.
They awkwardly negotiate a suitable day, with Gatsby expressing concern about the state of Nick's lawn.
Gatsby hesitantly brings up another matter, ascertaining Nick's modest income.
He vaguely offers Nick a chance to make money through a confidential 'side line' business, implicitly connected to his association with Wolfshiem.
Nick firmly refuses the offer, stating he is too busy, understanding it's likely a thinly veiled payment for arranging the tea.
Gatsby seems disappointed but accepts the refusal and returns home.
Nick reflects on the evening and prepares for bed, unsure of Gatsby's subsequent actions.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: When I came home to West Egg that night I was afraid for a moment that my house was on fire.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: So I don’t know whether or not Gatsby went to Coney Island, or for how many hours he “glanced into rooms” while his house blazed gaudily on.

events.text_segment:
When I came home to West Egg that night I was afraid for a moment that my house was on fire. Two o’clock and the whole corner of the peninsula was blazing with light, which fell unreal on the shrubbery and made thin elongating glints upon the roadside wires. Turning a corner, I saw that it was Gatsby’s house, lit from tower to cellar.
At first I thought it was another party, a wild rout that had resolved itself into “hide-and-go-seek” or “sardines-in-the-box” with all the house thrown open to the game. But there wasn’t a sound. Only wind in the trees, which blew the wires and made the lights go off and on again as if the house had winked into the darkness. As my taxi groaned away I saw Gatsby walking toward me across his lawn.
“Your place looks like the World’s Fair,” I said.
“Does it?” He turned his eyes toward it absently. “I have been glancing into some of the rooms. Let’s go to Coney Island, old sport. In my car.”
“It’s too late.”
“Well, suppose we take a plunge in the swimming pool? I haven’t made use of it all summer.”
“I’ve got to go to bed.”
“All right.”
He waited, looking at me with suppressed eagerness.
“I talked with Miss Baker,” I said after a moment. “I’m going to call up Daisy tomorrow and invite her over here to tea.”
“Oh, that’s all right,” he said carelessly. “I don’t want to put you to any trouble.”
“What day would suit you?”
“What day would suit you?” he corrected me quickly. “I don’t want to put you to any trouble, you see.”
“How about the day after tomorrow?”
He considered for a moment. Then, with reluctance: “I want to get the grass cut,” he said.
We both looked down at the grass—there was a sharp line where my ragged lawn ended and the darker, well-kept expanse of his began. I suspected that he meant my grass.
“There’s another little thing,” he said uncertainly, and hesitated.
“Would you rather put it off for a few days?” I asked.
“Oh, it isn’t about that. At least—” He fumbled with a series of beginnings. “Why, I thought—why, look here, old sport, you don’t make much money, do you?”
“Not very much.”
This seemed to reassure him and he continued more confidently.
“I thought you didn’t, if you’ll pardon my—you see, I carry on a little business on the side, a sort of side line, you understand. And I thought that if you don’t make very much—You’re selling bonds, aren’t you, old sport?”
“Trying to.”
“Well, this would interest you. It wouldn’t take up much of your time and you might pick up a nice bit of money. It happens to be a rather confidential sort of thing.”
I realize now that under different circumstances that conversation might have been one of the crises of my life. But, because the offer was obviously and tactlessly for a service to be rendered, I had no choice except to cut him off there.
“I’ve got my hands full,” I said. “I’m much obliged but I couldn’t take on any more work.”
“You wouldn’t have to do any business with Wolfshiem.” Evidently he thought that I was shying away from the “gonnegtion” mentioned at lunch, but I assured him he was wrong. He waited a moment longer, hoping I’d begin a conversation, but I was too absorbed to be responsive, so he went unwillingly home.
The evening had made me lightheaded and happy; I think I walked into a deep sleep as I entered my front door. So I don’t know whether or not Gatsby went to Coney Island, or for how many hours he “glanced into rooms” while his house blazed gaudily on.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: Returning to my place in West Egg that evening, I had a brief fear that my house was ablaze. It was two in the morning, and the entire point of the peninsula was lit up brightly, the light falling unnaturally on the shrubs and creating slender, elongated reflections on the wires along the road. As I rounded a bend, I saw that the light was emanating from Gatsby's residence, illuminated from its highest point to its lowest.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
When I returned to West Egg that night, for a moment I feared my house was on fire. It was two in the morning and the whole end of the peninsula was shining with light, creating an unreal effect on the bushes and casting long reflections on the telephone wires alongside the road. As I turned a corner, I realized it was Gatsby’s house, lit up from top to bottom.

At first, I assumed it must be another one of his extravagant parties and thought perhaps people were playing games throughout the house. But it was silent; the only sound was the wind rustling the trees and making the lights flicker on and off, as if the house was blinking in the darkness. As my taxi departed, I saw Gatsby walking across his lawn toward me.

"Your house looks like the World’s Fair," I remarked.

"Does it?" he replied absentmindedly, glancing at the house. "I’ve just been looking into some of the rooms. Why don’t we go to Coney Island, old sport? In my car."

"It’s too late for that."

"Then how about a swim in the pool? I haven’t used it all summer."

"I need to get some sleep."

"All right."

He lingered, appearing eager but holding back.

"I spoke with Miss Baker," I eventually said. "I’ll call Daisy tomorrow and ask her over for tea."

"That’s fine," he replied nonchalantly. "I don’t want to trouble you."

"Which day works for you?"

He quickly replied, "Which day works for you? I really don’t want to put you out, you know."

"How about the day after tomorrow?"

He thought for a bit and then said, reluctantly, "I should get the grass cut."

We both looked down at the lawn. There was a clear, sharp line where my patchy grass stopped and Gatsby’s lush lawn began. I had a feeling he meant he wanted my grass cut.

"There’s another small thing," he said, hesitating.

"Would you prefer to wait a few days?" I asked.

"Oh, it’s not that. At least—" He fumbled for words. "Well, old sport, you don’t earn a lot, do you?"

"Not very much."

He seemed comforted by this and continued, more assuredly.

"I thought as much. If you don’t mind my mentioning it—I have a bit of a side business, nothing too big, you understand. I thought that since you don’t earn much—and you’re selling bonds, right, old sport?"

"I’m trying to."

"Well, you might find this interesting. It wouldn’t take much of your time and could make you some decent money. The job is rather confidential."

I realize now that in another setting, this conversation could have been a turning point in my life. But since it was obviously an awkward offer in exchange for a favor, I felt compelled to decline.

"I’m already busy," I told him. "I appreciate it, but I can’t take on anything else."

"You wouldn’t have to deal with Wolfshiem." He clearly thought I was hesitant because of the connection mentioned over lunch, but I told him that wasn’t the case. He waited a bit, hoping I would start talking again, but I was too distracted, and he eventually left for home, disappointed.

The events of the evening had left me dizzy but happy; I probably drifted into deep sleep as soon as I got inside. I’m still not sure if Gatsby actually went to Coney Island, or how long he continued wandering through his brilliantly illuminated house.

events.title: Anxious Preparations and Waiting
detailed_summary: The next morning, Nick calls Daisy from his office and invites her to tea, specifically telling her not to bring Tom.
Daisy pretends not to know who Tom is.
The agreed-upon day arrives with heavy rain.
Gatsby sends a man to mow Nick's lawn despite the downpour.
Nick realizes he forgot to arrange for his maid and drives to the village to find her and buy supplies.
Gatsby sends an enormous quantity of flowers, filling Nick's house.
An hour before the appointed time, Gatsby arrives, dressed impeccably but looking pale and sleep-deprived.
He nervously asks if everything is satisfactory, initially seeming confused about Nick's comment regarding the lawn.
Gatsby vaguely comments on the weather forecast and inquires about the tea arrangements.
Nick shows him the pantry and the lemon cakes; Gatsby approves faintly.
As the rain lessens slightly, Gatsby waits, looking distractedly through a book, startled by noises, and frequently glancing out the window.
He becomes increasingly agitated, checking his watch and declaring that Daisy isn't coming because it's too late.
Nick reassures him it's only two minutes before the hour.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: I called up Daisy from the office next morning, and invited her to come to tea.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Don’t be silly; it’s just two minutes to four.”

events.text_segment:
I called up Daisy from the office next morning, and invited her to come to tea.
“Don’t bring Tom,” I warned her.
“What?”
“Don’t bring Tom.”
“Who is ‘Tom’?” she asked innocently.
The day agreed upon was pouring rain. At eleven o’clock a man in a raincoat, dragging a lawn-mower, tapped at my front door and said that Mr. Gatsby had sent him over to cut my grass. This reminded me that I had forgotten to tell my Finn to come back, so I drove into West Egg Village to search for her among soggy whitewashed alleys and to buy some cups and lemons and flowers.
The flowers were unnecessary, for at two o’clock a greenhouse arrived from Gatsby’s, with innumerable receptacles to contain it. An hour later the front door opened nervously, and Gatsby in a white flannel suit, silver shirt, and gold-coloured tie, hurried in. He was pale, and there were dark signs of sleeplessness beneath his eyes.
“Is everything all right?” he asked immediately.
“The grass looks fine, if that’s what you mean.”
“What grass?” he inquired blankly. “Oh, the grass in the yard.” He looked out the window at it, but, judging from his expression, I don’t believe he saw a thing.
“Looks very good,” he remarked vaguely. “One of the papers said they thought the rain would stop about four. I think it was The Journal. Have you got everything you need in the shape of—of tea?”
I took him into the pantry, where he looked a little reproachfully at the Finn. Together we scrutinized the twelve lemon cakes from the delicatessen shop.
“Will they do?” I asked.
“Of course, of course! They’re fine!” and he added hollowly, “… old sport.”
The rain cooled about half-past three to a damp mist, through which occasional thin drops swam like dew. Gatsby looked with vacant eyes through a copy of Clay’s Economics, starting at the Finnish tread that shook the kitchen floor, and peering towards the bleared windows from time to time as if a series of invisible but alarming happenings were taking place outside. Finally he got up and informed me, in an uncertain voice, that he was going home.
“Why’s that?”
“Nobody’s coming to tea. It’s too late!” He looked at his watch as if there was some pressing demand on his time elsewhere. “I can’t wait all day.”
“Don’t be silly; it’s just two minutes to four.”

events.title: Daisy's Arrival and Excruciating Reunion
detailed_summary: Gatsby sits down miserably just as a car is heard arriving.
Both Nick and Gatsby jump up nervously; Nick goes outside to greet the visitor.
Daisy arrives in a large open car, her face bright and smiling beneath a lavender hat.
Her voice captivates Nick as she confirms the location.
Nick helps her from the car; she playfully asks if Nick is in love with her or why she had to come alone.
Nick instructs her chauffeur, Ferdie, to return in an hour.
They enter the house, and Nick is shocked to find the living room empty.
As Daisy questions the emptiness, there is a knock at the front door.
Nick opens it to find Gatsby, deathly pale and standing in a puddle, staring intensely.
Gatsby walks stiffly past Nick into the hall and disappears into the living room without a word.
Nick closes the door against the rain, aware of his own racing heart.
After a moment of silence, Nick hears muffled sounds and Daisy's artificially bright voice greeting Gatsby.
An awkward pause follows; Nick enters the living room.
Gatsby is leaning against the mantelpiece, attempting to appear casual but clearly strained, staring at Daisy.
Daisy sits nervously on the edge of a chair.
Gatsby mutters that they have met before.
He almost knocks over the mantelpiece clock, catching it with trembling hands.
He sits down rigidly, apologizing for the clock.
Nick feels intensely awkward and comments inanely about the clock's age.
Daisy states matter-of-factly that they haven't met in years; Gatsby automatically corrects her: 'Five years next November'.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: He sat down miserably, as if I had pushed him, and simultaneously there was the sound of a motor turning into my lane.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The automatic quality of Gatsby’s answer set us all back at least another minute.

events.text_segment:
He sat down miserably, as if I had pushed him, and simultaneously there was the sound of a motor turning into my lane. We both jumped up, and, a little harrowed myself, I went out into the yard.
Under the dripping bare lilac-trees a large open car was coming up the drive. It stopped. Daisy’s face, tipped sideways beneath a three-cornered lavender hat, looked out at me with a bright ecstatic smile.
“Is this absolutely where you live, my dearest one?”
The exhilarating ripple of her voice was a wild tonic in the rain. I had to follow the sound of it for a moment, up and down, with my ear alone, before any words came through. A damp streak of hair lay like a dash of blue paint across her cheek, and her hand was wet with glistening drops as I took it to help her from the car.
“Are you in love with me,” she said low in my ear, “or why did I have to come alone?”
“That’s the secret of Castle Rackrent. Tell your chauffeur to go far away and spend an hour.”
“Come back in an hour, Ferdie.” Then in a grave murmur: “His name is Ferdie.”
“Does the gasoline affect his nose?”
“I don’t think so,” she said innocently. “Why?”
We went in. To my overwhelming surprise the living-room was deserted.
“Well, that’s funny,” I exclaimed.
“What’s funny?”
She turned her head as there was a light dignified knocking at the front door. I went out and opened it. Gatsby, pale as death, with his hands plunged like weights in his coat pockets, was standing in a puddle of water glaring tragically into my eyes.
With his hands still in his coat pockets he stalked by me into the hall, turned sharply as if he were on a wire, and disappeared into the living-room. It wasn’t a bit funny. Aware of the loud beating of my own heart I pulled the door to against the increasing rain.
For half a minute there wasn’t a sound. Then from the living-room I heard a sort of choking murmur and part of a laugh, followed by Daisy’s voice on a clear artificial note:
“I certainly am awfully glad to see you again.”
A pause; it endured horribly. I had nothing to do in the hall, so I went into the room.
Gatsby, his hands still in his pockets, was reclining against the mantelpiece in a strained counterfeit of perfect ease, even of boredom. His head leaned back so far that it rested against the face of a defunct mantelpiece clock, and from this position his distraught eyes stared down at Daisy, who was sitting, frightened but graceful, on the edge of a stiff chair.
“We’ve met before,” muttered Gatsby. His eyes glanced momentarily at me, and his lips parted with an abortive attempt at a laugh. Luckily the clock took this moment to tilt dangerously at the pressure of his head, whereupon he turned and caught it with trembling fingers, and set it back in place. Then he sat down, rigidly, his elbow on the arm of the sofa and his chin in his hand.
“I’m sorry about the clock,” he said.
My own face had now assumed a deep tropical burn. I couldn’t muster up a single commonplace out of the thousand in my head.
“It’s an old clock,” I told them idiotically.
I think we all believed for a moment that it had smashed in pieces on the floor.
“We haven’t met for many years,” said Daisy, her voice as matter-of-fact as it could ever be.
“Five years next November.”
The automatic quality of Gatsby’s answer set us all back at least another minute.

events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
He slumped into a seat in obvious distress, almost as if I had physically forced him down, and at that exact moment, we heard the noise of a car engine coming up my driveway. Both startled, we got up, and still feeling shaken, I stepped outside. In the rain beneath the bare lilac trees, a large open car pulled up and halted. Daisy leaned out, her head tilted under a lavender hat, and gave me a radiant, joyful smile. 

"Is this really where you live, darling?" she asked. Her lively, vibrant voice lifted my spirits in the gloomy weather. For an instant, I focused only on the sound before understanding her words. Her damp hair streaked across her cheek like blue paint, and her hand was wet as I helped her out of the car. 

Quietly in my ear, she asked, "Do you love me, or why did you make me come here alone?"

I replied, "That’s Castle Rackrent’s secret. Ask your driver to leave for an hour."

She instructed, "Come back in an hour, Ferdie," then added softly, "His name’s Ferdie."

"Does gasoline bother his nose?" I asked.

"I don’t think so," she answered innocently. "Why?"

We entered the house, and to my surprise, found the living room empty.

"Well, that’s odd," I said.

"What’s odd?" she replied, just as there was a quiet, dignified knock at the front door. I opened it to find Gatsby, ghostly pale with his hands deep in his coat pockets, standing miserably in a puddle and looking at me with an anguished expression. Still keeping his hands hidden, he marched past me inside, made a sharp turn as if moving on an invisible line, and vanished into the living room. The situation was anything but funny. My heart pounded loudly as I shut the door against the increasing rain.

For about thirty seconds, everything was silent. Then, I heard a shaky sound and part of a laugh from the living room, quickly followed by Daisy’s voice, bright but obviously forced: "I really am very happy to see you again."

A tense silence followed, drawing out the discomfort. With nothing to do in the hallway, I entered the room. Gatsby still had his hands in his pockets and was leaning against the mantel in a strained imitation of ease—almost as if bored. His head was thrown so far back that it nearly rested on the broken mantle clock, and his worried eyes were fixed on Daisy, who sat on the edge of a stiff chair, clearly nervous but still graceful.

“We’ve met before,” Gatsby muttered. He looked at me briefly and tried unsuccessfully to smile. Just then, the clock threatened to fall under the pressure of his head, and he quickly grabbed it with shaky hands and set it right. Then he sat down stiffly on the sofa, propping his chin on his hand.

"Sorry about the clock," he said.

My own face was now hot with embarrassment, and none of the usual small talk I knew came to mind.

"It’s just an old clock," I blurted out foolishly.

For a moment, we all seemed to believe the clock had crashed onto the floor.

"We haven’t seen each other in years," Daisy said in the most ordinary voice she could manage.

"Five years this coming November," Gatsby replied. His automatic response added to the awkwardness in the room, making the pause last even longer.

events.title: Nick Mediates Awkwardness and Witnesses Transformation
detailed_summary: Nick suggests they make tea, but the maid brings it in just then.
The activity of serving tea helps ease the tension slightly; Gatsby retreats into the shadows while Nick and Daisy talk.
Feeling superfluous, Nick decides to leave them alone.
Gatsby immediately panics and asks where Nick is going.
He follows Nick frantically into the kitchen, whispering that the entire meeting is a terrible mistake.
Nick tells him he's just embarrassed and reassures him that Daisy is embarrassed too.
Gatsby finds this hard to believe.
Nick becomes impatient, calling Gatsby childish and rude for leaving Daisy alone.
Gatsby looks reproachfully at Nick before cautiously returning to the living room.
Nick leaves through the back door and waits under a large tree in the continuing rain, observing Gatsby's house.
He reflects on the house's history and the American tendency towards servitude rather than peasantry.
After half an hour, the sun emerges.
Nick observes mundane activities at Gatsby's house and feels it's time to return, sensing a shift from murmuring voices to silence.
Making noise upon re-entry, Nick finds Gatsby and Daisy sitting at opposite ends of the couch, staring at each other, all trace of embarrassment gone.
Daisy's face is tear-streaked; she jumps up to fix her appearance.
Gatsby is utterly transformed, radiating a profound, quiet joy.
He greets Nick warmly, as if seeing him after a long time.
Gatsby beams when Nick points out the rain has stopped, repeating the news happily to Daisy.
Daisy responds with joy in her voice.
Gatsby invites both Nick and Daisy over to his house.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: I had them both on their feet with the desperate suggestion that they help me make tea in the kitchen when the demoniac Finn brought it in on a tray.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Absolutely, old sport.”

events.text_segment:
I had them both on their feet with the desperate suggestion that they help me make tea in the kitchen when the demoniac Finn brought it in on a tray.
Amid the welcome confusion of cups and cakes a certain physical decency established itself. Gatsby got himself into a shadow and, while Daisy and I talked, looked conscientiously from one to the other of us with tense, unhappy eyes. However, as calmness wasn’t an end in itself, I made an excuse at the first possible moment, and got to my feet.
“Where are you going?” demanded Gatsby in immediate alarm.
“I’ll be back.”
“I’ve got to speak to you about something before you go.”
He followed me wildly into the kitchen, closed the door, and whispered: “Oh, God!” in a miserable way.
“What’s the matter?”
“This is a terrible mistake,” he said, shaking his head from side to side, “a terrible, terrible mistake.”
“You’re just embarrassed, that’s all,” and luckily I added: “Daisy’s embarrassed too.”
“She’s embarrassed?” he repeated incredulously.
“Just as much as you are.”
“Don’t talk so loud.”
“You’re acting like a little boy,” I broke out impatiently. “Not only that, but you’re rude. Daisy’s sitting in there all alone.”
He raised his hand to stop my words, looked at me with unforgettable reproach, and, opening the door cautiously, went back into the other room.
I walked out the back way—just as Gatsby had when he had made his nervous circuit of the house half an hour before—and ran for a huge black knotted tree, whose massed leaves made a fabric against the rain. Once more it was pouring, and my irregular lawn, well-shaved by Gatsby’s gardener, abounded in small muddy swamps and prehistoric marshes. There was nothing to look at from under the tree except Gatsby’s enormous house, so I stared at it, like Kant at his church steeple, for half an hour. A brewer had built it early in the “period” craze, a decade before, and there was a story that he’d agreed to pay five years’ taxes on all the neighbouring cottages if the owners would have their roofs thatched with straw. Perhaps their refusal took the heart out of his plan to Found a Family—he went into an immediate decline. His children sold his house with the black wreath still on the door. Americans, while willing, even eager, to be serfs, have always been obstinate about being peasantry.
After half an hour, the sun shone again, and the grocer’s automobile rounded Gatsby’s drive with the raw material for his servants’ dinner—I felt sure he wouldn’t eat a spoonful. A maid began opening the upper windows of his house, appeared momentarily in each, and, leaning from the large central bay, spat meditatively into the garden. It was time I went back. While the rain continued it had seemed like the murmur of their voices, rising and swelling a little now and then with gusts of emotion. But in the new silence I felt that silence had fallen within the house too.
I went in—after making every possible noise in the kitchen, short of pushing over the stove—but I don’t believe they heard a sound. They were sitting at either end of the couch, looking at each other as if some question had been asked, or was in the air, and every vestige of embarrassment was gone. Daisy’s face was smeared with tears, and when I came in she jumped up and began wiping at it with her handkerchief before a mirror. But there was a change in Gatsby that was simply confounding. He literally glowed; without a word or a gesture of exultation a new well-being radiated from him and filled the little room.
“Oh, hello, old sport,” he said, as if he hadn’t seen me for years. I thought for a moment he was going to shake hands.
“It’s stopped raining.”
“Has it?” When he realized what I was talking about, that there were twinkle-bells of sunshine in the room, he smiled like a weather man, like an ecstatic patron of recurrent light, and repeated the news to Daisy. “What do you think of that? It’s stopped raining.”
“I’m glad, Jay.” Her throat, full of aching, grieving beauty, told only of her unexpected joy.
“I want you and Daisy to come over to my house,” he said, “I’d like to show her around.”
“You’re sure you want me to come?”
“Absolutely, old sport.”

Gatsby moved into a corner, and while Daisy and I chatted, he watched us intently and unhappily. However, since just being calm wasn't enough, I found the earliest chance to make an excuse and stand up. Gatsby, instantly alarmed, demanded, 'Where are you going?' I said I'd return. He insisted, 'I’ve got to speak to you about something before you go.' He followed me hastily into the kitchen, shut the door, and whispered a despairing 'Oh, God!' I asked what was wrong. Shaking his head, he declared, 'This is a terrible mistake,' repeating, 'a terrible, terrible mistake.' I told him he was merely feeling awkward, adding fortunately, 'Daisy’s embarrassed too.' They were seated at opposite ends of the sofa, gazing at each other as if a question had been posed or was pending, and all signs of embarrassment had vanished. Daisy’s face was wet with tears, and when I entered, she quickly stood up and began drying her face with her handkerchief in front of a mirror. But there was a change in Gatsby that was truly astonishing. He literally seemed to glow; without saying a word or making any triumphant gesture, a new sense of well-being radiated from him, filling the small room. 'Oh, hello, old sport,' he greeted me, as if he hadn't seen me in years. For a moment, I expected him to offer a handshake. I remarked, 'It’s stopped raining.' 'Has it?' he asked. When he grasped what I meant, that rays of sunshine were now visible in the room, he smiled broadly, like a weather forecaster, like someone overjoyed by the return of light, and relayed the news to Daisy. 'What do you think of that? It’s stopped raining.' 'I’m glad, Jay,' she replied. Her voice, full of sorrowful yet beautiful emotion, conveyed only her unexpected happiness. 'I want you and Daisy to come over to my house,' he said. 'I’d like to show her around.' I asked, 'Are you sure you want me to come?' 'Absolutely, old sport,' he confirmed.

But since calmness wasn’t the main goal, I found an excuse as soon as I could and stood up. Gatsby instantly sounded worried, asking where I was going. I told him I’d be back, but he insisted we speak before I left. He hurried after me into the kitchen, closed the door, and whispered miserably, "Oh, God!" I gazed at Gatsby’s huge house—there was little else to see—much like Kant would contemplate his church steeple, and stood there for half an hour. The house had been built a decade earlier by a brewer who, according to rumor, offered to pay five years of taxes for the neighboring homes if their owners would thatch their roofs, but they refused. A maid opened the house’s upstairs windows, pausing at each, and at one point spit thoughtfully into the garden below. I realized it was time to go back inside. While the rain fell, their voices had seemed to blend in with its sound, but now, in the quiet, I felt peace had settled over the house too. I returned—making as much noise as possible in the kitchen without causing real damage—but I doubt they noticed. They were sitting at opposite ends of the couch, looking at each other as if silently questioning one another, all their former awkwardness gone. Daisy’s face was streaked with tears, and she quickly wiped her face when I entered. But what amazed me was the transformation in Gatsby—he seemed to be practically glowing with happiness, changed beyond recognition, his contentment filling the room. "Has it?" he replied, then seeing the sunshine in the room, smiled joyfully and told Daisy. "Isn’t it something? It’s stopped raining." Daisy replied, her voice full of bittersweet emotion, "I’m glad, Jay." Gatsby then invited both of us to his house to show Daisy around. I asked if he was sure he wanted me to come, and he enthusiastically confirmed, "Absolutely, old sport."

events.title: Touring the Mansion: Wealth, History, and Emotion

events.text_segment:
Daisy went upstairs to wash her face—too late I thought with humiliation of my towels—while Gatsby and I waited on the lawn.
“My house looks well, doesn’t it?” he demanded. “See how the whole front of it catches the light.”
I agreed that it was splendid.
“Yes.” His eyes went over it, every arched door and square tower. “It took me just three years to earn the money that bought it.”
“I thought you inherited your money.”
“I did, old sport,” he said automatically, “but I lost most of it in the big panic—the panic of the war.”
I think he hardly knew what he was saying, for when I asked him what business he was in he answered: “That’s my affair,” before he realized that it wasn’t an appropriate reply.
“Oh, I’ve been in several things,” he corrected himself. “I was in the drug business and then I was in the oil business. But I’m not in either one now.” He looked at me with more attention. “Do you mean you’ve been thinking over what I proposed the other night?”
Before I could answer, Daisy came out of the house and two rows of brass buttons on her dress gleamed in the sunlight.
“That huge place there?” she cried pointing.
“Do you like it?”
“I love it, but I don’t see how you live there all alone.”
“I keep it always full of interesting people, night and day. People who do interesting things. Celebrated people.”
Instead of taking the shortcut along the Sound we went down to the road and entered by the big postern. With enchanting murmurs Daisy admired this aspect or that of the feudal silhouette against the sky, admired the gardens, the sparkling odour of jonquils and the frothy odour of hawthorn and plum blossoms and the pale gold odour of kiss-me-at-the-gate. It was strange to reach the marble steps and find no stir of bright dresses in and out the door, and hear no sound but bird voices in the trees.
And inside, as we wandered through Marie Antoinette music-rooms and Restoration Salons, I felt that there were guests concealed behind every couch and table, under orders to be breathlessly silent until we had passed through. As Gatsby closed the door of “the Merton College Library” I could have sworn I heard the owl-eyed man break into ghostly laughter.
We went upstairs, through period bedrooms swathed in rose and lavender silk and vivid with new flowers, through dressing-rooms and poolrooms, and bathrooms with sunken baths—intruding into one chamber where a dishevelled man in pyjamas was doing liver exercises on the floor. It was Mr. Klipspringer, the “boarder.” I had seen him wandering hungrily about the beach that morning. Finally we came to Gatsby’s own apartment, a bedroom and a bath, and an Adam’s study, where we sat down and drank a glass of some Chartreuse he took from a cupboard in the wall.
He hadn’t once ceased looking at Daisy, and I think he revalued everything in his house according to the measure of response it drew from her well-loved eyes. Sometimes too, he stared around at his possessions in a dazed way, as though in her actual and astounding presence none of it was any longer real. Once he nearly toppled down a flight of stairs.
His bedroom was the simplest room of all—except where the dresser was garnished with a toilet set of pure dull gold. Daisy took the brush with delight, and smoothed her hair, whereupon Gatsby sat down and shaded his eyes and began to laugh.
“It’s the funniest thing, old sport,” he said hilariously. “I can’t—When I try to—”
He had passed visibly through two states and was entering upon a third. After his embarrassment and his unreasoning joy he was consumed with wonder at her presence. He had been full of the idea so long, dreamed it right through to the end, waited with his teeth set, so to speak, at an inconceivable pitch of intensity. Now, in the reaction, he was running down like an over-wound clock.
Recovering himself in a minute he opened for us two hulking patent cabinets which held his massed suits and dressing-gowns and ties, and his shirts, piled like bricks in stacks a dozen high.
“I’ve got a man in England who buys me clothes. He sends over a selection of things at the beginning of each season, spring and fall.”
He took out a pile of shirts and began throwing them, one by one, before us, shirts of sheer linen and thick silk and fine flannel, which lost their folds as they fell and covered the table in many-coloured disarray. While we admired he brought more and the soft rich heap mounted higher—shirts with stripes and scrolls and plaids in coral and apple-green and lavender and faint orange, with monograms of indian blue. Suddenly, with a strained sound, Daisy bent her head into the shirts and began to cry stormily.
“They’re such beautiful shirts,” she sobbed, her voice muffled in the thick folds. “It makes me sad because I’ve never seen such—such beautiful shirts before.”

'I have a tailor in England who purchases clothing for me,' he explained. 'He sends me a selection of items at the start of each season, spring and autumn.' He pulled out a stack of shirts and began tossing them, one by one, towards us—shirts made of sheer linen, thick silk, and fine flannel. They lost their creases as they fell, covering the table in a colourful mess. As we admired them, he brought out more, and the soft, luxurious pile grew higher—shirts with stripes, intricate patterns, and plaids in shades of coral, apple-green, lavender, and pale orange, each featuring monograms in Indian blue. Suddenly, with a choked sound, Daisy buried her face in the pile of shirts and began to weep uncontrollably. 'They are such exquisite shirts,' she sobbed, her voice muffled by the thick layers. 'It makes me sad because I have never seen such—such beautiful shirts before.'

events.title: Reflections, Memories, Music, and Lingering Doubts
detailed_summary: Plans to see the grounds are halted as rain begins again; they look out at the Sound.
Gatsby points across the bay towards Daisy's house, mentioning the green light on her dock.
He remarks on its constant presence.
Daisy puts her arm through his, but Gatsby seems lost in thought, perhaps realizing the light's symbolic meaning has now fundamentally changed.
Nick reflects that the light, once representing the vast distance to Daisy, is now just a light, diminishing Gatsby's 'enchanted objects'.
Nick examines items in the room, noticing a large photo of Dan Cody, whom Gatsby identifies as a deceased former best friend.
There's also a small, defiant photo of a young Gatsby in yachting gear.
Daisy admires the old photo; Gatsby quickly redirects her attention to a collection of news clippings he saved about her.
Gatsby takes a brief, coded phone call related to his business dealings, mentioning a 'small town' and Detroit.
Daisy calls them to the window to admire a break in the clouds revealing pink and gold sky over the sea.
She whispers a desire to put Gatsby in one of the clouds.
Nick tries to leave, but they insist he stay, possibly needing his presence to feel comfortably alone.
Gatsby decides Klipspringer should play the piano.
He fetches the reluctant Klipspringer, now dressed casually.
Klipspringer protests his lack of practice but is urged to play.
Gatsby turns on lights throughout the house and sits with Daisy on a couch in the dimly lit music room while Klipspringer plays 'The Love Nest'.
Klipspringer again complains about his playing but is told sharply by Gatsby to continue.
As Klipspringer plays 'Ain't We Got Fun', Nick observes the weather and the general atmosphere of West Egg.
Nick notices a look of bewilderment return to Gatsby's face.
Nick speculates that even in this moment of reunion, Daisy might inevitably fall short of Gatsby's enormous, idealized vision of her.
He considers the impossibility of reality matching the 'colossal vitality of his illusion'.
Gatsby seems to recompose himself, taking Daisy's hand as she murmurs to him.
Nick concludes that Daisy's captivating voice is the one element that couldn't be 'over-dreamed'.
Feeling forgotten, Nick prepares to leave; Daisy offers her hand, but Gatsby seems completely unaware of Nick.
Nick observes them one last time, seeing them as remote and intensely absorbed in each other, before leaving them alone together in the rain.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: After the house, we were to see the grounds and the swimming pool, and the hydroplane, and the midsummer flowers—but outside Gatsby’s window it began to rain again, so we stood in a row looking at the corrugated surface of the Sound.

events.text_segment:
After the house, we were to see the grounds and the swimming pool, and the hydroplane, and the midsummer flowers—but outside Gatsby’s window it began to rain again, so we stood in a row looking at the corrugated surface of the Sound.
“If it wasn’t for the mist we could see your home across the bay,” said Gatsby. “You always have a green light that burns all night at the end of your dock.”
Daisy put her arm through his abruptly, but he seemed absorbed in what he had just said. Possibly it had occurred to him that the colossal significance of that light had now vanished forever. Compared to the great distance that had separated him from Daisy it had seemed very near to her, almost touching her. It had seemed as close as a star to the moon. Now it was again a green light on a dock. His count of enchanted objects had diminished by one.
I began to walk about the room, examining various indefinite objects in the half darkness. A large photograph of an elderly man in yachting costume attracted me, hung on the wall over his desk.
“Who’s this?”
“That? That’s Mr. Dan Cody, old sport.”
The name sounded faintly familiar.
“He’s dead now. He used to be my best friend years ago.”
There was a small picture of Gatsby, also in yachting costume, on the bureau—Gatsby with his head thrown back defiantly—taken apparently when he was about eighteen.
“I adore it,” exclaimed Daisy. “The pompadour! You never told me you had a pompadour—or a yacht.”
“Look at this,” said Gatsby quickly. “Here’s a lot of clippings—about you.”
They stood side by side examining it. I was going to ask to see the rubies when the phone rang, and Gatsby took up the receiver.
“Yes… Well, I can’t talk now… I can’t talk now, old sport… I said a small town… He must know what a small town is… Well, he’s no use to us if Detroit is his idea of a small town…”
He rang off.
“Come here quick!” cried Daisy at the window.
The rain was still falling, but the darkness had parted in the west, and there was a pink and golden billow of foamy clouds above the sea.
“Look at that,” she whispered, and then after a moment: “I’d like to just get one of those pink clouds and put you in it and push you around.”
I tried to go then, but they wouldn’t hear of it; perhaps my presence made them feel more satisfactorily alone.
“I know what we’ll do,” said Gatsby, “we’ll have Klipspringer play the piano.”
He went out of the room calling “Ewing!” and returned in a few minutes accompanied by an embarrassed, slightly worn young man, with shell-rimmed glasses and scanty blond hair. He was now decently clothed in a “sport shirt,” open at the neck, sneakers, and duck trousers of a nebulous hue.
“Did we interrupt your exercise?” inquired Daisy politely.
“I was asleep,” cried Mr. Klipspringer, in a spasm of embarrassment. “That is, I’d been asleep. Then I got up…”
“Klipspringer plays the piano,” said Gatsby, cutting him off. “Don’t you, Ewing, old sport?”
“I don’t play well. I don’t—hardly play at all. I’m all out of prac—”
“We’ll go downstairs,” interrupted Gatsby. He flipped a switch. The grey windows disappeared as the house glowed full of light.
In the music-room Gatsby turned on a solitary lamp beside the piano. He lit Daisy’s cigarette from a trembling match, and sat down with her on a couch far across the room, where there was no light save what the gleaming floor bounced in from the hall.
When Klipspringer had played “The Love Nest” he turned around on the bench and searched unhappily for Gatsby in the gloom.
“I’m all out of practice, you see. I told you I couldn’t play. I’m all out of prac—”
“Don’t talk so much, old sport,” commanded Gatsby. “Play!”
“In the morning,
In the evening,
Ain’t we got fun—”
Outside the wind was loud and there was a faint flow of thunder along the Sound. All the lights were going on in West Egg now; the electric trains, men-carrying, were plunging home through the rain from New York. It was the hour of a profound human change, and excitement was generating on the air.
“One thing’s sure and nothing’s surer
The rich get richer and the poor get—children.
In the meantime,
In between time—”
As I went over to say goodbye I saw that the expression of bewilderment had come back into Gatsby’s face, as though a faint doubt had occurred to him as to the quality of his present happiness. Almost five years! There must have been moments even that afternoon when Daisy tumbled short of his dreams—not through her own fault, but because of the colossal vitality of his illusion. It had gone beyond her, beyond everything. He had thrown himself into it with a creative passion, adding to it all the time, decking it out with every bright feather that drifted his way. No amount of fire or freshness can challenge what a man can store up in his ghostly heart.
As I watched him he adjusted himself a little, visibly. His hand took hold of hers, and as she said something low in his ear he turned toward her with a rush of emotion. I think that voice held him most, with its fluctuating, feverish warmth, because it couldn’t be over-dreamed—that voice was a deathless song.
They had forgotten me, but Daisy glanced up and held out her hand; Gatsby didn’t know me now at all. I looked once more at them and they looked back at me, remotely, possessed by intense life. Then I went out of the room and down the marble steps into the rain, leaving them there together.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1:
After seeing the house, we were supposed to tour the grounds, including the pool, seaplane, and summer flowers. However, it started raining heavily again outside Gatsby's window, so we stood in a line gazing at the choppy surface of the Sound.

"If the fog wasn't here, we could see your place across the water," Gatsby remarked. "There's always a green light burning all night at the very end of your dock."

Daisy suddenly linked her arm through his, but Gatsby seemed preoccupied with what he had just said. Perhaps he realized that the immense symbolic importance of that light had now vanished forever. Compared to the vast distance that had separated him from Daisy, it had once seemed incredibly close to her, almost within reach. It had felt as near as a star feels to the moon. But now, it was simply a green light on a dock again. The number of magical items he possessed had decreased by one.

I started to wander around the room, looking at various indistinct objects in the dim light. A large picture of an older man in a yachting outfit, hanging above his desk, caught my attention.

"Who is this?"

"That? That's Mr. Dan Cody, old sport."

The name sounded vaguely familiar.

"He passed away. He was my closest friend years ago."

On the dresser, there was a smaller photo of Gatsby, also dressed for yachting—Gatsby with his head tilted back confidently—apparently taken when he was around eighteen.

"I love it!" Daisy exclaimed. "The hairstyle! You never mentioned you had that kind of hair—or a yacht."

"Look at this," Gatsby quickly said. "Here are many newspaper clippings—all about you."

They stood together examining the clippings. I was about to ask to see the rubies when the telephone rang, and Gatsby picked it up.

"Yes... Listen, I can't talk right now... I really can't talk now, old sport... I said a small town... He surely knows what a small town is... Well, he's no good to us if he thinks Detroit is a small town..."

He hung up.

"Come here quickly!" Daisy called from the window.

The rain continued, but the sky in the west had cleared, revealing a pink and golden mass of frothy clouds above the sea.

"Look at that," she whispered, then after a moment added, "I wish I could just take one of those pink clouds, put you in it, and gently push you around."

I considered leaving then, but they wouldn't let me; maybe my presence made them feel more genuinely alone together.

"I know what we'll do," Gatsby announced, "we'll have Klipspringer play the piano."

He left the room calling for "Ewing!" and returned a few minutes later with a shy, slightly worn young man wearing wire-rimmed glasses and thin blond hair. He was now dressed more appropriately in a casual, open-necked 'sport shirt,' sneakers, and light-colored duck trousers.

"Did we interrupt your exercise?" Daisy asked politely.

"I was sleeping," Mr. Klipspringer blurted out, flustered. "That is, I had been sleeping. Then I woke up..."

"Klipspringer is a pianist," Gatsby interrupted him. "Isn't that right, Ewing, old sport?"

"I don't play well. I hardly play at all. I'm completely out of prac—"

"We'll go downstairs," Gatsby cut in again. He flipped a switch. The dull grey look of the windows vanished as the house filled with light.

In the music room, Gatsby switched on a single lamp next to the piano. He lit Daisy's cigarette with a trembling match and sat down with her on a sofa far across the room, where the only light came from the gleaming floor reflecting the light from the hall.

After Klipspringer finished playing "The Love Nest," he turned on the piano bench and awkwardly looked for Gatsby in the shadows.

"I haven't practiced in ages, you see. I told you I wasn't good. I'm completely out of prac—"

"Stop talking so much, old sport," Gatsby ordered. "Play!"

"In the morning,
In the evening,
Ain't we got fun—"

Outside, the wind howled, and a faint rumble of thunder echoed across the Sound. All the lights were now coming on in West Egg; the electric commuter trains, carrying people, were rushing home through the rain from New York. It was a time of significant human transition, and excitement seemed to fill the air.

"One thing's certain, absolutely certain,
The rich get richer, and the poor get—children.
In the meantime,
In between time—"

As I approached to say goodbye, I noticed the expression of confusion return to Gatsby's face, as if a slight doubt had crossed his mind regarding the quality of his current happiness. Almost five years! There must have been moments even that afternoon when Daisy didn't quite measure up to his dreams—not because of any fault of her own, but because of the immense power of his fantasy. It had grown beyond her, beyond everything. He had poured himself into it with creative intensity, constantly adding to it, decorating it with every brilliant detail that came his way. No amount of real-world passion or freshness can compare to what a person can build up in their idealized internal world.

As I observed him, he visibly composed himself a little. He took her hand, and as she whispered something softly in his ear, he turned towards her with a surge of feeling. I believe her voice held him most strongly, with its shifting, fervent warmth, because that voice couldn't be idealized or surpassed—it was like an eternal melody.

They had forgotten about me, but Daisy looked up and offered her hand; Gatsby didn't even seem to recognize me now. I looked at them one last time, and they looked back, distant, consumed by intense emotion. Then I left the room and went down the marble steps into the rain, leaving them there together.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
After touring the house, we planned to see the gardens, pool, Gatsby’s hydroplane, and the summer flowers, but rain began falling outside Gatsby’s window, so we stood together watching the rippled surface of the Sound. Gatsby commented, “If it weren’t for the mist, you could see your house across the bay. You always have a green light shining at the end of your dock.” Daisy slipped her arm through Gatsby’s, but he seemed preoccupied, perhaps realizing the green light, which had held such meaning for him, had now lost its significance. Before, it had seemed so close to Daisy, almost within reach, as if it were a star close to the moon. Now, it was simply a green light on a dock, and Gatsby’s collection of enchanted things had shrunk by one.

I wandered around the room, examining vague objects in the dimness. A large photograph of an older man in a yachting outfit above the desk caught my eye. I asked who it was. “That’s Mr. Dan Cody, old sport,” said Gatsby. The name sounded somewhat familiar. “He’s passed away now. He was my best friend many years ago.” On the bureau, I noticed a small photo of a young Gatsby in yachting clothes, head held back defiantly, likely taken when he was about eighteen. “I love it,” Daisy said. “The pompadour! You never told me you had one, or a yacht.” 

Gatsby quickly showed her a large bundle of newspaper clippings about her. They looked at them side by side. I was about to ask to see some rubies when the phone rang. Gatsby answered, sounding impatient: “Yes… Well, I can’t talk now… I said a small town… If he thinks Detroit is a small town he’s no use to us…” He hung up.

“Come here quick!” Daisy called from the window. Despite the rain, the sky in the west was clearing, with pink and golden clouds above the sea. “Look at that,” she whispered. After a moment, she added, “I’d like to grab one of those pink clouds, put you in it, and push you around.”

I tried to take my leave, but they insisted I stay—maybe my presence created a comfortable sense of privacy for them. “I know—we’ll have Klipspringer play piano,” suggested Gatsby. He left the room and returned with a self-conscious, slightly disheveled young man in glasses and casual clothes. “Did we interrupt your workout?” Daisy asked. “I was asleep,” replied Klipspringer, embarrassed. “I mean, I had been… Then I got up…”

“Klipspringer plays piano,” Gatsby interjected. “You play, right?”

“I don’t play very well… I’m out of practice—”

“We’ll go downstairs,” Gatsby insisted, turning on all the lights.

In the music room, Gatsby switched on a lamp by the piano, lit Daisy’s cigarette, and sat with her on a far couch where only soft light from the hall touched them. Klipspringer played “The Love Nest,” and then looked back at Gatsby, apologetic. “I told you I was out of practice…”

“Just play, old sport,” ordered Gatsby.

Klipspringer began to sing “Ain’t We Got Fun.” The wind howled outside, thunder rumbled over the Sound, and lights began to glow in West Egg as trains carried people home through the rain. Evening had ushered in a mood of transition and excitement.

As he sang, the lyrics went: “The rich get richer, and the poor get—children. In the meantime, In between time—”

As I moved to leave, I saw confusion return to Gatsby’s face—as if some doubt crept in about whether his happiness was real. Almost five years had passed—surely even that afternoon Daisy fell short of his dreams, not through any fault of hers, but because his vision had become too great. He had poured so much creativity and longing into it, embellishing it ever further, until no reality could match what he had conjured up in his heart.

As I watched, Gatsby visibly regathered himself, holding Daisy’s hand as she spoke quietly to him. He turned to her with a surge of feeling. I sensed that her voice fascinated him most, with its lively warmth that couldn’t be imagined or idealized—a voice like an immortal melody.

They had forgotten my presence until Daisy looked up and reached for my hand. Gatsby now seemed not to notice me at all. I gave them a final look; they looked back, absorbed in each other, radiating life. I left the room and went down the marble steps, out into the rain, leaving the two of them together.

events.title: A Reporter's Inquiry and Gatsby's Growing Notoriety
detailed_summary: An inquisitive young reporter from New York appears at Gatsby's residence.
The reporter vaguely asks Gatsby for a statement, having heard his name mentioned in his office.
The reporter's visit, though based on unclear information, reflects Gatsby's increasing notoriety.
Gatsby's fame, fueled by speculation from his party guests, has grown throughout the summer.
Various myths have become associated with Gatsby, including owning an underground pipeline or living in a mobile house-like boat.
The narrator questions the reasons behind James Gatz finding satisfaction in these fantastical rumors.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: About this time an ambitious young reporter from New York arrived one morning at Gatsby’s door and asked him if he had anything to say.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Just why these inventions were a source of satisfaction to James Gatz of North Dakota, isn’t easy to say.

events.text_segment:
About this time an ambitious young reporter from New York arrived one morning at Gatsby’s door and asked him if he had anything to say.
“Anything to say about what?” inquired Gatsby politely.
“Why—any statement to give out.”
It transpired after a confused five minutes that the man had heard Gatsby’s name around his office in a connection which he either wouldn’t reveal or didn’t fully understand. This was his day off and with laudable initiative he had hurried out “to see.”
It was a random shot, and yet the reporter’s instinct was right. Gatsby’s notoriety, spread about by the hundreds who had accepted his hospitality and so become authorities upon his past, had increased all summer until he fell just short of being news. Contemporary legends such as the “underground pipeline to Canada” attached themselves to him, and there was one persistent story that he didn’t live in a house at all, but in a boat that looked like a house and was moved secretly up and down the Long Island shore. Just why these inventions were a source of satisfaction to James Gatz of North Dakota, isn’t easy to say.
