Gatsby responded politely by asking, "What specifically would I have to say something about?" The reporter explained he was inquiring about "any official statement you might want to release." After a confusing few minutes, it became clear the reporter had encountered Gatsby's name mentioned at his office in a context he either chose not to disclose or didn't entirely understand. It was his day off, and demonstrating commendable proactivity, he had hurried out simply "to see what was happening." Although it was a speculative visit, the reporter's instinct was accurate. Gatsby's public recognition, amplified by the hundreds of people who had accepted his generosity and therefore felt like authorities on his past, had increased throughout the summer until he was nearly newsworthy. Contemporary myths, such as the notion of a "covert passage to Canada," became linked to him, and there was one persistent story that he didn't actually reside in a house, but in a vessel designed to resemble one, which was secretly moved along the Long Island coast. It is hard to pinpoint exactly why these invented stories were a source of pleasure for James Gatz, originally from North Dakota.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14: Around this period, a driven young journalist from New York showed up at Gatsby’s door one morning, inquiring if he had any comments or statements to make. Gatsby, ever gracious, asked what he was expected to comment on. It turned out, after a few puzzled minutes, that the reporter had heard Gatsby’s name mentioned at his workplace, tied to something he either couldn’t explain or was unwilling to share. Despite being on his day off, the reporter had enthusiastically rushed over "just to check it out." Although his visit was a bit haphazard, his instincts were correct. Over the summer, Gatsby’s fame—fueled by the many people who attended his parties and then acted as self-proclaimed experts on his background—had grown to the point that he was almost newsworthy. Wild stories circulated about him, such as the rumor that he had a secret smuggling route to Canada, and another persistent tale claimed that he didn’t actually reside in a house, but rather on a boat designed to look like a house, which was moved surreptitiously up and down the Long Island coast. Why these fanciful rumors were gratifying to James Gatz, originally from North Dakota, is difficult to explain.

events.title: The Creation of Jay Gatsby: Name Change and Self-Invention
detailed_summary: The narrator reveals Gatsby's legal name was James Gatz.
He changed his name to Jay Gatsby at age seventeen, coinciding with the start of his envisioned career.
This transformation occurred when he saw Dan Cody's yacht anchor near him on Lake Superior.
The narrative distinguishes the former self, James Gatz (lounging on the beach), from the emergent Jay Gatsby (rowing out to warn Cody about the wind).
The narrator speculates that the name 'Jay Gatsby' was conceived long before this specific moment.
Gatsby's parents are described as unsuccessful farm people whom he mentally disowned.
The persona of Jay Gatsby is presented as stemming from Gatsby's idealized, 'Platonic' self-image.
He viewed himself metaphorically as a 'son of God', dedicated to serving a grand, albeit gaudy and superficial, form of beauty.
Gatsby remained committed to this invented, idealized seventeen-year-old's version of himself throughout his life.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: James Gatz—that was really, or at least legally, his name.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: So he invented just the sort of Jay Gatsby that a seventeen-year-old boy would be likely to invent, and to this conception he was faithful to the end.

events.text_segment:
James Gatz—that was really, or at least legally, his name. He had changed it at the age of seventeen and at the specific moment that witnessed the beginning of his career—when he saw Dan Cody’s yacht drop anchor over the most insidious flat on Lake Superior. It was James Gatz who had been loafing along the beach that afternoon in a torn green jersey and a pair of canvas pants, but it was already Jay Gatsby who borrowed a rowboat, pulled out to the Tuolomee, and informed Cody that a wind might catch him and break him up in half an hour.
I suppose he’d had the name ready for a long time, even then. His parents were shiftless and unsuccessful farm people—his imagination had never really accepted them as his parents at all. The truth was that Jay Gatsby of West Egg, Long Island, sprang from his Platonic conception of himself. He was a son of God—a phrase which, if it means anything, means just that—and he must be about His Father’s business, the service of a vast, vulgar, and meretricious beauty. So he invented just the sort of Jay Gatsby that a seventeen-year-old boy would be likely to invent, and to this conception he was faithful to the end.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: Gatsby's birth name was actually James Gatz, at least officially. He legally changed it when he was seventeen, precisely when he started his new life journey. This moment occurred when he witnessed Dan Cody's yacht cast anchor in a particularly treacherous, shallow area of Lake Superior. James Gatz, dressed in simple clothes, was the one who saw the yacht from the shore that afternoon. However, it was already the newly conceived Jay Gatsby who rowed out to the *Tuolomee* and warned Cody that the wind could quickly wreck his boat. It's probable he had devised the name 'Jay Gatsby' well in advance, even back then. His parents were shiftless and struggling farmers, and his imagination had never really accepted them as his true family. The truth is that Jay Gatsby of West Egg, Long Island, was born from his own idealized vision of himself. He saw himself as a 'son of God' – a phrase which essentially means he felt he had a divine purpose – which was to pursue what he considered his 'Father's business,' the pursuit of a grand, ostentatious, and ultimately superficial form of beauty. Thus, at seventeen, he created the specific persona of Jay Gatsby, the kind a young man his age might invent, and he remained committed to this self-created image until his death.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14: James Gatz was his real—or at least his legal—name. He changed it when he was seventeen, precisely at the moment when his life started to take a new direction: the moment he saw Dan Cody’s yacht drop anchor on the treacherous shallows of Lake Superior. That afternoon, James Gatz had been idly wandering along the shore wearing a ripped green sweater and canvas trousers, but it was already as Jay Gatsby that he borrowed a rowboat, went out to the Tuolomee, and warned Cody that a sudden wind could wreck his boat within half an hour. It seems likely that he had been planning to adopt his new name for a long time. His parents were dishonest and unsuccessful farmers—he had never truly believed they were his parents. In reality, Jay Gatsby from West Egg, Long Island, was the product of his own idealized vision of himself. He saw himself as a son of God—which, if it means anything, means just that—and he felt destined to fulfill a mission of pursuing immense, showy, and superficial beauty. So he created the kind of Jay Gatsby that a seventeen-year-old boy might imagine, and he stayed true to that ideal for the rest of his life.

events.title: Gatsby's Early Struggles, Fantasies, and the Arrival of Dan Cody
detailed_summary: Before meeting Cody, Gatz spent over a year doing manual labor like clam-digging and salmon-fishing along Lake Superior.
His body grew strong through this rugged work.
He had early experiences with women but developed contempt for them due to being spoiled and their perceived ignorance or hysteria.
His inner life was tumultuous, filled with extravagant and fantastical nighttime daydreams.
His imagination constructed a universe of 'ineffable gaudiness' while mundane reality continued around him.
These dreams provided imaginative escape and reinforced a sense of life's potential unreality.
Driven by an 'instinct toward his future glory', he briefly attended St. Olaf's College in Minnesota.
He left after two weeks, disillusioned by the college's indifference to his ambitions and his need to work as a janitor.
He returned to Lake Superior, still searching, when Dan Cody's yacht arrived.
Dan Cody is introduced: fifty years old, wealthy from mining, physically strong but becoming mentally frail.
Cody was pursued by women seeking his fortune, notably Ella Kaye, a newspaper woman whose influence led him to sea.
Cody had been sailing for five years before encountering Gatz.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: For over a year he had been beating his way along the south shore of Lake Superior as a clam-digger and a salmon-fisher or in any other capacity that brought him food and bed.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He had been coasting along all too hospitable shores for five years when he turned up as James Gatz’s destiny in Little Girl Bay.

events.text_segment:
For over a year he had been beating his way along the south shore of Lake Superior as a clam-digger and a salmon-fisher or in any other capacity that brought him food and bed. His brown, hardening body lived naturally through the half-fierce, half-lazy work of the bracing days. He knew women early, and since they spoiled him he became contemptuous of them, of young virgins because they were ignorant, of the others because they were hysterical about things which in his overwhelming self-absorption he took for granted.
But his heart was in a constant, turbulent riot. The most grotesque and fantastic conceits haunted him in his bed at night. A universe of ineffable gaudiness spun itself out in his brain while the clock ticked on the washstand and the moon soaked with wet light his tangled clothes upon the floor. Each night he added to the pattern of his fancies until drowsiness closed down upon some vivid scene with an oblivious embrace. For a while these reveries provided an outlet for his imagination; they were a satisfactory hint of the unreality of reality, a promise that the rock of the world was founded securely on a fairy’s wing.
An instinct toward his future glory had led him, some months before, to the small Lutheran College of St. Olaf’s in southern Minnesota. He stayed there two weeks, dismayed at its ferocious indifference to the drums of his destiny, to destiny itself, and despising the janitor’s work with which he was to pay his way through. Then he drifted back to Lake Superior, and he was still searching for something to do on the day that Dan Cody’s yacht dropped anchor in the shallows alongshore.
Cody was fifty years old then, a product of the Nevada silver fields, of the Yukon, of every rush for metal since seventy-five. The transactions in Montana copper that made him many times a millionaire found him physically robust but on the verge of soft-mindedness, and, suspecting this, an infinite number of women tried to separate him from his money. The none too savoury ramifications by which Ella Kaye, the newspaper woman, played Madame de Maintenon to his weakness and sent him to sea in a yacht, were common property of the turgid journalism in 1902. He had been coasting along all too hospitable shores for five years when he turned up as James Gatz’s destiny in Little Girl Bay.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: For more than a year, he had been making his living along the southern edge of Lake Superior, working as a clam-digger, salmon-fisher, or in any job that provided him with sustenance and a place to sleep. The demanding yet sometimes relaxed nature of these invigorating days naturally shaped his tanned, strong body. He had early encounters with women; their indulgence of him led him to feel superior to them, viewing young virgins with disdain for their lack of experience and others as overly emotional about matters he considered trivial given his intense focus on himself. However, his inner state was one of constant, chaotic unrest. At night, while in bed, he was preoccupied by the most bizarre and extraordinary visions. In his mind, a world of indescribable splendor unfolded, while the clock ticked on the dresser and the moonlight bathed his scattered clothes on the floor in a pale glow. Every night, he elaborated on the details of his daydreams until sleep arrived, drawing him into an oblivious embrace that ended the vivid scene. For a period, these imaginings offered an outlet for his creative energy; they served as a compelling suggestion that reality might be less solid than it appeared, a promise that the fundamental basis of the world was as fragile as a fairy's wing. Guided by an intuition about his future success, he had, several months prior, gone to the small Lutheran institution, St. Olaf's College, located in southern Minnesota. He remained there for only two weeks, discouraged by its seeming lack of interest in his aspirations and fate, and finding the janitorial duties he was required to perform to fund his education contemptible. He then returned to Lake Superior, and he was still seeking employment when Dan Cody's yacht cast anchor in the shallow waters near the shore. Cody was fifty years old at that time, having made his fortune from the Nevada silver mines, the Yukon gold rush, and every mining boom since 1875. The copper transactions in Montana that made him enormously wealthy left him in good physical health but appearing somewhat mentally vulnerable, and aware of this, countless women attempted to take advantage of him financially. The rather scandalous circumstances through which Ella Kaye, a journalist, influenced him in his weakened state and prompted him to live on a yacht at sea, were widely reported in the sensationalist newspapers of 1902. He had spent five years sailing along welcoming coastlines before he appeared in Little Girl Bay, becoming the catalyst for James Gatz's fate.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
For over a year, he survived along the southern edge of Lake Superior by doing various jobs, such as digging for clams and fishing for salmon, or anything else that provided him food and shelter. His skin became tanned and tougher as he naturally adapted to the mix of strenuous and relaxed labor each day. He gained early experience with women, and their indulgence made him look down on them—he saw young girls as naïve, and the others as overly emotional about things he found commonplace, absorbed as he was in himself.

However, inside, he was always restless and in turmoil; bizarre and fantastic dreams plagued his nights. He would lie awake as his mind spun visions of dazzling possibilities, while the clock ticked and moonlight shone on his scattered clothes. Every night, he expanded these dreams until sleep overtook him. For a time, these fantasies satisfied his need for escape, offering him the sense that reality itself was unstable, and hinting that the world's solid foundations rested on something magical and fleeting.

A sense of his destined greatness had led him a few months earlier to enroll at a small Lutheran college in southern Minnesota, St. Olaf’s. He only lasted two weeks before becoming discouraged with the school’s complete disregard for his ambitions—and resentful because he had to work as a janitor to pay his expenses. After leaving, he returned to Lake Superior, still looking for his purpose, and it was on this quest that he encountered Dan Cody’s yacht anchored offshore.

At that time, Cody was fifty years old and had made his fortune in silver mining in Nevada, in the Yukon, and throughout every mineral rush since 1875. His wealth from Montana copper deals had made him a millionaire many times over. Though still physically strong, he was beginning to lose his mental sharpness, and because of that, countless women tried to get his money. The notorious events by which Ella Kaye, a journalist, manipulated Cody and took advantage of his weaknesses, eventually sending him out to sea on his yacht, were widely reported in sensational newspapers around 1902. After five years of traveling along many welcoming shores, Cody finally became intertwined with James Gatz’s fate in Little Girl Bay.

events.title: Gatsby Joins Dan Cody: A Five-Year Voyage and Education
detailed_summary: Young Gatz perceived Cody's yacht as the embodiment of worldly beauty and glamour.
The narrator presumes Gatz used his smile effectively when interacting with Cody.
Cody asked Gatz questions, discovering his new name and immense ambition.
Cody hired Gatz shortly after, buying him nautical attire in Duluth.
Gatsby joined Cody aboard the yacht, the Tuolomee, traveling to the West Indies and the Barbary Coast.
Gatsby served Cody in various roles over five years: steward, mate, skipper, secretary, and caretaker during Cody's drunken episodes.
Cody increasingly trusted Gatsby to manage his affairs, especially concerning his drinking.
Their arrangement, involving voyages around the continent, lasted five years.
The association ended abruptly after Ella Kaye boarded the yacht in Boston; Cody died a week later.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: To young Gatz, resting on his oars and looking up at the railed deck, that yacht represented all the beauty and glamour in the world.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: It might have lasted indefinitely except for the fact that Ella Kaye came on board one night in Boston and a week later Dan Cody inhospitably died.

events.text_segment:
To young Gatz, resting on his oars and looking up at the railed deck, that yacht represented all the beauty and glamour in the world. I suppose he smiled at Cody—he had probably discovered that people liked him when he smiled. At any rate Cody asked him a few questions (one of them elicited the brand new name) and found that he was quick and extravagantly ambitious. A few days later he took him to Duluth and bought him a blue coat, six pairs of white duck trousers, and a yachting cap. And when the Tuolomee left for the West Indies and the Barbary Coast, Gatsby left too.
He was employed in a vague personal capacity—while he remained with Cody he was in turn steward, mate, skipper, secretary, and even jailor, for Dan Cody sober knew what lavish doings Dan Cody drunk might soon be about, and he provided for such contingencies by reposing more and more trust in Gatsby. The arrangement lasted five years, during which the boat went three times around the Continent. It might have lasted indefinitely except for the fact that Ella Kaye came on board one night in Boston and a week later Dan Cody inhospitably died.

When the Tuolomee set sail for regions like the West Indies and the Barbary Coast, Gatsby was on board. His role was vaguely defined but personal; during his time with Cody, he served consecutively as steward, mate, skipper, secretary, and even acted as a sort of keeper. This was because a sober Dan Cody understood the potential excesses of a drunken Dan Cody and increasingly entrusted Gatsby to handle such possibilities. The association lasted for five years, during which the vessel circumnavigated the continent three times. It could have continued indefinitely, were it not for Ella Kaye boarding the ship one night in Boston, followed by Dan Cody's abrupt death just a week later.

events.title: Dan Cody's Influence, Lost Inheritance, and Narrative Context
detailed_summary: The narrator recalls seeing a portrait of Dan Cody in Gatsby's bedroom, describing him as a 'pioneer debauchee'.
Cody represented the untamed, rough nature of the frontier brought to the East Coast.
Witnessing Cody's heavy drinking is cited as the indirect reason for Gatsby's own temperance.
Gatsby inherited $25,000 from Cody, but never received the money.
Legal maneuvering, likely by Ella Kaye, ensured the fortune went to her instead.
Despite losing the money, Gatsby gained what the narrator considers a uniquely fitting education from his time with Cody.
This experience transformed the 'vague contour' of Jay Gatsby into a fully formed man.
Nick explains he's recounting this history (told to him later by Gatsby) to correct the wild rumors about Gatsby's past.
He inserts this information during a pause in the main narrative to clarify Gatsby's background during a period of Nick's own confusion.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: I remember the portrait of him up in Gatsby’s bedroom, a grey, florid man with a hard, empty face—the pioneer debauchee, who during one phase of American life brought back to the Eastern seaboard the savage violence of the frontier brothel and saloon.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: So I take advantage of this short halt, while Gatsby, so to speak, caught his breath, to clear this set of misconceptions away.

events.text_segment:
I remember the portrait of him up in Gatsby’s bedroom, a grey, florid man with a hard, empty face—the pioneer debauchee, who during one phase of American life brought back to the Eastern seaboard the savage violence of the frontier brothel and saloon. It was indirectly due to Cody that Gatsby drank so little. Sometimes in the course of gay parties women used to rub champagne into his hair; for himself he formed the habit of letting liquor alone.
And it was from Cody that he inherited money—a legacy of twenty-five thousand dollars. He didn’t get it. He never understood the legal device that was used against him, but what remained of the millions went intact to Ella Kaye. He was left with his singularly appropriate education; the vague contour of Jay Gatsby had filled out to the substantiality of a man.
He told me all this very much later, but I’ve put it down here with the idea of exploding those first wild rumours about his antecedents, which weren’t even faintly true. Moreover he told it to me at a time of confusion, when I had reached the point of believing everything and nothing about him. So I take advantage of this short halt, while Gatsby, so to speak, caught his breath, to clear this set of misconceptions away.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: I recall the picture of him hanging in Gatsby's room; he was a ruddy-faced man, somewhat grey, with a stern, expressionless look. This was the early profligate who, in a certain period of US history, reintroduced the brutal roughness of Western bordellos and bars to the East Coast. Cody's influence was indirectly responsible for Gatsby's minimal alcohol intake. At lively gatherings, women sometimes playfully rubbed champagne into his hair, but he himself chose to abstain from alcoholic drinks. Furthermore, he received an inheritance from Cody: a sum of twenty-five thousand dollars. However, he never actually received this money. He couldn't grasp the legal maneuver employed to prevent him from inheriting it, resulting in the substantial fortune passing entirely to Ella Kaye. What he did gain was his remarkably suitable education, through which the indistinct figure of Jay Gatsby developed into a fully formed individual. Gatsby shared all these details with me much later, but I am including them now to correct the initial, baseless speculations about his background. He also confided in me during a period when I was feeling uncertain, simultaneously inclined to believe everything and nothing I heard about him. Therefore, I am using this brief pause, as if Gatsby is taking a moment to compose himself, to dispel these false ideas.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14: I recall seeing the portrait of Cody in Gatsby's bedroom—a gray, florid man with a tough, emotionless expression, a true pioneer of extravagance who, at a certain point in American history, reintroduced the raw brutality of frontier saloons and brothels to the East Coast. Cody’s influence was one reason Gatsby rarely drank; at parties, some women would splash champagne on his hair, but Gatsby himself chose to avoid alcohol. Cody also left Gatsby a legacy of $25,000, but Gatsby never received it. He never understood exactly how he was cheated out of the money, which ended up going to Ella Kaye, while Gatsby was left only with the practical lessons he’d learned. This contributed to Jay Gatsby’s transformation into a man of substance. He confided this story to me much later, but I’m sharing it here to dispel the wild rumors about his past, which were completely unfounded. He told me this at a time when I didn’t know what to believe about him, so I’m taking this opportunity to clarify the truth and set the record straight.

events.title: Tom Buchanan's Unpleasant Visit and Rude Departure
detailed_summary: The narrator notes a pause in his involvement with Gatsby's life, during which he spent time in New York with Jordan Baker.
He visits Gatsby's house one Sunday afternoon.
Tom Buchanan arrives unexpectedly on horseback, accompanied by a man named Sloane and a woman.
Gatsby greets them effusively but appears unsettled by Tom's presence, rushing to offer drinks.
Mr. Sloane rudely declines all refreshments.
An awkward conversation follows about the ride and local roads.
Gatsby initiates a tense exchange by reminding Tom they had met previously.
Tom responds with gruff politeness but clearly doesn't recall the earlier meeting well.
Gatsby pointedly mentions knowing Tom's wife.
Sloane remains aloof, while the woman becomes friendly after drinking and suggests they all attend Gatsby's next party.
Gatsby invites them to stay for supper, but the woman counters with an invitation for Gatsby and Nick to join *her* supper party.
Sloane subtly tries to dissuade the woman and makes it clear Gatsby is not included in his address to her.
Gatsby, eager to go and see more of Tom, misses the social cue and agrees, offering to follow in his car as he lacks a horse.
While Gatsby goes inside to prepare, the others wait on the porch.
Sloane and the woman have a heated, private discussion.
Tom expresses incredulity and disdain that Gatsby thinks he's actually invited, questioning where he met Daisy and criticizing modern women.
Sloane and the woman abruptly mount their horses and prepare to leave.
Sloane curtly tells Tom they are late and asks Nick to inform Gatsby they couldn't wait.
After cool farewells, the trio rides away quickly.
Gatsby emerges from the house, ready to leave, just as they vanish down the drive.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: It was a halt, too, in my association with his affairs.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Tom and I shook hands, the rest of us exchanged a cool nod, and they trotted quickly down the drive, disappearing under the August foliage just as Gatsby, with hat and light overcoat in hand, came out the front door.

events.text_segment:
It was a halt, too, in my association with his affairs. For several weeks I didn’t see him or hear his voice on the phone—mostly I was in New York, trotting around with Jordan and trying to ingratiate myself with her senile aunt—but finally I went over to his house one Sunday afternoon. I hadn’t been there two minutes when somebody brought Tom Buchanan in for a drink. I was startled, naturally, but the really surprising thing was that it hadn’t happened before.
They were a party of three on horseback—Tom and a man named Sloane and a pretty woman in a brown riding-habit, who had been there previously.
“I’m delighted to see you,” said Gatsby, standing on his porch. “I’m delighted that you dropped in.”
As though they cared!
“Sit right down. Have a cigarette or a cigar.” He walked around the room quickly, ringing bells. “I’ll have something to drink for you in just a minute.”
He was profoundly affected by the fact that Tom was there. But he would be uneasy anyhow until he had given them something, realizing in a vague way that that was all they came for. Mr. Sloane wanted nothing. A lemonade? No, thanks. A little champagne? Nothing at all, thanks… I’m sorry—
“Did you have a nice ride?”
“Very good roads around here.”
“I suppose the automobiles—”
“Yeah.”
Moved by an irresistible impulse, Gatsby turned to Tom, who had accepted the introduction as a stranger.
“I believe we’ve met somewhere before, Mr. Buchanan.”
“Oh, yes,” said Tom, gruffly polite, but obviously not remembering. “So we did. I remember very well.”
“About two weeks ago.”
“That’s right. You were with Nick here.”
“I know your wife,” continued Gatsby, almost aggressively.
“That so?”
Tom turned to me.
“You live near here, Nick?”
“Next door.”
“That so?”
Mr. Sloane didn’t enter into the conversation, but lounged back haughtily in his chair; the woman said nothing either—until unexpectedly, after two highballs, she became cordial.
“We’ll all come over to your next party, Mr. Gatsby,” she suggested. “What do you say?”
“Certainly; I’d be delighted to have you.”
“Be ver’ nice,” said Mr. Sloane, without gratitude. “Well—think ought to be starting home.”
“Please don’t hurry,” Gatsby urged them. He had control of himself now, and he wanted to see more of Tom. “Why don’t you—why don’t you stay for supper? I wouldn’t be surprised if some other people dropped in from New York.”
“You come to supper with me,” said the lady enthusiastically. “Both of you.”
This included me. Mr. Sloane got to his feet.
“Come along,” he said—but to her only.
“I mean it,” she insisted. “I’d love to have you. Lots of room.”
Gatsby looked at me questioningly. He wanted to go and he didn’t see that Mr. Sloane had determined he shouldn’t.
“I’m afraid I won’t be able to,” I said.
“Well, you come,” she urged, concentrating on Gatsby.
Mr. Sloane murmured something close to her ear.
“We won’t be late if we start now,” she insisted aloud.
“I haven’t got a horse,” said Gatsby. “I used to ride in the army, but I’ve never bought a horse. I’ll have to follow you in my car. Excuse me for just a minute.”
The rest of us walked out on the porch, where Sloane and the lady began an impassioned conversation aside.
“My God, I believe the man’s coming,” said Tom. “Doesn’t he know she doesn’t want him?”
“She says she does want him.”
“She has a big dinner party and he won’t know a soul there.” He frowned. “I wonder where in the devil he met Daisy. By God, I may be old-fashioned in my ideas, but women run around too much these days to suit me. They meet all kinds of crazy fish.”
Suddenly Mr. Sloane and the lady walked down the steps and mounted their horses.
“Come on,” said Mr. Sloane to Tom, “we’re late. We’ve got to go.” And then to me: “Tell him we couldn’t wait, will you?”
Tom and I shook hands, the rest of us exchanged a cool nod, and they trotted quickly down the drive, disappearing under the August foliage just as Gatsby, with hat and light overcoat in hand, came out the front door.

My involvement with Gatsby's affairs came to a pause at this point as well. For several weeks, I had no contact with him, not seeing him or speaking on the phone. I spent most of that time in New York, accompanying Jordan and trying to get on the good side of her elderly aunt. However, one Sunday afternoon, I finally visited his house. I had only been there for a couple of minutes when someone arrived with Tom Buchanan for a drink. While I was startled, the truly surprising part was that this encounter hadn't occurred sooner.

Tom was part of a group of three who had arrived on horseback. The others were a man named Sloane and a pretty woman in a brown riding outfit, someone who had visited Gatsby before.

Standing on his porch, Gatsby greeted them warmly, saying, "I'm delighted to see you," and "I'm delighted that you dropped in."

It seemed unlikely that they genuinely cared!

Gatsby urged them, "Sit right down. Have a cigarette or a cigar." He hurried around the room, pressing service bells. "I'll have something for you to drink momentarily."

Tom's presence clearly deeply affected him. Still, Gatsby would have been restless regardless until he had offered them something, dimly aware that this was the only reason they had come. Mr. Sloane didn't want anything. A lemonade? No, thank you. A little champagne? Absolutely nothing, thank you... I apologize—

“Did you enjoy your ride?” Gatsby asked.

“The roads are quite good around here,” Sloane replied.

“I suppose the automobiles—” Gatsby began.

“Yes,” Sloane cut in.

Pushed by an overwhelming impulse, Gatsby turned to Tom, who had accepted the introduction as if he were a stranger.

“Oh, yes,” Tom responded, his tone roughly polite, though he clearly didn't recall. “Indeed we have. I remember very well.”

“It was about two weeks ago,” Gatsby prompted.

“That’s right. You were with Nick here,” Tom said.

“I know your wife,” Gatsby continued, speaking almost aggressively.

“Is that so?” Tom replied.

Tom then turned to me.

“Do you live nearby, Nick?” he asked.

“Next door,” I answered.

“Is that so?” Tom repeated.

Mr. Sloane didn't participate in the conversation, leaning back haughtily in his chair. The woman remained silent as well until, unexpectedly, after two highballs, she became friendly.

“We’ll all come over to your next party, Mr. Gatsby,” she proposed. “What do you think?”

“Certainly; I’d be happy to have you,” Gatsby responded.

“It would be quite pleasant,” Mr. Sloane remarked, his voice devoid of warmth. “Well—I think we should be heading home.”

“Please don’t leave so soon,” Gatsby urged them. He was composed now and eager to spend more time with Tom. “Why don’t you—why don’t you stay for supper? I wouldn’t be surprised if some other people from New York show up.”

“You come to supper with me,” the lady suggested enthusiastically. “Both of you.”

This invitation included me. Mr. Sloane immediately stood up.

“Come along,” he said, but directed the remark only to her.

“I mean it,” she insisted. “I’d truly love for you to come. There’s plenty of space.”

Gatsby looked at me uncertainly. He wanted to accept but didn't seem to grasp that Mr. Sloane had decided against it.

“I’m afraid I won’t be able to,” I said.

“Well, you come,” she urged, focusing her attention on Gatsby.

Mr. Sloane murmured something quietly in her ear.

“We won’t be late if we start now,” she stated aloud.

“I don’t have a horse,” Gatsby said. “I used to ride in the army, but I’ve never bought one. I’ll have to follow you in my car. Please excuse me for just a moment.”

The rest of us went out onto the porch, where Sloane and the lady began an intense private conversation.

“My God, I think the man’s coming,” Tom said. “Doesn’t he realize she doesn’t want him?”

“She says she does want him,” I replied.

“She’s having a large dinner party and he won’t know a single person there.” Tom frowned. “I wonder where on earth he met Daisy. Honestly, I may hold old-fashioned views, but women nowadays are out and about too much for my liking. They encounter all sorts of odd characters.”

Suddenly, Mr. Sloane and the lady walked down the steps and mounted their horses.

“Come on,” Mr. Sloane said to Tom, “we’re behind schedule. We need to go.” Then, addressing me: “Could you tell him we couldn’t wait?”

Tom and I shook hands, the rest of us exchanged cool nods, and they quickly rode down the drive, vanishing beneath the August leaves just as Gatsby, with his hat and light overcoat in hand, emerged from the front door.

events.title: Daisy Attends a Gatsby Party: Atmosphere and Interactions
detailed_summary: Apparently concerned about Daisy, Tom accompanies her to Gatsby's party the following Saturday.
Nick senses a distinct, oppressive harshness in the party's atmosphere compared to previous ones.
He speculates this feeling might stem from Tom's presence or from seeing the familiar West Egg scene through Daisy's presumably critical eyes.
He reflects on the inherent sadness of re-evaluating familiar things through a new perspective.
Daisy arrives expressing excitement, whispering flirtatiously to Nick.
Gatsby attempts to impress the Buchanans by pointing out famous guests.
Tom dismissively states he doesn't know anyone there.
Gatsby identifies a movie star and her director for them.
During introductions, Gatsby repeatedly refers to Tom as 'the polo player', despite Tom's objection.
Daisy claims to enjoy meeting celebrities, mentioning one with a 'blue nose'.
Tom expresses a preference for observing the famous people anonymously.
Nick is surprised by Gatsby's graceful dancing when he dances with Daisy.
Later, Daisy and Gatsby spend half an hour talking alone on Nick's porch steps, with Nick standing guard at Daisy's request.

events.text_segment:
Tom was evidently perturbed at Daisy’s running around alone, for on the following Saturday night he came with her to Gatsby’s party. Perhaps his presence gave the evening its peculiar quality of oppressiveness—it stands out in my memory from Gatsby’s other parties that summer. There were the same people, or at least the same sort of people, the same profusion of champagne, the same many-coloured, many-keyed commotion, but I felt an unpleasantness in the air, a pervading harshness that hadn’t been there before. Or perhaps I had merely grown used to it, grown to accept West Egg as a world complete in itself, with its own standards and its own great figures, second to nothing because it had no consciousness of being so, and now I was looking at it again, through Daisy’s eyes. It is invariably saddening to look through new eyes at things upon which you have expended your own powers of adjustment.
They arrived at twilight, and, as we strolled out among the sparkling hundreds, Daisy’s voice was playing murmurous tricks in her throat.
“These things excite me so,” she whispered. “If you want to kiss me any time during the evening, Nick, just let me know and I’ll be glad to arrange it for you. Just mention my name. Or present a green card. I’m giving out green—”
“Look around,” suggested Gatsby.
“I’m looking around. I’m having a marvellous—”
“You must see the faces of many people you’ve heard about.”
Tom’s arrogant eyes roamed the crowd.
“We don’t go around very much,” he said; “in fact, I was just thinking I don’t know a soul here.”
“Perhaps you know that lady.” Gatsby indicated a gorgeous, scarcely human orchid of a woman who sat in state under a white-plum tree. Tom and Daisy stared, with that peculiarly unreal feeling that accompanies the recognition of a hitherto ghostly celebrity of the movies.
“She’s lovely,” said Daisy.
“The man bending over her is her director.”
He took them ceremoniously from group to group:
“Mrs. Buchanan… and Mr. Buchanan—” After an instant’s hesitation he added: “the polo player.”
“Oh no,” objected Tom quickly, “not me.”
But evidently the sound of it pleased Gatsby for Tom remained “the polo player” for the rest of the evening.
“I’ve never met so many celebrities,” Daisy exclaimed. “I liked that man—what was his name?—with the sort of blue nose.”
Gatsby identified him, adding that he was a small producer.
“Well, I liked him anyhow.”
“I’d a little rather not be the polo player,” said Tom pleasantly, “I’d rather look at all these famous people in—in oblivion.”
Daisy and Gatsby danced. I remember being surprised by his graceful, conservative foxtrot—I had never seen him dance before. Then they sauntered over to my house and sat on the steps for half an hour, while at her request I remained watchfully in the garden. “In case there’s a fire or a flood,” she explained, “or any act of God.”
Tom appeared from his oblivion as we were sitting down to supper together. “Do you mind if I eat with some people over here?” he said. “A fellow’s getting off some funny stuff.”
“Go ahead,” answered Daisy genially, “and if you want to take down any addresses here’s my little gold pencil.”… She looked around after a moment and told me the girl was “common but pretty,” and I knew that except for the half-hour she’d been alone with Gatsby she wasn’t having a good time.

events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
Tom was clearly unsettled by Daisy going out by herself, so the next Saturday he accompanied her to Gatsby’s party. His attendance may have been what made the evening feel so stifling—the event stands out in my mind from Gatsby’s other parties that summer. There were the usual guests, or at least the same sort of crowd, just as much champagne, and the same lively, multi-colored chaos, but this time I sensed a certain discomfort, a harshness in the atmosphere that I hadn’t noticed before. Maybe I had just grown accustomed to it—perhaps West Egg had become a complete, self-contained world in my mind, with its own standards and celebrities, feeling important simply because it didn’t know any different, and now I was seeing it anew, through Daisy’s perspective. Tom and Daisy arrived at dusk, and as we mingled with the glittering crowd, Daisy spoke in a soft, excited voice. She whispered to me that she found the occasion thrilling and joked that if I wanted to kiss her during the evening, I only needed to ask or present a green card, as she was 'giving out green.' Gatsby encouraged her to look around, and she replied that she was enjoying herself, marveling at all the famous faces. Tom, looking around arrogantly, remarked that they didn’t socialize much and that he didn’t know anyone there. Tom insisted he’d rather observe than be called a polo player, preferring to stay in the background among all the famous guests.
Daisy and Gatsby danced together; I was surprised by Gatsby’s skillful and understated foxtrot, since I’d never seen him dance before. Afterwards, they strolled over to my house and sat on the steps for half an hour while I waited nearby in the garden at Daisy’s suggestion, supposedly in case of an emergency. Later, when we sat down for supper, Tom reappeared and asked if he could join another group because someone was telling jokes, and Daisy cheerfully offered him her gold pencil for taking addresses. After a while, she told me that a certain girl was ‘common but pretty,’ and I realized that except for the time she spent alone with Gatsby, Daisy hadn’t actually enjoyed herself at the party.

Daisy remarks that the actress is 'lovely'.
However, the public display of emotion and the general atmosphere of West Egg offend Daisy deeply.
She is appalled by its 'raw vigour', perceived lack of social graces, and the trajectory of its inhabitants' lives.
She finds the 'simplicity' she doesn't understand to be awful.
While Nick, Tom, and Daisy wait for their car, Tom abruptly speculates that Gatsby is a bootlegger.
Nick dismisses the idea, but Tom persists, criticizing Gatsby's collection of guests.
Daisy defends the guests as more interesting than their own circle, though Tom doubts her sincerity.
Daisy begins humming and singing along with the party music drifting from the house.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: We were at a particularly tipsy table.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Perhaps some unbelievable guest would arrive, a person infinitely rare and to be marvelled at, some authentically radiant young girl who with one fresh glance at Gatsby, one moment of magical encounter, would blot out those five years of unwavering devotion.

events.text_segment:
We were at a particularly tipsy table. That was my fault—Gatsby had been called to the phone, and I’d enjoyed these same people only two weeks before. But what had amused me then turned septic on the air now.
“How do you feel, Miss Baedeker?”
The girl addressed was trying, unsuccessfully, to slump against my shoulder. At this inquiry she sat up and opened her eyes.
“Wha’?”
A massive and lethargic woman, who had been urging Daisy to play golf with her at the local club tomorrow, spoke in Miss Baedeker’s defence:
“Oh, she’s all right now. When she’s had five or six cocktails she always starts screaming like that. I tell her she ought to leave it alone.”
“I do leave it alone,” affirmed the accused hollowly.
“We heard you yelling, so I said to Doc Civet here: ‘There’s somebody that needs your help, Doc.’ ”
“She’s much obliged, I’m sure,” said another friend, without gratitude, “but you got her dress all wet when you stuck her head in the pool.”
“Anything I hate is to get my head stuck in a pool,” mumbled Miss Baedeker. “They almost drowned me once over in New Jersey.”
“Then you ought to leave it alone,” countered Doctor Civet.
“Speak for yourself!” cried Miss Baedeker violently. “Your hand shakes. I wouldn’t let you operate on me!”
It was like that. Almost the last thing I remember was standing with Daisy and watching the moving-picture director and his Star. They were still under the white-plum tree and their faces were touching except for a pale, thin ray of moonlight between. It occurred to me that he had been very slowly bending toward her all evening to attain this proximity, and even while I watched I saw him stoop one ultimate degree and kiss at her cheek.
“I like her,” said Daisy, “I think she’s lovely.”
But the rest offended her—and inarguably because it wasn’t a gesture but an emotion. She was appalled by West Egg, this unprecedented “place” that Broadway had begotten upon a Long Island fishing village—appalled by its raw vigour that chafed under the old euphemisms and by the too obtrusive fate that herded its inhabitants along a shortcut from nothing to nothing. She saw something awful in the very simplicity she failed to understand.
I sat on the front steps with them while they waited for their car. It was dark here in front; only the bright door sent ten square feet of light volleying out into the soft black morning. Sometimes a shadow moved against a dressing-room blind above, gave way to another shadow, an indefinite procession of shadows, who rouged and powdered in an invisible glass.
“Who is this Gatsby anyhow?” demanded Tom suddenly. “Some big bootlegger?”
“Where’d you hear that?” I inquired.
“I didn’t hear it. I imagined it. A lot of these newly rich people are just big bootleggers, you know.”
“Not Gatsby,” I said shortly.
He was silent for a moment. The pebbles of the drive crunched under his feet.
“Well, he certainly must have strained himself to get this menagerie together.”
A breeze stirred the grey haze of Daisy’s fur collar.
“At least they are more interesting than the people we know,” she said with an effort.
“You didn’t look so interested.”
“Well, I was.”
Tom laughed and turned to me.
“Did you notice Daisy’s face when that girl asked her to put her under a cold shower?”
Daisy began to sing with the music in a husky, rhythmic whisper, bringing out a meaning in each word that it had never had before and would never have again. When the melody rose her voice broke up sweetly, following it, in a way contralto voices have, and each change tipped out a little of her warm human magic upon the air.
“Lots of people come who haven’t been invited,” she said suddenly. “That girl hadn’t been invited. They simply force their way in and he’s too polite to object.”
“I’d like to know who he is and what he does,” insisted Tom. “And I think I’ll make a point of finding out.”
“I can tell you right now,” she answered. “He owned some drugstores, a lot of drugstores. He built them up himself.”
The dilatory limousine came rolling up the drive.
“Good night, Nick,” said Daisy.
Her glance left me and sought the lighted top of the steps, where “Three O’Clock in the Morning,” a neat, sad little waltz of that year, was drifting out the open door. After all, in the very casualness of Gatsby’s party there were romantic possibilities totally absent from her world. What was it up there in the song that seemed to be calling her back inside? What would happen now in the dim, incalculable hours? Perhaps some unbelievable guest would arrive, a person infinitely rare and to be marvelled at, some authentically radiant young girl who with one fresh glance at Gatsby, one moment of magical encounter, would blot out those five years of unwavering devotion.

I was partly to blame for this; Gatsby had been called away, and I'd enjoyed interacting with the same people just two weeks prior. However, what I'd found amusing then now felt off-putting. Someone asked, "How are you feeling, Miss Baedeker?" The young woman being addressed was unsuccessfully trying to lean against my shoulder. Hearing the question, she sat up and opened her eyes, responding, "What?" A large, sluggish woman who had been trying to convince Daisy to play golf with her the next day defended Miss Baedeker, saying, "Oh, she's fine now. She always starts screaming like that after five or six cocktails. I keep telling her to stop." Miss Baedeker weakly insisted, "I do stop." The other woman continued, "We heard you yelling, so I told Doc Civet here, 'Someone needs your help, Doc.'" Another friend sarcastically added, "She's surely grateful, but you soaked her dress when you shoved her head in the pool." "I hate having my head shoved in a pool," Miss Baedeker mumbled. "They almost drowned me once in New Jersey." Doctor Civet retorted, "Then you should avoid it." Miss Baedeker aggressively shot back, "Mind your own business! Your hand shakes. I wouldn't let you operate on me!" The atmosphere was like that. One of my final memories from the party was standing with Daisy, watching the movie director and his lead actress. They were still under the white plum tree, their faces close, separated only by a thin line of moonlight. It struck me that he had been slowly leaning towards her all night to get this close, and even as I watched, he leaned one last bit and kissed her cheek. Daisy commented, "I like her; I think she's lovely." But the rest of the party bothered her, definitely because it wasn't just behavior but a feeling. She was disturbed by West Egg, this strange new place created by mixing Broadway people with a Long Island fishing village – disturbed by its crude energy that didn't fit with old traditions and by the obvious way its residents were quickly moving from obscurity to nothingness. She found something unsettling in the very simplicity she couldn't grasp. I sat with them on the front steps, waiting for their car. It was dark there, with only the bright light from the doorway extending ten square feet into the soft, dark morning. Sometimes a shadow moved behind a dressing room window upstairs, replaced by another shadow, a hazy line of figures applying makeup and powder in an unseen mirror. Tom suddenly asked, "Who exactly is this Gatsby? Some major bootlegger?" "Where did you hear that?" I asked. "I didn't hear it. I just figured it. A lot of these newly wealthy people are just big bootleggers, you know." "Not Gatsby," I stated simply. He was quiet for a moment, the gravel on the driveway crunching under his feet. "Well, he certainly had to work hard to gather this assortment of people." A breeze rustled the grey fluff of Daisy's fur collar. "At least they're more interesting than the people we know," she said with effort. "You didn't seem that interested." "Well, I was." Tom laughed and turned to me. "Did you see Daisy's reaction when that girl suggested putting her under a cold shower?" Daisy started singing softly to the music in a low, rhythmic whisper, giving each word a meaning it had never held before and would never hold again. When the tune went higher, her voice sweetly followed, breaking slightly, as contralto voices sometimes do, and with each change, a little of her warm, human charm seemed to spread into the air. "Many people come who aren't invited," she said abruptly. "That girl wasn't invited. They just push their way in, and he's too polite to say no." Tom insisted, "I want to know who he is and what he does. And I plan to find out." "I can tell you now," she replied. "He owned drugstores, many of them. He built them up himself." The slow-moving limousine finally drove up. "Good night, Nick," Daisy said. Her eyes left me and went up to the lit area at the top of the steps, where "Three O'Clock in the Morning," a simple, melancholic little waltz from that year, was drifting out the open door. After all, in the casual nature of Gatsby's party, there were romantic possibilities completely absent from her life. What was it about that song upstairs that seemed to call her back inside? What would happen during the unpredictable hours ahead? events.title: Gatsby's Post-Party Despair and Obsession with Repeating the Past
detailed_summary: Nick waits for Gatsby after the party guests have left.
Gatsby finally appears, looking strained and tired.
He immediately tells Nick that Daisy disliked the party and didn't have a good time.
Nick senses Gatsby's profound depression and feelings of distance from Daisy.
Gatsby reveals his ultimate desire: for Daisy to tell Tom she never loved him.
He believes this declaration would erase the past four years, allowing them to return to Louisville and marry as if it were five years ago.
He expresses frustration that Daisy doesn't seem to understand or accept this plan.
Nick advises Gatsby not to demand too much from Daisy, stating, 'You can't repeat the past'.
Gatsby reacts with incredulous disagreement, passionately insisting that the past *can* be repeated.
He vows to 'fix everything just the way it was before'.
Gatsby talks extensively about the past, conveying his longing to recover something essential—perhaps an idealized version of himself—that became intertwined with loving Daisy.
He feels his life has been disordered since losing her and believes returning to a specific 'starting place' could clarify what was lost.
He recounts a specific memory: walking with Daisy on a moonlit autumn night five years earlier.
He describes the magical atmosphere and his perception of the sidewalk as a symbolic ladder to a higher realm attainable only alone.
He recalls the moment before kissing Daisy, realizing that doing so would forever bind his 'unutterable visions' to her 'perishable breath,' ending his purely imaginative, god-like state.
He paused, then kissed her, feeling her 'blossom' and completing the 'incarnation' of his dream.

However, the feeling remains elusive and ultimately 'uncommunicable'.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: I stayed late that night.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: But they made no sound, and what I had almost remembered was uncommunicable forever.

events.text_segment:
I stayed late that night. Gatsby asked me to wait until he was free, and I lingered in the garden until the inevitable swimming party had run up, chilled and exalted, from the black beach, until the lights were extinguished in the guestrooms overhead. When he came down the steps at last the tanned skin was drawn unusually tight on his face, and his eyes were bright and tired.
“She didn’t like it,” he said immediately.
“Of course she did.”
“She didn’t like it,” he insisted. “She didn’t have a good time.”
He was silent, and I guessed at his unutterable depression.
“I feel far away from her,” he said. “It’s hard to make her understand.”
“You mean about the dance?”
“The dance?” He dismissed all the dances he had given with a snap of his fingers. “Old sport, the dance is unimportant.”
He wanted nothing less of Daisy than that she should go to Tom and say: “I never loved you.” After she had obliterated four years with that sentence they could decide upon the more practical measures to be taken. One of them was that, after she was free, they were to go back to Louisville and be married from her house—just as if it were five years ago.
“And she doesn’t understand,” he said. “She used to be able to understand. We’d sit for hours—”
He broke off and began to walk up and down a desolate path of fruit rinds and discarded favours and crushed flowers.
“I wouldn’t ask too much of her,” I ventured. “You can’t repeat the past.”
“Can’t repeat the past?” he cried incredulously. “Why of course you can!”
He looked around him wildly, as if the past were lurking here in the shadow of his house, just out of reach of his hand.
“I’m going to fix everything just the way it was before,” he said, nodding determinedly. “She’ll see.”
He talked a lot about the past, and I gathered that he wanted to recover something, some idea of himself perhaps, that had gone into loving Daisy. His life had been confused and disordered since then, but if he could once return to a certain starting place and go over it all slowly, he could find out what that thing was…
… One autumn night, five years before, they had been walking down the street when the leaves were falling, and they came to a place where there were no trees and the sidewalk was white with moonlight. They stopped here and turned toward each other. Now it was a cool night with that mysterious excitement in it which comes at the two changes of the year. The quiet lights in the houses were humming out into the darkness and there was a stir and bustle among the stars. Out of the corner of his eye Gatsby saw that the blocks of the sidewalks really formed a ladder and mounted to a secret place above the trees—he could climb to it, if he climbed alone, and once there he could suck on the pap of life, gulp down the incomparable milk of wonder.
His heart beat faster as Daisy’s white face came up to his own. He knew that when he kissed this girl, and forever wed his unutterable visions to her perishable breath, his mind would never romp again like the mind of God. So he waited, listening for a moment longer to the tuning-fork that had been struck upon a star. Then he kissed her. At his lips’ touch she blossomed for him like a flower and the incarnation was complete.
Through all he said, even through his appalling sentimentality, I was reminded of something—an elusive rhythm, a fragment of lost words, that I had heard somewhere a long time ago. For a moment a phrase tried to take shape in my mouth and my lips parted like a dumb man’s, as though there was more struggling upon them than a wisp of startled air. But they made no sound, and what I had almost remembered was uncommunicable forever.

"Of course, she did," I replied. "She didn't like it," he insisted again. "She didn't enjoy herself." He fell silent, and I could sense his profound sadness. "I feel distant from her," he said. events.title: Gatsby's Parties Cease and Staff Replaced
detailed_summary: Nick notices Gatsby's house is dark on a Saturday night, signaling the end of his extravagant parties.
Cars arriving at Gatsby's driveway turn away disappointed.
Concerned, Nick goes to Gatsby's house and encounters a rude, unfamiliar butler who confirms Gatsby isn't sick but offers no further information.
Nick learns from his housekeeper that Gatsby fired his entire staff a week prior and hired new ones, rumored not to be actual servants, who maintain secrecy and order supplies minimally.
Gatsby phones Nick the next day.
Gatsby confirms he fired his staff because he wanted people who wouldn't spread rumors, as Daisy frequently visits him in the afternoons.
Nick realizes Gatsby dismantled his entire social spectacle because Daisy disapproved.
Gatsby mentions the new staff are associates of Wolfshiem, possibly siblings who previously ran a hotel.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: It was when curiosity about Gatsby was at its highest that the lights in his house failed to go on one Saturday night—and, as obscurely as it had begun, his career as Trimalchio was over.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “I see.”

events.text_segment:
It was when curiosity about Gatsby was at its highest that the lights in his house failed to go on one Saturday night—and, as obscurely as it had begun, his career as Trimalchio was over. Only gradually did I become aware that the automobiles which turned expectantly into his drive stayed for just a minute and then drove sulkily away. Wondering if he were sick I went over to find out—an unfamiliar butler with a villainous face squinted at me suspiciously from the door.
“Is Mr. Gatsby sick?”
“Nope.” After a pause he added “sir” in a dilatory, grudging way.
“I hadn’t seen him around, and I was rather worried. Tell him Mr. Carraway came over.”
“Who?” he demanded rudely.
“Carraway.”
“Carraway. All right, I’ll tell him.”
Abruptly he slammed the door.
My Finn informed me that Gatsby had dismissed every servant in his house a week ago and replaced them with half a dozen others, who never went into West Egg village to be bribed by the tradesmen, but ordered moderate supplies over the telephone. The grocery boy reported that the kitchen looked like a pigsty, and the general opinion in the village was that the new people weren’t servants at all.
Next day Gatsby called me on the phone.
“Going away?” I inquired.
“No, old sport.”
“I hear you fired all your servants.”
“I wanted somebody who wouldn’t gossip. Daisy comes over quite often—in the afternoons.”
So the whole caravansary had fallen in like a card house at the disapproval in her eyes.
“They’re some people Wolfshiem wanted to do something for. They’re all brothers and sisters. They used to run a small hotel.”
“I see.”
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: Right when speculation about Gatsby was at its peak, his mansion remained dark on a Saturday evening, signaling the sudden end of his extravagant party-hosting days, which had begun just as mysteriously. Gradually, I noticed cars turning into his driveway with anticipation, only to leave moments later, looking dejected. Concerned he might be ill, I went to check on him. An unfamiliar butler with a suspicious, unpleasant expression eyed me warily from the doorway. I asked, "Is Mr. Gatsby unwell?" He simply replied, "Nope," adding a drawn-out, reluctant "sir" after a pause. I explained, "I haven't seen him around and was a bit concerned. Please tell him Mr. Carraway stopped by." He rudely demanded, "Who?" I repeated, "Carraway." He acknowledged, "Carraway. Alright, I'll inform him," before abruptly shutting the door in my face. My cleaning woman told me Gatsby had fired all his previous staff a week earlier and hired a new group of about six people. These new employees stayed out of the local village, avoiding interaction or bribes from shopkeepers, and placed small orders over the phone. The boy who delivered groceries reported the kitchen was filthy, and the general consensus locally was that these new people were not actually servants. The following day, Gatsby telephoned me. I asked if he was leaving. He said, "No, old sport." I mentioned hearing about him firing all his servants. He explained, "I wanted staff who wouldn't spread rumors. Daisy comes over quite frequently now—in the afternoons." So, it seemed the entire elaborate setup had collapsed completely, like a house of cards, due to her disapproval. He added, "They are people Mr. Wolfshiem wanted to help out. They are all family, brothers and sisters. They used to operate a small hotel." I responded, "I understand."
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14: At the height of public curiosity about Gatsby, the lights at his house remained dark one Saturday night, marking an inconspicuous end to his era of lavish, Trimalchio-like parties. I gradually noticed that cars would drive in expecting festivities, only to leave shortly after in disappointment. Concerned that Gatsby might be unwell, I decided to check on him myself, only to be met by a new, unfriendly butler who eyed me with suspicion. When I asked for Gatsby, the butler answered tersely, and even seemed unfamiliar with my name before rudely shutting the door. Later, I learned from my housekeeper that Gatsby had recently let go of his entire staff, replacing them with a handful of people who kept to themselves and didn’t socialize in the village, instead making only modest orders over the phone. Gossip around town claimed the newcomers didn’t even seem like real servants, and that the kitchen was in disarray. The following day, Gatsby phoned me. When I asked about the staff change, he explained he wanted to avoid gossip because Daisy had been visiting frequently in the afternoons. The extravagant house parties had ceased, collapsing like a house of cards under Daisy’s disapproval. Gatsby added that the new servants were associates of Wolfshiem’s, supposedly siblings who once managed a small hotel. I accepted this explanation.

events.title: Invitation to Lunch Amidst Oppressive Heat
detailed_summary: Gatsby calls Nick at Daisy's request, inviting him to lunch at the Buchanans' house the following day, mentioning Miss Baker will also attend.
Daisy calls Nick shortly after, expressing relief that he accepted, making Nick sense that something significant is planned, possibly the confrontation Gatsby had previously mentioned.
The next day is described as unbearably hot, the peak of summer.
Nick travels by train through the intense heat, observing the discomfort of fellow passengers, including a woman who drops her purse.
Nick retrieves the purse for the woman but feels unjustly suspected by her and others nearby.
The train conductor complains about the heat, leaving a sweaty stain on Nick's ticket.
Nick reflects on the overpowering heat, questioning the significance of romance or emotion in such extreme weather.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: He was calling up at Daisy’s request—would I come to lunch at her house tomorrow?
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: That anyone should care in this heat whose flushed lips he kissed, whose head made damp the pyjama pocket over his heart!

events.text_segment:
He was calling up at Daisy’s request—would I come to lunch at her house tomorrow? Miss Baker would be there. Half an hour later Daisy herself telephoned and seemed relieved to find that I was coming. Something was up. And yet I couldn’t believe that they would choose this occasion for a scene—especially for the rather harrowing scene that Gatsby had outlined in the garden.
The next day was broiling, almost the last, certainly the warmest, of the summer. As my train emerged from the tunnel into sunlight, only the hot whistles of the National Biscuit Company broke the simmering hush at noon. The straw seats of the car hovered on the edge of combustion; the woman next to me perspired delicately for a while into her white shirtwaist, and then, as her newspaper dampened under her fingers, lapsed despairingly into deep heat with a desolate cry. Her pocketbook slapped to the floor.
“Oh, my!” she gasped.
I picked it up with a weary bend and handed it back to her, holding it at arm’s length and by the extreme tip of the corners to indicate that I had no designs upon it—but everyone near by, including the woman, suspected me just the same.
“Hot!” said the conductor to familiar faces. “Some weather!… Hot!… Hot!… Hot!… Is it hot enough for you? Is it hot? Is it… ?”
My commutation ticket came back to me with a dark stain from his hand. That anyone should care in this heat whose flushed lips he kissed, whose head made damp the pyjama pocket over his heart!
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: Gatsby called at Daisy's prompting, asking if I would come to lunch at her place the following day, mentioning that Miss Baker would also be present. About thirty minutes later, Daisy herself telephoned and sounded relieved to hear I was coming. It felt like something significant was about to unfold. Nevertheless, I couldn't imagine they would select this particular time for a confrontation, especially not the potentially distressing scene that Gatsby had outlined to me in the garden. The next day was intensely hot, quite possibly the hottest, and certainly one of the final, days of summer. As my train emerged from the tunnel into the bright sun, the only sound breaking the still noon quiet was the loud blasts from the National Biscuit Company. The straw seats of the train car felt on the verge of combustion; the woman beside me initially sweated delicately into her white blouse, and then, as her newspaper grew damp under her fingers, she slumped despairingly into the oppressive heat with a wretched cry. Her handbag fell to the floor. “Oh, heavens!” she gasped. I picked it up with a tired bend and gave it back to her, holding it out at arm's length by the very tips of the corners to show I had no interest in its contents—yet everyone nearby, including the woman, seemed to eye me with suspicion just the same. “Hot!” the conductor said to people he recognized. “Some weather!… Hot!… Hot!… Hot!… Is this heat enough for you? Is it hot? Is it…?” My train ticket was returned to me with a dark smudge from his hand. In this heat, it struck me as irrelevant whose flushed lips he might have kissed, or whose head might have dampened the pajama pocket above his heart!
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
He was calling because Daisy had asked him to—he wanted to know if I’d come to lunch at her place the next day. Miss Baker would be there, too. About thirty minutes later, Daisy herself called and sounded relieved to hear I was coming. Clearly, something was going on. Still, I couldn’t imagine they’d use this event for a confrontation—especially not the painful one Gatsby had described in the garden.

The following day was sweltering—one of the last days of summer and definitely the hottest. As the train left the tunnel and entered the bright daylight, the only sounds piercing the heavy midday quiet were the hot whistles from the National Biscuit Company. The straw seats on the train seemed like they were about to catch fire from the heat. The woman sitting next to me quietly sweated through her white shirt for a while, then, as her newspaper became damp in her hands, she gave up and let out a lonely cry, overcome by the heat. Her purse dropped to the floor.

“Oh, my!” she exclaimed.

I picked it up for her, tiredly bending over and handing it back by the very tips of my fingers—trying to make it obvious I was only being helpful—but people around, and even the woman herself, seemed to suspect me anyway.

“It’s hot!” the conductor said to people he recognized. “Some weather! Hot! Hot! Hot! Is it hot enough for you? Is it hot?”

When I got my commuter ticket back, it was stained dark from his hand. In this kind of heat, it seemed ridiculous that anyone would care who anybody kissed or whose head left sweat on someone’s pajama pocket.

events.title: Tense Arrival and Pammy's Introduction at the Buchanans'
detailed_summary: Nick and Gatsby arrive at the Buchanans' house, hearing the phone ringing inside.
The butler answers the phone with a dismissive remark about the heat before greeting them.
The butler leads them into a cool, darkened room where Daisy and Jordan are reclining languidly on a couch, complaining about the heat.
Jordan greets Nick.
Tom's voice is heard on the phone in the hall; Jordan whispers to Nick that Tom's mistress is likely the caller.

events.text_segment:
… Through the hall of the Buchanans’ house blew a faint wind, carrying the sound of the telephone bell out to Gatsby and me as we waited at the door.
“The master’s body?” roared the butler into the mouthpiece. “I’m sorry, madame, but we can’t furnish it—it’s far too hot to touch this noon!”
What he really said was: “Yes… Yes… I’ll see.”
He set down the receiver and came toward us, glistening slightly, to take our stiff straw hats.
“Madame expects you in the salon!” he cried, needlessly indicating the direction. In this heat every extra gesture was an affront to the common store of life.
The room, shadowed well with awnings, was dark and cool. Daisy and Jordan lay upon an enormous couch, like silver idols weighing down their own white dresses against the singing breeze of the fans.
“We can’t move,” they said together.
Jordan’s fingers, powdered white over their tan, rested for a moment in mine.
“And Mr. Thomas Buchanan, the athlete?” I inquired.
Simultaneously I heard his voice, gruff, muffled, husky, at the hall telephone.
Gatsby stood in the centre of the crimson carpet and gazed around with fascinated eyes. Daisy watched him and laughed, her sweet, exciting laugh; a tiny gust of powder rose from her bosom into the air.
“The rumour is,” whispered Jordan, “that that’s Tom’s girl on the telephone.”
We were silent. The voice in the hall rose high with annoyance: “Very well, then, I won’t sell you the car at all… I’m under no obligations to you at all… and as for your bothering me about it at lunch time, I won’t stand that at all!”
“Holding down the receiver,” said Daisy cynically.
“No, he’s not,” I assured her. “It’s a bona-fide deal. I happen to know about it.”
Tom flung open the door, blocked out its space for a moment with his thick body, and hurried into the room.
“Mr. Gatsby!” He put out his broad, flat hand with well-concealed dislike. “I’m glad to see you, sir… Nick…”
“Make us a cold drink,” cried Daisy.
As he left the room again she got up and went over to Gatsby and pulled his face down, kissing him on the mouth.
“You know I love you,” she murmured.
“You forget there’s a lady present,” said Jordan.
Daisy looked around doubtfully.
“You kiss Nick too.”
“What a low, vulgar girl!”
“I don’t care!” cried Daisy, and began to clog on the brick fireplace. Then she remembered the heat and sat down guiltily on the couch just as a freshly laundered nurse leading a little girl came into the room.
“Bles-sed pre-cious,” she crooned, holding out her arms. “Come to your own mother that loves you.”
The child, relinquished by the nurse, rushed across the room and rooted shyly into her mother’s dress.
“The bles-sed pre-cious! Did mother get powder on your old yellowy hair? Stand up now, and say—How-de-do.”
Gatsby and I in turn leaned down and took the small reluctant hand. Afterward he kept looking at the child with surprise. I don’t think he had ever really believed in its existence before.
“I got dressed before luncheon,” said the child, turning eagerly to Daisy.
“That’s because your mother wanted to show you off.” Her face bent into the single wrinkle of the small white neck. “You dream, you. You absolute little dream.”
“Yes,” admitted the child calmly. “Aunt Jordan’s got on a white dress too.”
“How do you like mother’s friends?” Daisy turned her around so that she faced Gatsby. “Do you think they’re pretty?”
“Where’s Daddy?”
“She doesn’t look like her father,” explained Daisy. “She looks like me. She’s got my hair and shape of the face.”
Daisy sat back upon the couch. The nurse took a step forward and held out her hand.
“Come, Pammy.”
“Goodbye, sweetheart!”
With a reluctant backward glance the well-disciplined child held to her nurse’s hand and was pulled out the door, just as Tom came back, preceding four gin rickeys that clicked full of ice.

However, what he actually said was simply, "Yes... Yes... I will see." He then placed the receiver down and approached us, slightly gleaming with sweat, to take our stiff straw hats. "Madame is expecting you in the drawing-room!" he announced, unnecessarily gesturing towards it. In such intense heat, any superfluous movement felt like an imposition. The drawing-room, well-shaded by awnings, was cool and dimly lit. I have absolutely no obligation to you... and as for bothering me about it during lunch, I absolutely will not tolerate that!" "He's just pretending to hang up," Daisy remarked sarcastically. "Come to your very own mother who adores you." The child, released by the nurse, quickly crossed the room and shyly burrowed into her mother's dress. "My blessed precious! Did mother get powder on your slightly yellow hair? Stand up now, and say—Hello." Both Gatsby and I in turn leaned down and took the child's small, hesitant hand. Afterwards, he continued to look at the child with astonishment. I don't believe he had ever truly accepted her existence before. "I was dressed before lunch," the child said, turning eagerly to Daisy. "That's because your mother wanted to show you off." Her face softened into the single wrinkle of the child's small white neck. "You are a dream, you are. An absolute little dream." "Yes," the child agreed calmly. "Aunt Jordan is wearing a white dress too." "How do you like your mother's friends?" Daisy turned her so she faced Gatsby. "Do you think they are attractive?" "Where is Daddy?" "She doesn't resemble her father," Daisy explained. "She looks like me. She has my hair and face shape." Daisy leaned back onto the couch. The nurse stepped forward and extended her hand. "Let's go, Pammy." "Goodbye, sweetheart!" With a reluctant backward glance, the well-behaved child held the nurse's hand and was led out the door, just as Tom returned, carrying four gin rickeys that clinked with ice.

events.title: Luncheon Tension Culminates in a Trip to Town
detailed_summary: Gatsby nervously sips his drink.
Tom makes small talk about the weather and shows Gatsby the estate.
Gatsby points out his own house across the bay.
They have lunch in a darkened dining room, the mood strained despite attempts at gaiety.
Daisy despairs about the heat and the future, impulsively suggesting they all go to town.
While Tom talks to Gatsby about converting a garage, Daisy pointedly tells Gatsby he looks cool.
Daisy and Gatsby share an intense, exclusive gaze, which Tom observes.
Tom, visibly shocked and angered by the intimacy he witnessed, abruptly agrees to go to town.
Tom's agitation grows as he tries to hurry everyone along.

Daisy and Jordan go upstairs to prepare, leaving the men awkwardly waiting outside.
