The moment I touched the wheel, the crash happened—it must have killed her instantly.” “She was badly hurt—” “Please don’t tell me,” Gatsby said, wincing. “Anyway—Daisy floored it. I tried to make her stop, but she couldn’t, so I used the emergency brake. Then, overcome, she slumped into my lap and I kept driving.”

“She’ll be okay tomorrow,” he said after a moment. “I’m going to stay here to make sure no one bothers her about what happened this afternoon. She’s in her room, and if Tom tries to hurt her, she’ll signal by flicking the light.”

“He won’t touch her,” I reassured him. “He’s not thinking of her right now.”

“I still don’t trust him,” Gatsby said.

A new thought occurred to me: if Tom found out Daisy had been driving, he might make further connections. I looked back at the house, noticing the downstairs windows lit up and Daisy’s room glowing pink. “Wait here,” I told Gatsby. “I’ll check if there’s any trouble.”

So I left him there, standing in the moonlight—watching over nothing.

events.title: Nick's Anxious Vigil and Gatsby's Despair
detailed_summary: Nick spends a sleepless night disturbed by a foghorn and troubling thoughts, feeling an urgent need to warn Gatsby.
He goes to Gatsby's house at dawn, finding the door open and Gatsby inside, looking exhausted and dejected.
Gatsby reports that Daisy came to the window briefly during the night but then turned off the light, offering no resolution.
Nick observes the immense, dusty, and unused state of Gatsby's mansion as they search for cigarettes, highlighting its emptiness.
They sit smoking by the open windows.
Nick advises Gatsby to leave town immediately, suggesting Atlantic City or Montreal, fearing Gatsby's car will be traced back to the accident.
Gatsby refuses, stating he cannot leave until he knows Daisy's decision, clinging to a final hope.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: I couldn’t sleep all night; a foghorn was groaning incessantly on the Sound, and I tossed half-sick between grotesque reality and savage, frightening dreams.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He was clutching at some last hope and I couldn’t bear to shake him free.

events.text_segment:
I couldn’t sleep all night; a foghorn was groaning incessantly on the Sound, and I tossed half-sick between grotesque reality and savage, frightening dreams. Toward dawn I heard a taxi go up Gatsby’s drive, and immediately I jumped out of bed and began to dress—I felt that I had something to tell him, something to warn him about, and morning would be too late.
Crossing his lawn, I saw that his front door was still open and he was leaning against a table in the hall, heavy with dejection or sleep.
“Nothing happened,” he said wanly. “I waited, and about four o’clock she came to the window and stood there for a minute and then turned out the light.”
His house had never seemed so enormous to me as it did that night when we hunted through the great rooms for cigarettes. We pushed aside curtains that were like pavilions, and felt over innumerable feet of dark wall for electric light switches—once I tumbled with a sort of splash upon the keys of a ghostly piano. There was an inexplicable amount of dust everywhere, and the rooms were musty, as though they hadn’t been aired for many days. I found the humidor on an unfamiliar table, with two stale, dry cigarettes inside. Throwing open the French windows of the drawing-room, we sat smoking out into the darkness.
“You ought to go away,” I said. “It’s pretty certain they’ll trace your car.”
“Go away now, old sport?”
“Go to Atlantic City for a week, or up to Montreal.”
He wouldn’t consider it. He couldn’t possibly leave Daisy until he knew what she was going to do. He was clutching at some last hope and I couldn’t bear to shake him free.

events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
I was unable to sleep the entire night; the sound of a foghorn echoed persistently over the water, and I lay restlessly, feeling unwell as I drifted between distorted reality and wild, disturbing dreams. Near dawn, I heard a taxi pull up Gatsby's driveway, and I got out of bed and started getting dressed right away—I had an urgent feeling that I needed to speak to him, to warn him about something, before morning arrived.

As I crossed his lawn, I noticed his front door was still open, and he stood by a table in the hall, looking exhausted or deeply sad.

"Nothing happened," he said tiredly. "I waited, and around four she appeared at the window for a moment, then turned off the light."

His house felt larger and lonelier to me than ever as we searched its vast rooms for cigarettes. We moved aside heavy curtains, feeling along dark walls for light switches—at one point, I stumbled and landed with a crash on a silent piano. Dust coated everything and the air was stuffy, as though no one had opened the rooms for days. I eventually came across the humidor on an unfamiliar table, but only two old, dry cigarettes remained. We flung open the French windows in the drawing room and smoked, looking out into the darkness.

"You should leave," I advised him. "It’s almost certain they’ll trace your car."

"Leave now?" he asked.

"Go to Atlantic City for a while, or maybe up to Montreal."

He refused to entertain the idea. He couldn’t bring himself to leave Daisy until he knew what her decision would be. He was holding onto a final glimmer of hope, and I didn’t have the heart to take it away from him.

events.title: Gatsby Recounts His Early Romance with Daisy
detailed_summary: Gatsby, feeling his persona shattered after the confrontation with Tom, confides in Nick about his past, specifically focusing on Daisy.
He describes Daisy as the first 'nice' girl he had ever known, encountered while he was an officer at Camp Taylor.
He was captivated by her beauty, her magnificent house, and the aura of wealth, mystery, and romance surrounding her life.
He notes the casualness with which she inhabited this world, so different from his own experience.
Gatsby found Daisy more desirable because many other men had loved her, feeling their emotional presence in her house.
He acknowledges his presence in her world was accidental; as a penniless man without a past, his uniform provided temporary cover.
He pursued Daisy intensely, taking what he could, aware he had no 'right' to her.
He admits he misled Daisy, letting her believe he belonged to her social stratum and could provide for her, though he couldn't.
Despite intending a temporary affair, Gatsby found himself deeply committed, as if following a 'grail'.
He realized the profound impact Daisy, as an extraordinary 'nice' girl, had on him, leaving him feeling empty yet married to her when she returned to her wealthy life.
He recalls their reunion two days later, feeling breathless and betrayed, yet overwhelmingly aware of the allure of her youth, wealth, and voice, which seemed to imprison and preserve her.
Gatsby confesses his surprise at falling in love and how his ambitions seemed less important than sharing his plans with Daisy.
He describes their last, tranquil afternoon together before he went to war, emphasizing their silent, profound connection and intimacy.

events.text_segment:
It was this night that he told me the strange story of his youth with Dan Cody—told it to me because “Jay Gatsby” had broken up like glass against Tom’s hard malice, and the long secret extravaganza was played out. I think that he would have acknowledged anything now, without reserve, but he wanted to talk about Daisy.
She was the first “nice” girl he had ever known. In various unrevealed capacities he had come in contact with such people, but always with indiscernible barbed wire between. He found her excitingly desirable. He went to her house, at first with other officers from Camp Taylor, then alone. It amazed him—he had never been in such a beautiful house before. But what gave it an air of breathless intensity, was that Daisy lived there—it was as casual a thing to her as his tent out at camp was to him. There was a ripe mystery about it, a hint of bedrooms upstairs more beautiful and cool than other bedrooms, of gay and radiant activities taking place through its corridors, and of romances that were not musty and laid away already in lavender but fresh and breathing and redolent of this year’s shining motorcars and of dances whose flowers were scarcely withered. It excited him, too, that many men had already loved Daisy—it increased her value in his eyes. He felt their presence all about the house, pervading the air with the shades and echoes of still vibrant emotions.
But he knew that he was in Daisy’s house by a colossal accident. However glorious might be his future as Jay Gatsby, he was at present a penniless young man without a past, and at any moment the invisible cloak of his uniform might slip from his shoulders. So he made the most of his time. He took what he could get, ravenously and unscrupulously—eventually he took Daisy one still October night, took her because he had no real right to touch her hand.
He might have despised himself, for he had certainly taken her under false pretences. I don’t mean that he had traded on his phantom millions, but he had deliberately given Daisy a sense of security; he let her believe that he was a person from much the same strata as herself—that he was fully able to take care of her. As a matter of fact, he had no such facilities—he had no comfortable family standing behind him, and he was liable at the whim of an impersonal government to be blown anywhere about the world.
But he didn’t despise himself and it didn’t turn out as he had imagined. He had intended, probably, to take what he could and go—but now he found that he had committed himself to the following of a grail. He knew that Daisy was extraordinary, but he didn’t realize just how extraordinary a “nice” girl could be. She vanished into her rich house, into her rich, full life, leaving Gatsby—nothing. He felt married to her, that was all.
When they met again, two days later, it was Gatsby who was breathless, who was, somehow, betrayed. Her porch was bright with the bought luxury of star-shine; the wicker of the settee squeaked fashionably as she turned toward him and he kissed her curious and lovely mouth. She had caught a cold, and it made her voice huskier and more charming than ever, and Gatsby was overwhelmingly aware of the youth and mystery that wealth imprisons and preserves, of the freshness of many clothes, and of Daisy, gleaming like silver, safe and proud above the hot struggles of the poor.
“I can’t describe to you how surprised I was to find out I loved her, old sport. I even hoped for a while that she’d throw me over, but she didn’t, because she was in love with me too. She thought I knew a lot because I knew different things from her… Well, there I was, way off my ambitions, getting deeper in love every minute, and all of a sudden I didn’t care. What was the use of doing great things if I could have a better time telling her what I was going to do?”
On the last afternoon before he went abroad, he sat with Daisy in his arms for a long, silent time. It was a cold fall day, with fire in the room and her cheeks flushed. Now and then she moved and he changed his arm a little, and once he kissed her dark shining hair. The afternoon had made them tranquil for a while, as if to give them a deep memory for the long parting the next day promised. They had never been closer in their month of love, nor communicated more profoundly one with another, than when she brushed silent lips against his coat’s shoulder or when he touched the end of her fingers, gently, as though she were asleep.

She retreated back into her affluent residence and her privileged, abundant existence, leaving Gatsby with nothing. All he felt was a sense of being tied to her, as though they were married. Gatsby then quoted his past self, saying, "I can’t explain how astonished I was to discover I was in love with her, old sport. I even wished for a time that she would break things off, but she didn’t, because she was also in love with me. She believed I was very knowledgeable because the things I knew were different from what she knew… So there I was, completely sidetracked from my ambitions, falling more deeply in love every moment, until suddenly nothing else mattered. What was the benefit of achieving great things if I could have a better time simply describing my future plans to her?" On the final afternoon before his deployment abroad, he and Daisy sat embracing for a lengthy period in silence. It was a chilly fall day, with a warm fire in the room and her cheeks glowing. Periodically she would stir, and he would slightly shift his arm; on one occasion, he kissed her dark, lustrous hair. That afternoon momentarily granted them a sense of calm, almost as if preparing them with a profound memory for the long separation promised by the following day. In their month-long romance, they had never felt more connected or communicated more deeply than through her soft, silent touch against his coat shoulder or when he lightly touched the tip of her fingers, as though she were slumbering.

He knew Daisy was remarkable, but he hadn’t realized just how special a “nice” girl could be. She disappeared back into her wealthy life, leaving Gatsby with nothing but the feeling of being married to her.
When they saw each other again two days later, it was Gatsby who felt breathless and betrayed. Her porch gleamed with the luxury of bought starlight; the wicker couch creaked fashionably as she turned and he kissed her beautiful, curious mouth. She had caught a cold, making her voice even more appealing, and Gatsby was struck by the youthful mystery protected by wealth, the freshness of her many clothes, and Daisy herself—shining, proud, and secure far above the struggles of the poor.
“I can’t tell you how shocked I was to realize I loved her,” Gatsby said. “For a while I even hoped she’d leave me, but she didn’t, because she loved me too. She thought I knew a lot, just because I knew things she didn’t… So there I was, forgetting my ambitions, loving her more every minute, and suddenly it didn’t matter. Why chase big dreams when I had as much joy telling her about them?”
On his last afternoon before leaving for Europe, Gatsby and Daisy sat together quietly for a long time. It was a chilly autumn day, a fire burned in the room, and her cheeks were flushed. Occasionally she moved and he would shift his arm, sometimes kissing her dark, shining hair. That afternoon gave them a rare peacefulness, as if to create a lasting memory before their separation. They were never closer in their brief romance, nor understood each other so deeply, than in those silent gestures—Daisy’s gentle touch on Gatsby’s coat, or when he softly held her fingers, as if she were asleep.

events.title: War, Oxford, Daisy's Impatience, and Gatsby's Return
detailed_summary: Gatsby performed well in the war, reaching the rank of Major, but complications sent him to Oxford afterwards instead of home.
Daisy's letters became nervously desperate; she felt external pressures and needed Gatsby's reassurance.
Her world of privilege, parties, and social expectations pushed her towards making a decision about her life.
She resumed dating multiple men, caught between her feelings for Gatsby and the need for immediate security.
Tom Buchanan arrived, representing stability and wealth, flattering Daisy.
She married Tom, a decision likely involving both struggle and relief; Gatsby received her letter while at Oxford.
As dawn breaks at Gatsby's house, he insists to Nick that Daisy never loved Tom, or only briefly, claiming her confession was coerced.
Gatsby makes the enigmatic comment that the affair 'was just personal'.
After the war, penniless, Gatsby travelled to Louisville while Tom and Daisy were on their honeymoon.
He revisited places he and Daisy shared, finding the city imbued with melancholy beauty due to her absence.
Leaving Louisville by train, he felt he hadn't searched hard enough, that he was leaving her behind.
He watched the city fade, feeling he had lost the best part of his past forever.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: He did extraordinarily well in the war.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: But it was all going by too fast now for his blurred eyes and he knew that he had lost that part of it, the freshest and the best, forever.

events.text_segment:
He did extraordinarily well in the war. He was a captain before he went to the front, and following the Argonne battles he got his majority and the command of the divisional machine-guns. After the armistice he tried frantically to get home, but some complication or misunderstanding sent him to Oxford instead. He was worried now—there was a quality of nervous despair in Daisy’s letters. She didn’t see why he couldn’t come. She was feeling the pressure of the world outside, and she wanted to see him and feel his presence beside her and be reassured that she was doing the right thing after all.
For Daisy was young and her artificial world was redolent of orchids and pleasant, cheerful snobbery and orchestras which set the rhythm of the year, summing up the sadness and suggestiveness of life in new tunes. All night the saxophones wailed the hopeless comment of the “Beale Street Blues” while a hundred pairs of golden and silver slippers shuffled the shining dust. At the grey tea hour there were always rooms that throbbed incessantly with this low, sweet fever, while fresh faces drifted here and there like rose petals blown by the sad horns around the floor.
Through this twilight universe Daisy began to move again with the season; suddenly she was again keeping half a dozen dates a day with half a dozen men, and drowsing asleep at dawn with the beads and chiffon of an evening-dress tangled among dying orchids on the floor beside her bed. And all the time something within her was crying for a decision. She wanted her life shaped now, immediately—and the decision must be made by some force—of love, of money, of unquestionable practicality—that was close at hand.
That force took shape in the middle of spring with the arrival of Tom Buchanan. There was a wholesome bulkiness about his person and his position, and Daisy was flattered. Doubtless there was a certain struggle and a certain relief. The letter reached Gatsby while he was still at Oxford.
It was dawn now on Long Island and we went about opening the rest of the windows downstairs, filling the house with grey-turning, gold-turning light. The shadow of a tree fell abruptly across the dew and ghostly birds began to sing among the blue leaves. There was a slow, pleasant movement in the air, scarcely a wind, promising a cool, lovely day.
“I don’t think she ever loved him.” Gatsby turned around from a window and looked at me challengingly. “You must remember, old sport, she was very excited this afternoon. He told her those things in a way that frightened her—that made it look as if I was some kind of cheap sharper. And the result was she hardly knew what she was saying.”
He sat down gloomily.
“Of course she might have loved him just for a minute, when they were first married—and loved me more even then, do you see?”
Suddenly he came out with a curious remark.
“In any case,” he said, “it was just personal.”
What could you make of that, except to suspect some intensity in his conception of the affair that couldn’t be measured?
He came back from France when Tom and Daisy were still on their wedding trip, and made a miserable but irresistible journey to Louisville on the last of his army pay. He stayed there a week, walking the streets where their footsteps had clicked together through the November night and revisiting the out-of-the-way places to which they had driven in her white car. Just as Daisy’s house had always seemed to him more mysterious and gay than other houses, so his idea of the city itself, even though she was gone from it, was pervaded with a melancholy beauty.
He left feeling that if he had searched harder, he might have found her—that he was leaving her behind. The day-coach—he was penniless now—was hot. He went out to the open vestibule and sat down on a folding-chair, and the station slid away and the backs of unfamiliar buildings moved by. Then out into the spring fields, where a yellow trolley raced them for a minute with people in it who might once have seen the pale magic of her face along the casual street.
The track curved and now it was going away from the sun, which, as it sank lower, seemed to spread itself in benediction over the vanishing city where she had drawn her breath. He stretched out his hand desperately as if to snatch only a wisp of air, to save a fragment of the spot that she had made lovely for him. But it was all going by too fast now for his blurred eyes and he knew that he had lost that part of it, the freshest and the best, forever.

events.title: Nick's Departure and Final Words to Gatsby
detailed_summary: After breakfast, the weather feels autumnal.
Gatsby's gardener plans to drain the pool, but Gatsby asks him to wait, telling Nick he hasn't used it all summer.
Nick feels reluctant to leave Gatsby for work in the city and misses several trains.
He promises to call Gatsby around noon.
As they walk down the steps, Gatsby anxiously hopes Daisy will call.
Nick reassures him.
As Nick walks away, he turns back and shouts across the lawn that Gatsby is worth more than the 'rotten crowd' he associates with.
Nick reflects that this was his only compliment to Gatsby, despite disapproving of him.
Gatsby responds with a radiant, understanding smile.
Nick remembers first arriving at Gatsby's house months earlier, contrasting the past crowds with Gatsby's solitary stance concealing his 'incorruptible dream'.
Nick thanks Gatsby for his hospitality and says goodbye.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: It was nine o’clock when we finished breakfast and went out on the porch.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Goodbye,” I called. “I enjoyed breakfast, Gatsby.”

events.text_segment:
It was nine o’clock when we finished breakfast and went out on the porch. The night had made a sharp difference in the weather and there was an autumn flavour in the air. The gardener, the last one of Gatsby’s former servants, came to the foot of the steps.
“I’m going to drain the pool today, Mr. Gatsby. Leaves’ll start falling pretty soon, and then there’s always trouble with the pipes.”
“Don’t do it today,” Gatsby answered. He turned to me apologetically. “You know, old sport, I’ve never used that pool all summer?”
I looked at my watch and stood up.
“Twelve minutes to my train.”
I didn’t want to go to the city. I wasn’t worth a decent stroke of work, but it was more than that—I didn’t want to leave Gatsby. I missed that train, and then another, before I could get myself away.
“I’ll call you up,” I said finally.
“Do, old sport.”
“I’ll call you about noon.”
We walked slowly down the steps.
“I suppose Daisy’ll call too.” He looked at me anxiously, as if he hoped I’d corroborate this.
“I suppose so.”
“Well, goodbye.”
We shook hands and I started away. Just before I reached the hedge I remembered something and turned around.
“They’re a rotten crowd,” I shouted across the lawn. “You’re worth the whole damn bunch put together.”
I’ve always been glad I said that. It was the only compliment I ever gave him, because I disapproved of him from beginning to end. First he nodded politely, and then his face broke into that radiant and understanding smile, as if we’d been in ecstatic cahoots on that fact all the time. His gorgeous pink rag of a suit made a bright spot of colour against the white steps, and I thought of the night when I first came to his ancestral home, three months before. The lawn and drive had been crowded with the faces of those who guessed at his corruption—and he had stood on those steps, concealing his incorruptible dream, as he waved them goodbye.
I thanked him for his hospitality. We were always thanking him for that—I and the others.
“Goodbye,” I called. “I enjoyed breakfast, Gatsby.”

I felt reluctant to go back to the city, partly because I wasn't in a mood to work effectively, but more so because I didn't want to leave Gatsby. “Goodbye,” he said.

We shook hands, and I started to walk away. Just as I reached the hedge at the edge of the lawn, I turned back, calling out, “They’re a lousy bunch, and you’re better than all of them put together.” That was the only real compliment I ever gave Gatsby, despite my overall disapproval of him—but I’ve always been glad I said it. "Goodbye," I called. "Breakfast was great, Gatsby."

events.title: Nick's Distracted Day and Breakup with Jordan
detailed_summary: In the city, Nick is unable to focus on work and falls asleep.
He's awakened by a phone call from Jordan Baker just before noon.
Jordan sounds harsh and dry, unlike her usual cool tone.
She informs Nick she has left Daisy's house and is heading to Southampton.
Nick is annoyed by her departure from Daisy's.
Jordan confronts Nick about his behavior the previous night.
Their conversation becomes stilted and awkward as they arrange, then cancel, plans to meet.
The call ends abruptly, with Nick realizing their relationship is over and feeling indifferent.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Up in the city, I tried for a while to list the quotations on an interminable amount of stock, then I fell asleep in my swivel-chair.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I couldn’t have talked to her across a tea-table that day if I never talked to her again in this world.

events.text_segment:
Up in the city, I tried for a while to list the quotations on an interminable amount of stock, then I fell asleep in my swivel-chair. Just before noon the phone woke me, and I started up with sweat breaking out on my forehead. It was Jordan Baker; she often called me up at this hour because the uncertainty of her own movements between hotels and clubs and private houses made her hard to find in any other way. Usually her voice came over the wire as something fresh and cool, as if a divot from a green golf-links had come sailing in at the office window, but this morning it seemed harsh and dry.
“I’ve left Daisy’s house,” she said. “I’m at Hempstead, and I’m going down to Southampton this afternoon.”
Probably it had been tactful to leave Daisy’s house, but the act annoyed me, and her next remark made me rigid.
“You weren’t so nice to me last night.”
“How could it have mattered then?”
Silence for a moment. Then:
“However—I want to see you.”
“I want to see you, too.”
“Suppose I don’t go to Southampton, and come into town this afternoon?”
“No—I don’t think this afternoon.”
“Very well.”
“It’s impossible this afternoon. Various—”
We talked like that for a while, and then abruptly we weren’t talking any longer. I don’t know which of us hung up with a sharp click, but I know I didn’t care. I couldn’t have talked to her across a tea-table that day if I never talked to her again in this world.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: While at my city office, I attempted for a time to record stock prices, which felt endless, but eventually I dozed off in my office chair. My telephone rang just before midday, startling me awake and causing me to sit up abruptly, with perspiration forming on my brow. It was Jordan Baker calling; she frequently contacted me around this time of day because her unpredictable schedule, constantly moving among hotels, social clubs, and private residences, made it difficult to locate her otherwise. Typically, her voice sounded refreshing and calm on the phone line, like a piece of turf from a well-kept golf course had floated in through the office window, but today her tone sounded rough and devoid of warmth. "I've departed from Daisy's residence," she informed me. "I'm currently in Hempstead and plan to travel south to Southampton later today." It was likely a considerate move for her to have departed Daisy's place, but the action bothered me, and her subsequent comment caused me to become tense. "You weren't very pleasant towards me yesterday evening." "Why would that have been important at that moment?" A brief pause followed. Then she continued: "Nevertheless, I would like to meet with you." "I also wish to see you." "What if I decide not to proceed to Southampton and instead come into the city this afternoon?" "No, I don't believe this afternoon is suitable." "Alright." "It won't be possible today. Several..." Our conversation continued in that strained manner for a short time, and then it ended suddenly. I'm not sure who ended the call with that distinct click, but I am certain I was indifferent about it. I felt incapable of having a calm, civil conversation with her at that moment, even if it meant never speaking to her again in my life.

We continued with this back and forth for a bit, until suddenly the conversation just ended. I have no idea who hung up abruptly, but I felt indifferent. At that moment, I couldn’t have sat across from her at a tea table, even if it meant never seeing her again.

events.title: Failed Call to Gatsby and Wilson's Grief-Stricken Vigil
detailed_summary: Nick attempts to call Gatsby several times but finds the line busy, eventually learning it's held for a long-distance call from Detroit.
He plans to take the 3:50 train.
The narrative shifts focus back to the previous night at Wilson's garage after the accident.
Nick reflects on passing the ash-heaps earlier, deliberately avoiding the scene.
Myrtle's sister, Catherine, arrived drunk and distraught, fainting when told the ambulance had already left.
George Wilson remained inside the garage, rocking in grief, while a crowd gathered outside.
Michaelis, the neighboring restaurant owner, stayed with Wilson throughout the night, along with a few other men initially.
Eventually, Michaelis sent the last stranger away and remained alone with Wilson until dawn, making coffee to stay awake.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: I called Gatsby’s house a few minutes later, but the line was busy.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: After that, he stayed there alone with Wilson until dawn.

events.text_segment:
I called Gatsby’s house a few minutes later, but the line was busy. I tried four times; finally an exasperated central told me the wire was being kept open for long distance from Detroit. Taking out my timetable, I drew a small circle around the three-fifty train. Then I leaned back in my chair and tried to think. It was just noon.
When I passed the ash-heaps on the train that morning I had crossed deliberately to the other side of the car. I supposed there’d be a curious crowd around there all day with little boys searching for dark spots in the dust, and some garrulous man telling over and over what had happened, until it became less and less real even to him and he could tell it no longer, and Myrtle Wilson’s tragic achievement was forgotten. Now I want to go back a little and tell what happened at the garage after we left there the night before.
They had difficulty in locating the sister, Catherine. She must have broken her rule against drinking that night, for when she arrived she was stupid with liquor and unable to understand that the ambulance had already gone to Flushing. When they convinced her of this, she immediately fainted, as if that was the intolerable part of the affair. Someone, kind or curious, took her in his car and drove her in the wake of her sister’s body.
Until long after midnight a changing crowd lapped up against the front of the garage, while George Wilson rocked himself back and forth on the couch inside. For a while the door of the office was open, and everyone who came into the garage glanced irresistibly through it. Finally someone said it was a shame, and closed the door. Michaelis and several other men were with him; first, four or five men, later two or three men. Still later Michaelis had to ask the last stranger to wait there fifteen minutes longer, while he went back to his own place and made a pot of coffee. After that, he stayed there alone with Wilson until dawn.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: A few minutes later, I telephoned Gatsby's house, but the line was in use. Taking out my train schedule, I drew a small circle around the train scheduled for three-fifty. Then I settled back in my chair and attempted to clear my thoughts. It was precisely noon. When I rode past the valley of ashes by train that morning, I purposefully moved to the opposite side of the carriage. I assumed there would be a curious crowd gathered there all day, with young boys sifting through the dust for dark marks, and a chatty man recounting the events repeatedly until they seemed increasingly unreal even to him and he could no longer tell the story, and Myrtle Wilson's tragic end would be forgotten. Now, I want to briefly recount what happened at the garage after we left the night before. Finding Catherine, Myrtle's sister, presented a challenge. She must have broken her usual practice of not drinking that night, because when she arrived, she was heavily intoxicated and couldn't comprehend that the ambulance had already departed for Flushing. Once they managed to make her understand this, she immediately fainted, as if that specific piece of information was the most unbearable aspect of the whole situation. Someone, perhaps out of compassion or just curiosity, put her in their car and followed behind her sister's body. A fluctuating group of people stayed gathered in front of the garage until long after midnight, while inside, George Wilson rocked back and forth on the couch. For a time, the office door remained open, and everyone who entered the garage couldn't help but glance through it. Eventually, someone commented that it was indecent and closed the door. Michaelis and several other men were there with him; initially, four or five men, later two or three. Even later, Michaelis had to request the final remaining stranger to wait fifteen minutes longer while he went back to his own place to make some coffee. After that, he stayed there by himself with Wilson until the morning.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14: A few minutes later I tried calling Gatsby's house, but the phone was busy. I made four attempts before a frustrated operator explained that the line was reserved for a long-distance call from Detroit. I consulted my schedule and circled the 3:50 train, then leaned back to think, realizing it was only noon. That morning, as I rode the train past the ash heaps, I moved to the opposite side of the car. I imagined that area would be crowded all day: children searching the dust and a talkative man repeatedly recounting what happened—until even he lost hold of the reality and Myrtle Wilson's fate was forgotten. Now I want to go back and describe the events at the garage after we left that night. It took some time to find Catherine, Myrtle’s sister. It seemed she must have broken her no-drinking rule, because when she arrived she was drunk and couldn't grasp that the ambulance had already gone to Flushing. Once she understood, she fainted, as if that was the unbearable part. Someone—out of concern or curiosity—gave her a ride to follow her sister’s body. Well after midnight, crowds came and went outside the garage, while George Wilson sat inside, rocking on the couch. For a period, the office door was left open, and everyone who entered would inevitably look in. Eventually, someone remarked it was a shame and closed the door. Michaelis and a few other men stayed with Wilson: at first four or five, then two or three, and later Michaelis had to ask the last visitor to wait another quarter hour while he went to his own place to make coffee. Michaelis then remained alone with Wilson until morning.

events.title: Wilson's Dawning Suspicion and Ominous Resolve
detailed_summary: Around 3 a.m., Wilson grows quieter and starts talking about the yellow car, claiming he knows how to find its owner.
He mentions Myrtle returning from the city months ago with bruises.
Overcome with grief, he cries out again.

Wilson directs Michaelis to a drawer containing a small, expensive, new-looking dog leash braided with silver.
Wilson reveals he found it the previous afternoon and suspected something 'funny'.
Michaelis offers innocent explanations, but Wilson, likely having heard similar excuses from Myrtle, becomes distressed again.

events.text_segment:
About three o’clock the quality of Wilson’s incoherent muttering changed—he grew quieter and began to talk about the yellow car. He announced that he had a way of finding out whom the yellow car belonged to, and then he blurted out that a couple of months ago his wife had come from the city with her face bruised and her nose swollen.
But when he heard himself say this, he flinched and began to cry “Oh, my God!” again in his groaning voice. Michaelis made a clumsy attempt to distract him.
“How long have you been married, George? Come on there, try and sit still a minute, and answer my question. How long have you been married?”
“Twelve years.”
“Ever had any children? Come on, George, sit still—I asked you a question. Did you ever have any children?”
The hard brown beetles kept thudding against the dull light, and whenever Michaelis heard a car go tearing along the road outside it sounded to him like the car that hadn’t stopped a few hours before. He didn’t like to go into the garage, because the work bench was stained where the body had been lying, so he moved uncomfortably around the office—he knew every object in it before morning—and from time to time sat down beside Wilson trying to keep him more quiet.
“Have you got a church you go to sometimes, George? Maybe even if you haven’t been there for a long time? Maybe I could call up the church and get a priest to come over and he could talk to you, see?”
“Don’t belong to any.”
“You ought to have a church, George, for times like this. You must have gone to church once. Didn’t you get married in a church? Listen, George, listen to me. Didn’t you get married in a church?”
“That was a long time ago.”
The effort of answering broke the rhythm of his rocking—for a moment he was silent. Then the same half-knowing, half-bewildered look came back into his faded eyes.
“Look in the drawer there,” he said, pointing at the desk.
“Which drawer?”
“That drawer—that one.”
Michaelis opened the drawer nearest his hand. There was nothing in it but a small, expensive dog-leash, made of leather and braided silver. It was apparently new.
“This?” he inquired, holding it up.
Wilson stared and nodded.
“I found it yesterday afternoon. She tried to tell me about it, but I knew it was something funny.”
“You mean your wife bought it?”
“She had it wrapped in tissue paper on her bureau.”
Michaelis didn’t see anything odd in that, and he gave Wilson a dozen reasons why his wife might have bought the dog-leash. But conceivably Wilson had heard some of these same explanations before, from Myrtle, because he began saying “Oh, my God!” again in a whisper—his comforter left several explanations in the air.
“Then he killed her,” said Wilson. His mouth dropped open suddenly.
“Who did?”
“I have a way of finding out.”
“You’re morbid, George,” said his friend. “This has been a strain to you and you don’t know what you’re saying. You’d better try and sit quiet till morning.”
“He murdered her.”
“It was an accident, George.”
Wilson shook his head. His eyes narrowed and his mouth widened slightly with the ghost of a superior “Hm!”
“I know,” he said definitely. “I’m one of these trusting fellas and I don’t think any harm to nobody, but when I get to know a thing I know it. It was the man in that car. She ran out to speak to him and he wouldn’t stop.”
Michaelis had seen this too, but it hadn’t occurred to him that there was any special significance in it. He believed that Mrs. Wilson had been running away from her husband, rather than trying to stop any particular car.
“How could she of been like that?”
“She’s a deep one,” said Wilson, as if that answered the question. “Ah-h-h—”
He began to rock again, and Michaelis stood twisting the leash in his hand.
“Maybe you got some friend that I could telephone for, George?”
This was a forlorn hope—he was almost sure that Wilson had no friend: there was not enough of him for his wife. He was glad a little later when he noticed a change in the room, a blue quickening by the window, and realized that dawn wasn’t far off. About five o’clock it was blue enough outside to snap off the light.
Wilson’s glazed eyes turned out to the ash-heaps, where small grey clouds took on fantastic shapes and scurried here and there in the faint dawn wind.
“I spoke to her,” he muttered, after a long silence. “I told her she might fool me but she couldn’t fool God. I took her to the window”—with an effort he got up and walked to the rear window and leaned with his face pressed against it—“and I said ‘God knows what you’ve been doing, everything you’ve been doing. You may fool me, but you can’t fool God!’ ”
Standing behind him, Michaelis saw with a shock that he was looking at the eyes of Doctor T. J. Eckleburg, which had just emerged, pale and enormous, from the dissolving night.
“God sees everything,” repeated Wilson.
“That’s an advertisement,” Michaelis assured him. Something made him turn away from the window and look back into the room. But Wilson stood there a long time, his face close to the window pane, nodding into the twilight.

events.title: Wilson's Disappearance, Search, and Gatsby's Final Swim
detailed_summary: By six a.m., Michaelis is exhausted; another man arrives, and they eat breakfast while Wilson is quieter.
Michaelis goes home to sleep.
When Michaelis returns four hours later, Wilson is gone.
Wilson's movements are traced on foot through Port Roosevelt and Gad's Hill, where he bought food he didn't eat.
Witnesses report seeing a man acting strangely.
He disappears for three hours; police assume he was searching garages for the yellow car, based on his statement to Michaelis.
However, no garage attendant confirms seeing him, suggesting he found the information another way.
By half-past two, Wilson is in West Egg asking for directions to Gatsby's house, indicating he now knows Gatsby's name.
Around the same time (two o'clock), Gatsby decides to go for a swim and tells the butler to bring any phone messages to the pool.
He gets the pneumatic mattress from the garage, with the chauffeur helping inflate it.
Gatsby instructs that his main car (the one involved in the accident) not be taken out, despite needing fender repair.
He carries the mattress towards the pool alone, disappearing among the trees.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: By six o’clock Michaelis was worn out, and grateful for the sound of a car stopping outside.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Once he stopped and shifted it a little, and the chauffeur asked him if he needed help, but he shook his head and in a moment disappeared among the yellowing trees.

events.text_segment:
By six o’clock Michaelis was worn out, and grateful for the sound of a car stopping outside. It was one of the watchers of the night before who had promised to come back, so he cooked breakfast for three, which he and the other man ate together. Wilson was quieter now, and Michaelis went home to sleep; when he awoke four hours later and hurried back to the garage, Wilson was gone.
His movements—he was on foot all the time—were afterward traced to Port Roosevelt and then to Gad’s Hill, where he bought a sandwich that he didn’t eat, and a cup of coffee. He must have been tired and walking slowly, for he didn’t reach Gad’s Hill until noon. Thus far there was no difficulty in accounting for his time—there were boys who had seen a man “acting sort of crazy,” and motorists at whom he stared oddly from the side of the road. Then for three hours he disappeared from view. The police, on the strength of what he said to Michaelis, that he “had a way of finding out,” supposed that he spent that time going from garage to garage thereabout, inquiring for a yellow car. On the other hand, no garage man who had seen him ever came forward, and perhaps he had an easier, surer way of finding out what he wanted to know. By half-past two he was in West Egg, where he asked someone the way to Gatsby’s house. So by that time he knew Gatsby’s name.
At two o’clock Gatsby put on his bathing-suit and left word with the butler that if anyone phoned word was to be brought to him at the pool. He stopped at the garage for a pneumatic mattress that had amused his guests during the summer, and the chauffeur helped him to pump it up. Then he gave instructions that the open car wasn’t to be taken out under any circumstances—and this was strange, because the front right fender needed repair.
Gatsby shouldered the mattress and started for the pool. Once he stopped and shifted it a little, and the chauffeur asked him if he needed help, but he shook his head and in a moment disappeared among the yellowing trees.

It was the man who had been watching the night before and promised to return, so Michaelis prepared breakfast for three people, which he and the other man consumed together. Wilson seemed more composed now, allowing Michaelis to leave for some sleep; when he woke up four hours later and hurried back to the repair shop, Wilson was no longer there. His movements—entirely on foot—were subsequently traced, first to Port Roosevelt, then to Gad’s Hill, where he purchased a sandwich he didn’t eat and a cup of coffee. He must have been exhausted and walking slowly, given that he didn't arrive at Gad’s Hill until midday. His time up to this point was easily accounted for; there were young boys who had seen a man appearing somewhat disturbed and drivers whom he stared at strangely from the roadside. He then vanished from sight for a period of three hours. The police, based on his remark to Michaelis about having "a method for finding things out," speculated that he spent this time visiting nearby garages, searching for a yellow vehicle. However, no garage operator who encountered him ever came forward, suggesting he might have had a simpler, more certain way of obtaining the information he sought. By two-thirty that afternoon, he had reached West Egg and inquired with someone about how to get to Gatsby’s residence. Thus, he was aware of Gatsby's name by then. At two o’clock, Gatsby changed into his swimming costume and instructed the butler that if any calls came in, he was to be notified by the pool. He stopped at the garage to get an inflatable mattress that had been used for guest entertainment during the summer, and the chauffeur assisted him in pumping it up. He then gave explicit orders that the open car was not to be driven under any circumstances—which was odd considering the damaged front right fender needed repairs. Gatsby lifted the mattress onto his shoulder and began walking towards the pool. He paused briefly to adjust it, and the chauffeur offered assistance, but Gatsby shook his head and quickly disappeared among the trees whose leaves were starting to turn yellow.

By six in the morning, Michaelis was exhausted and felt relieved when he heard a car pull up outside. It was a man who had stayed to keep watch the previous night and had promised to return. Michaelis prepared breakfast for three people, and he and the visitor ate together. Wilson was now calmer, so Michaelis left to get some sleep. When Michaelis woke up four hours later and hurried back to the garage, he found that Wilson was no longer there.

Wilson’s movements—which were all on foot—were later traced first to Port Roosevelt, then to Gad’s Hill. There, he bought a sandwich (which he didn’t eat) and a cup of coffee. It’s likely he was tired and walked slowly, as he didn’t arrive in Gad’s Hill until noon. So far, accounting for his time was straightforward—some local boys remembered seeing a man behaving strangely, and some drivers noted that he stared at them oddly from the roadside. For the next three hours, though, there were no reports of anyone seeing him. Based on his conversation with Michaelis, where Wilson said he had his own way of finding things out, the police assumed he spent those hours going from garage to garage in the area, asking about a yellow car. Still, no garage owners who might have seen him reported doing so, so it’s possible he found out what he needed in an easier or more reliable way. By 2:30 PM, he was in West Egg, where he asked someone for directions to Gatsby’s house. So by then, he had already learned Gatsby’s name.

At 2 PM, Gatsby changed into his swimsuit and told his butler to let him know at the pool if anyone called. He made a stop at the garage to get a pneumatic mattress that guests had enjoyed over the summer, and the chauffeur helped him inflate it. Then Gatsby instructed that the open car should not be driven for any reason—which was odd, since the car’s front right fender needed to be repaired.

Carrying the mattress, Gatsby walked toward the pool. He paused for a moment to adjust it, and when the chauffeur asked if he needed help, he declined. Soon after, he disappeared into the trees, their leaves starting to turn yellow.

events.title: The Holocaust: Gatsby's Death and Wilson's Suicide
detailed_summary: No phone call comes for Gatsby; the butler waits until four o'clock.
Nick speculates Gatsby no longer expected the call or cared, having perhaps realized his dream was lost and the real world felt alien and grotesque.
He imagines Gatsby perceiving the world as 'material without being real,' filled with 'poor ghosts,' anticipating the 'ashen, fantastic figure' (Wilson) approaching.
The chauffeur hears shots but doesn't initially react.
Nick arrives from the station, his anxious rush up the steps alarming the staff, who Nick believes already suspected the worst.
Nick, the chauffeur, butler, and gardener hurry to the pool.
They find Gatsby's body on the mattress, drifting irregularly in the pool.
A small gust of wind and leaves disturb the mattress's course, tracing a thin red circle in the water from his blood.
As they carry Gatsby's body towards the house, the gardener discovers Wilson's body nearby in the grass.
The murder-suicide is complete.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: No telephone message arrived, but the butler went without his sleep and waited for it until four o’clock—until long after there was anyone to give it to if it came.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: It was after we started with Gatsby toward the house that the gardener saw Wilson’s body a little way off in the grass, and the holocaust was complete.

events.text_segment:
No telephone message arrived, but the butler went without his sleep and waited for it until four o’clock—until long after there was anyone to give it to if it came. I have an idea that Gatsby himself didn’t believe it would come, and perhaps he no longer cared. If that was true he must have felt that he had lost the old warm world, paid a high price for living too long with a single dream. He must have looked up at an unfamiliar sky through frightening leaves and shivered as he found what a grotesque thing a rose is and how raw the sunlight was upon the scarcely created grass. A new world, material without being real, where poor ghosts, breathing dreams like air, drifted fortuitously about… like that ashen, fantastic figure gliding toward him through the amorphous trees.
The chauffeur—he was one of Wolfshiem’s protégés—heard the shots—afterwards he could only say that he hadn’t thought anything much about them. I drove from the station directly to Gatsby’s house and my rushing anxiously up the front steps was the first thing that alarmed anyone. But they knew then, I firmly believe. With scarcely a word said, four of us, the chauffeur, butler, gardener, and I hurried down to the pool.
There was a faint, barely perceptible movement of the water as the fresh flow from one end urged its way toward the drain at the other. With little ripples that were hardly the shadows of waves, the laden mattress moved irregularly down the pool. A small gust of wind that scarcely corrugated the surface was enough to disturb its accidental course with its accidental burden. The touch of a cluster of leaves revolved it slowly, tracing, like the leg of transit, a thin red circle in the water.
It was after we started with Gatsby toward the house that the gardener saw Wilson’s body a little way off in the grass, and the holocaust was complete.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: Despite waiting sleeplessly until four in the morning, the butler received no phone call; it was far too late for any message to arrive even if one had been sent. I suspect Gatsby himself didn't truly expect the call to come, and perhaps he had even lost interest. If this was the case, he must have felt that he had lost touch with a comfortable, familiar past, having paid dearly for dedicating himself excessively to one ambition. He likely gazed at an alien sky through menacing foliage, shivering as he perceived the distortion in something as common as a rose and the harshness of the sunlight on the newly mowed lawn. He faced a new reality that seemed substantial but lacked authenticity, populated by unfortunate, spectral figures whose dreams sustained them like air, and who drifted aimlessly... much like the pale, surreal shape approaching him through the indistinct trees. The chauffeur, who was associated with Wolfshiem, heard the gunshots but later reported that he hadn't paid much attention to them at the time. I drove directly from the station to Gatsby's residence, and my hurried, worried ascent up the front steps was the first sign that something was wrong, alerting others. At that moment, I am certain, they understood. Almost silently, the four of us – the chauffeur, butler, gardener, and myself – rushed down to the swimming pool. The water showed a slight, almost undetectable stirring as the incoming fresh flow moved towards the drain. Carried on tiny ripples that were barely more than faint movements, the mattress with its weight drifted unevenly down the pool. Even a light breeze that barely wrinkled the water's surface was sufficient to alter the random path of the mattress and its unexpected load. When a clump of leaves touched it, the mattress slowly spun, leaving a faint red circle in the water, like the mark of a drawing compass. After we began to move Gatsby's body towards the house, the gardener discovered Wilson's body a short distance away in the grass, completing the tragedy.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
No one called on the telephone, though the butler stayed up, forgoing sleep, waiting until four in the morning—well past the point when anyone would be around to receive the call, had it come. I suspect Gatsby himself had lost hope that the call would ever arrive and maybe he no longer even cared. If so, he must have felt the warm, comforting world he once knew had slipped away from him, that he’d sacrificed too much for a single dream. In those last moments, he must have gazed up at a sky that felt strange to him, shivered beneath unsettling leaves, and felt a chill at how bizarre a rose could appear and how harsh the sunlight was on newly grown grass. The world around him seemed new, physical but not truly alive—a realm where unlucky souls drifted through life, sustained only by their dreams, like the ghostly figure moving toward him among the shapeless trees.

The driver, who was one of Wolfshiem’s associates, heard gunshots, but later said he hadn’t thought much of them at the time. I hurried from the train station straight to Gatsby’s mansion, and my anxious arrival was the first thing that alerted anyone to trouble. But I believe that at that moment, they already knew something terrible had happened. Without much discussion, the chauffeur, butler, gardener, and I rushed to the pool.

In the stillness, the water barely moved as fresh water entered from one side and flowed toward the drain. On the surface, the mattress—with its heavy, tragic burden—floated unevenly, barely making any ripples. Even a light breeze that barely disturbed the water was enough to alter its path. As a clump of leaves brushed against it, the mattress slowly turned, tracing a thin, red circle across the pool, like the movement of a compass.

After we started to carry Gatsby toward the house, the gardener noticed Wilson’s body lying in the grass nearby, and with that, the great tragedy was complete.

events.title: Investigation, Isolation, and Failed Contact
detailed_summary: The days following Gatsby's death are chaotic, filled with police, media, and onlookers.
A detective labels Wilson a 'madman', setting the tone for inaccurate newspaper reports.
Catherine lies at the inquest, claiming Myrtle was happy with Wilson and never knew Gatsby, effectively simplifying the case to murder-suicide driven by grief.
Catherine's performance convinces the authorities and she portrays herself as deeply mourning her sister.
Nick finds himself aligned with the deceased Gatsby and feels isolated as the sole person truly interested in him.
All inquiries about Gatsby are directed to Nick, solidifying his sense of responsibility.
Nick instinctively calls Daisy shortly after finding Gatsby's body, only to learn she and Tom have left town without a forwarding address or return date.
The Buchanans' departure leaves Nick unable to reach them.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: After two years I remember the rest of that day, and that night and the next day, only as an endless drill of police and photographers and newspaper men in and out of Gatsby’s front door.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Can’t say.”

events.text_segment:
After two years I remember the rest of that day, and that night and the next day, only as an endless drill of police and photographers and newspaper men in and out of Gatsby’s front door. A rope stretched across the main gate and a policeman by it kept out the curious, but little boys soon discovered that they could enter through my yard, and there were always a few of them clustered open-mouthed about the pool. Someone with a positive manner, perhaps a detective, used the expression “madman” as he bent over Wilson’s body that afternoon, and the adventitious authority of his voice set the key for the newspaper reports next morning.
Most of those reports were a nightmare—grotesque, circumstantial, eager, and untrue. When Michaelis’s testimony at the inquest brought to light Wilson’s suspicions of his wife I thought the whole tale would shortly be served up in racy pasquinade—but Catherine, who might have said anything, didn’t say a word. She showed a surprising amount of character about it too—looked at the coroner with determined eyes under that corrected brow of hers, and swore that her sister had never seen Gatsby, that her sister was completely happy with her husband, that her sister had been into no mischief whatever. She convinced herself of it, and cried into her handkerchief, as if the very suggestion was more than she could endure. So Wilson was reduced to a man “deranged by grief” in order that the case might remain in its simplest form. And it rested there.
But all this part of it seemed remote and unessential. I found myself on Gatsby’s side, and alone. From the moment I telephoned news of the catastrophe to West Egg village, every surmise about him, and every practical question, was referred to me. At first I was surprised and confused; then, as he lay in his house and didn’t move or breathe or speak, hour upon hour, it grew upon me that I was responsible, because no one else was interested—interested, I mean, with that intense personal interest to which everyone has some vague right at the end.
I called up Daisy half an hour after we found him, called her instinctively and without hesitation. But she and Tom had gone away early that afternoon, and taken baggage with them.
“Left no address?”
“No.”
“Say when they’d be back?”
“No.”
“Any idea where they are? How I could reach them?”
“I don’t know. Can’t say.”

Two years later, all I can clearly recall about the remainder of that day, that night, and the following day is a constant stream of police officers, photographers, and journalists passing through the entrance of Gatsby's house. A rope was set up across the main gate, guarded by a policeman to keep out the onlookers, but young boys soon realized they could slip in through my yard, and I often saw a few of them gathered and staring in amazement around the pool. Someone—likely a detective, given the authoritative way he spoke—referred to Wilson as a "madman" while examining his body that afternoon, and his words influenced the tone of the newspaper stories the next day.

Those news articles were mostly filled with outrageous, detailed, and eager but false accounts of what happened. When Michaelis revealed at the inquest that Wilson had been suspicious of his wife, I expected the whole story to be sensationalized in the press. But Catherine, who could have exposed everything, kept completely silent. She demonstrated unexpected strength, met the coroner’s eyes confidently, and swore that her sister had never met Gatsby, was perfectly content with her husband, and had done nothing wrong. She managed to convince herself, breaking down in tears as though the accusation was unbearable. Thus, Wilson was simply labeled a man "driven insane by grief," making the case straightforward and uncomplicated. And with that, things were left as they were.

Still, all of this felt distant and unimportant to me. I found myself alone, standing by Gatsby’s side. From the minute I called West Egg Village with the tragic news, every speculation and practical matter about Gatsby came to me for resolution. Initially, I was bewildered and uncertain; but as Gatsby lay in his house, lifeless and silent for hours, it gradually sank in that I was now responsible—because no one else cared enough, not with the deep, personal concern everyone deserves at the end of their life.

Soon after we found Gatsby, I instinctively called Daisy, without a second thought. But she and Tom had left town earlier that day and taken their luggage. "Did they leave an address?" I asked. "No." "Did they say when they’d return?" "No." "Any idea where they went? How I might reach them?" "I don’t know. Can’t say."

events.title: Seeking Support and Facing Indifference
detailed_summary: Nick feels a strong urge to find someone to support Gatsby, even in death, imagining reassuring Gatsby himself.
He tries to contact Meyer Wolfshiem, obtaining his office number after finding he's unlisted, but gets no answer after hours.
Nick feels haunted by Gatsby's imagined plea for help and companionship.
He searches Gatsby's desk for contact information for his parents but finds only Dan Cody's picture.
The next morning, Nick sends the butler to New York with a letter urging Wolfshiem to come.
Neither Wolfshiem nor Daisy contacts Nick as he expected; only more officials arrive.
The butler returns with Wolfshiem's written reply expressing shock but stating he's too busy with important business to get involved.
Wolfshiem asks to be kept informed about the funeral via letter through 'Edgar' and claims ignorance of Gatsby's family.
Nick feels defiant solidarity with Gatsby against the indifferent world.
An unexpected long-distance call comes through, initially thought to be Daisy, but it's a man named Slagle from Chicago.
Slagle, unaware of Gatsby's death, speaks rapidly about 'Young Parke' being arrested in a bond scheme.
Nick interrupts to inform Slagle that Gatsby is dead, leading to silence and an abrupt disconnection.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: I wanted to get somebody for him.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: There was a long silence on the other end of the wire, followed by an exclamation… then a quick squawk as the connection was broken.

events.text_segment:
I wanted to get somebody for him. I wanted to go into the room where he lay and reassure him: “I’ll get somebody for you, Gatsby. Don’t worry. Just trust me and I’ll get somebody for you—”
Meyer Wolfshiem’s name wasn’t in the phone book. The butler gave me his office address on Broadway, and I called Information, but by the time I had the number it was long after five, and no one answered the phone.
“Will you ring again?”
“I’ve rung three times.”
“It’s very important.”
“Sorry. I’m afraid no one’s there.”
I went back to the drawing-room and thought for an instant that they were chance visitors, all these official people who suddenly filled it. But, though they drew back the sheet and looked at Gatsby with shocked eyes, his protest continued in my brain:
“Look here, old sport, you’ve got to get somebody for me. You’ve got to try hard. I can’t go through this alone.”
Someone started to ask me questions, but I broke away and going upstairs looked hastily through the unlocked parts of his desk—he’d never told me definitely that his parents were dead. But there was nothing—only the picture of Dan Cody, a token of forgotten violence, staring down from the wall.
Next morning I sent the butler to New York with a letter to Wolfshiem, which asked for information and urged him to come out on the next train. That request seemed superfluous when I wrote it. I was sure he’d start when he saw the newspapers, just as I was sure there’d be a wire from Daisy before noon—but neither a wire nor Mr. Wolfshiem arrived; no one arrived except more police and photographers and newspaper men. When the butler brought back Wolfshiem’s answer I began to have a feeling of defiance, of scornful solidarity between Gatsby and me against them all.
Dear Mr. Carraway. This has been one of the most terrible shocks of my life to me I hardly can believe it that it is true at all. Such a mad act as that man did should make us all think. I cannot come down now as I am tied up in some very important business and cannot get mixed up in this thing now. If there is anything I can do a little later let me know in a letter by Edgar. I hardly know where I am when I hear about a thing like this and am completely knocked down and out.
Yours truly
Meyer Wolfshiem
and then hasty addenda beneath:
Let me know about the funeral etc do not know his family at all.
When the phone rang that afternoon and Long Distance said Chicago was calling I thought this would be Daisy at last. But the connection came through as a man’s voice, very thin and far away.
“This is Slagle speaking…”
“Yes?” The name was unfamiliar.
“Hell of a note, isn’t it? Get my wire?”
“There haven’t been any wires.”
“Young Parke’s in trouble,” he said rapidly. “They picked him up when he handed the bonds over the counter. They got a circular from New York giving ’em the numbers just five minutes before. What d’you know about that, hey? You never can tell in these hick towns—”
“Hello!” I interrupted breathlessly. “Look here—this isn’t Mr. Gatsby. Mr. Gatsby’s dead.”
There was a long silence on the other end of the wire, followed by an exclamation… then a quick squawk as the connection was broken.

I wished I could enter the room where he lay and offer comfort, assuring him, "I'll make sure someone is here for you, Gatsby. Don't worry. Just trust that I will find someone." Meyer Wolfshiem wasn't listed in the telephone directory. The butler provided his office address on Broadway. I contacted Information for his number, but by the time I got it, it was well past five o'clock, and nobody answered the call. "Could you please try calling again?" I asked. "I've already dialed three times," she replied. "This is extremely important," I insisted. "My apologies, but I don't believe anyone is available there," she said. Returning to the living room, I briefly thought the many official-looking people who had suddenly filled the space were just casual callers. However, they pulled back the sheet covering Gatsby and gazed at him with horrified expressions. Inside my head, I could still hear his plea echoing, "Listen, old friend, you absolutely must find someone for me. You have to make a real effort. I can't face this by myself." Someone began directing questions at me, but I got away and went upstairs to quickly look through the parts of his desk that weren't locked – he'd never explicitly stated whether his parents were deceased. As I wrote it, the request seemed unnecessary; I was convinced he would react upon seeing the news in the papers, just as I was certain I would receive a telegram from Daisy before noon. But neither a telegram nor Mr. Wolfshiem appeared. The only arrivals were more police officers, photographers, and journalists. When the butler returned with Wolfshiem's reply, I started to feel a sense of defiance, a scornful sense of alliance connecting Gatsby and me against everyone else. His letter read: "Dear Mr. Carraway. This is one of the most terrible shocks of my life I can hardly believe it is true at all. Such a mad act as that man did should make us all think. I hardly know where I am when I hear about a thing like this and am completely knocked down and out. Yours truly Meyer Wolfshiem". Below his signature, there was a hurried addition: "Let me know about the funeral etc do not know his family at all." That afternoon, when the telephone rang and the operator announced a call from Chicago, I initially thought it must be Daisy at last. But the connection delivered a man's voice, faint and distant. "This is Slagle speaking..." it said. "Yes?" I responded, not recognizing the name. "Terrible situation, isn't it? Did you get my telegram?" "There haven't been any telegrams," I replied. "Young Parke is in trouble," he spoke quickly. "They caught him when he passed the bonds over the counter. They'd received a memo from New York with the numbers just five minutes earlier. Can you believe that? You never know what'll happen in these small towns..." "Hello!" I broke in breathlessly. "Listen – this isn't Mr. Gatsby. Mr. Gatsby is dead." There was a lengthy silence from the other end of the line, followed by a startled exclamation... then a sharp crackle as the call was disconnected.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
I wanted to find someone for Gatsby. I wanted to go into the room where he was and comfort him: 'I’ll get someone for you, Gatsby. Don’t worry. Trust me, I’ll get someone—'

I couldn’t find Meyer Wolfshiem’s number in the phone book. The butler gave me Wolfshiem’s office address on Broadway, so I called directory assistance, but by the time I got the number it was past five o’clock and no one answered.

“Will you call again?” 
“I’ve called three times.” 
“It’s very important.” 
“Sorry, I don’t think anyone’s there.”

I went back into the drawing-room. For a moment, all the official people who had suddenly filled the space seemed like strangers, just bystanders. But even when they pulled back the sheet and gazed at Gatsby with shocked expressions, I could still hear his pleading in my mind: 

"Listen, old sport, you have to find someone for me. You have to really try. I can’t face this alone."

Someone started to ask me questions, but I pulled away. I headed upstairs and rifled through the unlocked areas of Gatsby’s desk; he’d never clearly told me his parents had died. There was nothing in the desk, only a portrait of Dan Cody on the wall, a memento of some forgotten brutality.

The next morning I sent the butler into New York with a letter for Wolfshiem, asking for information and urging him to come on the next train. The request felt almost pointless as I wrote it. Surely, I thought, he’d visit once he saw the news, just as I was certain Daisy would get in touch by noon. Neither Daisy nor Wolfshiem contacted us; no one showed up except more police, photographers, and journalists. When the butler returned with Wolfshiem’s response, I began to feel a sense of defiance—a kind of bond between Gatsby and me against everyone else.

Wolfshiem’s letter read:

Dear Mr. Carraway, This is one of the worst shocks of my life, I can hardly believe it. Such a senseless act should make us all think. I can’t come right now since I am tied up in important business and shouldn’t get involved. If there’s anything I can do later, let me know by letter to Edgar. I’m still in shock from the news and completely overwhelmed.

Sincerely,
Meyer Wolfshiem

Then, scrawled underneath: Let me know about the funeral, etc. I don’t know his family at all.

That afternoon the phone rang, and Long Distance said someone from Chicago was calling. I thought perhaps this was finally Daisy. But when the connection went through, it was a thin, distant male voice.

“This is Slagle speaking…”
“Yes?” I didn’t recognize the name.
“Heard the news? Did you get my telegram?”
“There haven’t been any messages.”
“Young Parke got into trouble,” he said quickly. “He was arrested when he tried to cash the bonds. They got a warning from New York with the bond numbers just five minutes earlier. Can you believe it? These small-town cops—”

“Hello!” I cut in, short of breath. “This isn’t Mr. Gatsby. Mr. Gatsby is dead.”

There was a long silence on the other end, then a shout, and a sudden click as the line went dead.

events.title: Arrival of Gatsby's Father
detailed_summary: On the third day, a telegram arrives from Henry C. Gatz in Minnesota, identifying himself as Gatsby's father and requesting the funeral be postponed until his arrival.
Mr. Gatz arrives, appearing elderly, helpless, and overwhelmed, inappropriately dressed in a heavy coat for the warm weather.
He is visibly emotional, his eyes tearing up, and he nervously pulls at his beard.
Nick takes him inside, offering food and drink, but Mr. Gatz is too distraught to eat or drink steadily.
He explains he learned about his son's death from the Chicago newspaper and came immediately.
Mr. Gatz refers to Wilson as a 'madman'.
Nick leads Mr. Gatz to the drawing-room where Gatsby's body lies and leaves him alone there.
After some time, Mr. Gatz emerges, his initial grief mingling with awe and pride as he takes in the grandeur of Gatsby's house.
Nick helps him upstairs to a bedroom.
Mr. Gatz confirms his name is Gatz, not Gatsby.
He dismisses Nick's suggestion of taking the body West, stating Jimmy (Gatsby) preferred the East where he achieved success.
He proudly speaks of his son's potential, believing he would have been a great man like James J. Hill and contributed significantly to the country.
Overcome with emotion and exhaustion, Mr. Gatz falls asleep almost instantly.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: I think it was on the third day that a telegram signed Henry C. Gatz arrived from a town in Minnesota.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He fumbled at the embroidered coverlet, trying to take it from the bed, and lay down stiffly—was instantly asleep.

events.text_segment:
I think it was on the third day that a telegram signed Henry C. Gatz arrived from a town in Minnesota. It said only that the sender was leaving immediately and to postpone the funeral until he came.
It was Gatsby’s father, a solemn old man, very helpless and dismayed, bundled up in a long cheap ulster against the warm September day. His eyes leaked continuously with excitement, and when I took the bag and umbrella from his hands he began to pull so incessantly at his sparse grey beard that I had difficulty in getting off his coat. He was on the point of collapse, so I took him into the music-room and made him sit down while I sent for something to eat. But he wouldn’t eat, and the glass of milk spilled from his trembling hand.
“I saw it in the Chicago newspaper,” he said. “It was all in the Chicago newspaper. I started right away.”
“I didn’t know how to reach you.”
His eyes, seeing nothing, moved ceaselessly about the room.
“It was a madman,” he said. “He must have been mad.”
“Wouldn’t you like some coffee?” I urged him.
“I don’t want anything. I’m all right now, Mr.—”
“Carraway.”
“Well, I’m all right now. Where have they got Jimmy?”
I took him into the drawing-room, where his son lay, and left him there. Some little boys had come up on the steps and were looking into the hall; when I told them who had arrived, they went reluctantly away.
After a little while Mr. Gatz opened the door and came out, his mouth ajar, his face flushed slightly, his eyes leaking isolated and unpunctual tears. He had reached an age where death no longer has the quality of ghastly surprise, and when he looked around him now for the first time and saw the height and splendour of the hall and the great rooms opening out from it into other rooms, his grief began to be mixed with an awed pride. I helped him to a bedroom upstairs; while he took off his coat and vest I told him that all arrangements had been deferred until he came.
“I didn’t know what you’d want, Mr. Gatsby—”
“Gatz is my name.”
“—Mr. Gatz. I thought you might want to take the body West.”
He shook his head.
“Jimmy always liked it better down East. He rose up to his position in the East. Were you a friend of my boy’s, Mr.—?”
“We were close friends.”
“He had a big future before him, you know. He was only a young man, but he had a lot of brain power here.”
He touched his head impressively, and I nodded.
“If he’d of lived, he’d of been a great man. A man like James J. Hill. He’d of helped build up the country.”
“That’s true,” I said, uncomfortably.
He fumbled at the embroidered coverlet, trying to take it from the bed, and lay down stiffly—was instantly asleep.

However, he refused to eat, and a glass of milk slipped from his shaking hand. He told me, “I saw it in the Chicago newspaper. It was all there in the Chicago newspaper. I left right away.” He added, “I didn’t know how to get in touch with you.” His eyes, which didn't seem to be focusing on anything, restlessly scanned the room. “It was a lunatic,” he declared. “He must have been insane.” I gently prompted him, “Wouldn’t you care for some coffee?” He replied, “I don’t want anything.
